title: Q2: How does Basketball Related Income work?
content:
Basketball Related Income” (“BRI”) for a Salary Cap Year means the aggregate operating revenues (including
the value of any property or services received in any barter transactions), received or to be received for or with
respect to such Salary Cap Year by the NBA, NBA Properties, Inc., including any of its subsidiaries whether
now in existence or created in the future (hereinafter, “Properties”), NBA Media Ventures LLC (“Media
Ventures”), any other entity which is controlled, or in which at least fifty percent (50%) of the issued and
outstanding ownership interests are owned, by the NBA, Properties, Media Ventures, and/or a group of NBA
Teams.
BRI example: Gate receipts and broadcast rights
New in the 2023 CBA
Licensing
For the first time since the inception of the Salary Cap / Revenue Sharing system 40 years ago, team and
league licensing revenue from deals where players are not already directly receiving payment as part of the
transaction will be included in Basketball Related Income (BRI). This is expected to add approximately $160M
to BRI in 2023-24, growing annually.
BRI Improvements
Revenue sharing formula will be enhanced in multiple ways, including with respect to the treatment of
complimentary tickets, team watch parties, barter expenses, plaza naming rights, and treatment of equity
transactions. Under the negotiated formula for “Forecasted BRI,” players are again expected to receive 51% of
BRI throughout the course of the agreement, resulting in a projected $250 million collective increase in
Salaries and Benefits in the 2023-24 Season. Depending on the success of our business, players are expected
to earn between $45-50 billion in Salaries and Benefits over the full 7-year term of the CBA.
6
Team Audits
The maximum number of NBPA team audits will increase from 10 per year to an average of 15 per year. A
two-year “lookback” effectively allows for the NBPA to adjust each year for all 30 teams. The NBPA also
continues to have the right to audit the NBA league office annually. These audits are in addition to the annual
joint NBPA/NBA comprehensive audit of all 30 teams by PricewaterhouseCoopers.

title: Q3: What percentage of BRI are players guaranteed?
content:
Note: The players’ share of Basketball Related Income (BRI) will remain within a band of 49%-51%
(currently at 51%).
NBA players are guaranteed 50% of Basketball Related Income (BRI).
In the event that BRI for a Salary Cap Year exceeds Forecasted BRI for such Salary Cap Year, then the
Designated Share for such Salary Cap Year shall equal fifty percent (50%) of Forecasted BRI for such Salary
Cap Year, plus sixty and one-half percent (60.5%) of the difference between BRI for such Salary Cap Year and
Forecasted BRI for such Salary Cap Year; and
If forecasted BRI for a Salary Cap Year exceeds BRI for such Salary Cap Year, then the Designated Share for
such Salary Cap Year shall equal fifty percent (50%) of Forecasted BRI for such Salary Cap Year, less sixty
and one-half percent (60.5%) of the difference between Forecasted BRI for such Salary Cap Year and BRI for
such Salary Cap Year.
Designated Share” means, with respect to a Salary Cap Year, fifty percent (50%) of BRI for such Salary Cap
Year, provided that the Designated Share for a Salary Cap Year shall be increased or decreased in accordance
with the following:
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the foregoing, in no event shall the Designated Share for any
Salary Cap Year be less than forty-nine percent (49%) of BRI for such Salary Cap Year or greater than fifty-one
percent (51%) of BRI for such Salary Cap Year.
The players will continue to contribute 10% of their salary that will go into an escrow account.
The escrow payment acts as a safety net for the NBA if the players receive more than 51% of BRI.
If there was an overage in BRI, some portion in the escrow account will go back to the teams.

content:
● Escrow is 10% withholding of player salary.
● A player earning $10 million for 2025-26 would receive $9 million throughout the season, with $1

Any player who suffers a career-ending injury or illness, and whose Contract is terminated by the Team in
accordance with the NBA waiver procedure, will be excluded from his Team’s Team Salary as follows:
A Team may apply to the NBA to have the player’s Salary for each remaining Salary Cap Year covered by the
Contract excluded from Team Salary beginning on the first anniversary of the date of the last Regular Season,
Play-In, or playoff game in which the player played; provided, however, that if the player played in fewer than
ten (10) Regular Season, Play-In, and playoff games in the last Season in which he played, then the earliest
date upon which a Team may apply to the NBA to have the player’s Salary excluded from its Team Salary in
accordance with this Section 4(h) shall be the later of (A) sixty (60) days following the date during such Season
in which the player last played in a Regular Season, Play-In, or playoff game, and (B) the first anniversary of
the date during a prior Season in which the player last played in a Regular Season, Play-In, or playoff game
under such Contract.
A Team may not apply to have a player’s Salary excluded from Team Salary prior to the first anniversary of the
date of the first Regular Season game that the player is on the Team’s roster under the Contract in question.
14
The determination of whether a player has suffered a career-ending injury or illness shall be made by a
physician selected jointly by the NBA and the Players Association or, upon agreement of the NBA and the
Players Association, a Fitness-to-Play Panel.
A player shall be deemed to have suffered a career-ending injury or illness if it is determined (i) by such a
physician or Fitness-to-Play Panel that the player has an injury or illness that (x) prevents him from playing
skilled professional basketball at an NBA level for the duration of his career, or (y)substantially impairs his
ability to play skilled professional basketball at an NBA level and is of such severity that continuing to play
professional basketball at an NBA level would subject the player to medically unacceptable risk of suffering a
life-threatening or permanently disabling injury or illness, or (ii) by such Fitness-to-Play Panel that the player
has an injury or illness that would create a materially elevated risk of death, paralysis, or other permanent
spinal injury for the player.
What happens if a player returns to play?
If after a player’s Salary is excluded from Team Salary, the player plays in twenty-five (25) NBA Regular
Season, Play-In, and playoff games in any Season for any Team, the excluded Salary for the Salary Cap Year
covering such Season and each subsequent Salary Cap Year shall thereupon be included in Team Salary of
the Team from which the Salary was previously excluded (and if the twenty-fifth (25th) game played is a Play-In
or playoff game, then the excluded Salary shall be included in Team Salary retroactively as of the start of the
Team’s last Regular Season game); provided, however, that the foregoing sentence shall not apply in the event
a player is determined to have suffered a career- ending injury or illness.
After a player’s Salary for one (1) or more Salary Cap Years has been included in Team Salary, the Team shall
be permitted to re-apply to have the player’s Salary (for each Salary Cap Year remaining at the time of the
re-application) excluded from Team Salary.
Can a team acquire an injured player and remove his salary?
Only the Team with which the player was under Contract at the time his career-ending injury or illness became
known or reasonably should have become known shall be permitted to apply to have the player’s Salary
excluded from Team Salary. (Ball cannot be traded to Team X and have his new team apply to have his
salary removed)
If a Team applies to have a player’s Salary excluded from its Team Salary and such application is granted, the
Team will be prohibited from re-signing or re-acquiring that player at any time.

title: Q12: Can a team get financial relief if they waive a player?
content:
Yes. A team is allowed to use the stretch provision prior to August 29 if they elect to do so.
If a Team terminates a Player contract and the payment of the player’s protected Compensation for one or
more Seasons is stretched, then the waiving Team may elect to have the Player’s Salary for the then-current
and any remaining years stretched. If the salary is stretched, the waiving team cannot re-acquire the player
until the end of the original term of the contract.
The calculation is as follows:
From a period of July until August 29 @ 5PM ET, a Team is allowed to aggregate and stretch the guaranteed
salary over the number of salary cap years equal to twice the number of seasons plus one.
The Formula:
●     Player A has one-year and $10M left on his contract
●     Team A elects to waive and stretch his contract prior to August 29 @ 5PM ET. (the deadline)
The Formula:
Years left on the contract x 2 + 1
The contract for Player A would be stretched over 3 seasons @ $3,333,333 each year.
1=3
2=5
3=7
4=9
5 = 11
Recent example A
● Damian Lillard has two-years and $112,583,016 left on his contract
● The Milwaukee elected to waive and stretch his remaining salary over the next 5 seasons (2 years
remaining multiplied by 2 plus 1)
Recent example B
●     Bradley Beal has two-years and $110,794,880 left on his contract
●     The Suns were not allowed to waive and stretch Beal without reducing his salary
16
●   Beal elected to reduce the amount owed by $13.9M
●   Phoenix can elect to waive and stretch his contract prior to August 31 (the deadline)
The Formula:
Years left on the contract (2) multiplied by 2 + 1= 5
The contract ($96.9M) for Bradley Beal is stretched over 5 seasons @ $19.4M each year.
Salary Cap ramifications
The maximum amount of salary stretched cannot exceed 15% of the salary cap- $23,197,050
Phoenix has $23.19M in total salary stretched (Nassir Little, EJ Liddell and Beal)
New in the 2023 CBA
Teams will be permitted to make a one-time election by August 31 of any year covered by the term of a
terminated Contract to stretch a player’s then- remaining future Salary over twice the number of Seasons
remaining on the original term of the Contract plus one. (Note that this modification will not apply to Contracts
terminated prior to the first day of the 2023-24 Salary Cap Year.)
How the rule works: Team elects to waiver Player A who has two years and $40 million left on his contract.
Under the prior CBA, the team had until August 29 to decide whether the salary owed is stretched over 5
seasons. Under the new CBA, the team can elect to keep the first-year salary of $20 million counting against
the cap and then stretch the last year over three seasons (ex: $6.6 million).
The Uniform Player Contract (UPC) will be revised such that the $250,000 minimum threshold to stretch a
player’s Salary will be (1) increased to $500,000 for cash purposes for all Contracts or Extensions signed
beginning on the first day of the 2023-24 Salary Cap Year, and (2) eliminated for Salary Cap purposes.

title: Q13: Do teams receive a reimbursement if a player is waived and signs with a different team?
content:
A team has the right to reduce the amount owed to a player waived if he signs with a new team.
Below is an example:
● Player A is waived and has $10M owed to him by Team A
● He signs a 1 year $5M contract with his new team (Team B)
● Team A will now receive a set off
Here is the Formula:
The amount owed by Team B (the new team) minus Minimum 1 Year of Service* x 50%
●    $5M (new contract) minus $2,048,494 x 50%
●    Set Off = $1,475,753
Team A (the former team) is now responsible in paying $8,524,247 to Player A
*The set-off does not apply until after the regular season
** If the player has 0 years of service and is waived, the set-off formula is Minimum 0 Year of Service (not 1)

title: Q18: Besides player salaries, what else counts against the tax and do teams ever receive a credit?
content:
For luxury tax purposes, the below are added to or deducted from team salary.
NBA Suspension
●   50% of any reduction made to a player’s salary because of a suspension by the NBA. Note: This is not
applied to the team salary applied to the apron.
Example
● The NBA suspended Bobby Portis. The suspension cost Portis a total of $2.85M (1/110 of his salary
multiplied by 25). The Bucks received a tax variance credit that is applied to salary for $1,429,351.
Years of Service
● For any free agent with zero (0) Years of Service or one (1) Years of Service, the amount applicable of
a player with two (2) Years of Service.
23
Example
● Justin Edwards has 1 year of service and signs a contract with Philadelphia. For luxury tax purposes,
$2,296,274 (2 years of service) and not $2,048,494 (his salary), is applied to team salary that counts
toward the tax.
Bonuses
● Any incentive bonus that was deemed unlikely before the season but then earned during the season
will apply toward salary that counts toward the luxury tax.
● A team will also receive a tax variance credit for any incentive bonus that was deemed likely before the
season but not earned.
● A trade bonus will count toward the luxury tax if a player is traded after the regular season.
Example
● Cameron Johnson had a $562,500 bonus that was considered unlikely during the 2024-25 season. The
bonus was earned and Brooklyn had that amount apply to team salary towards the luxury tax. The
bonus is now considered likely in 2025-26.
● Jaden McDaniels had a $431K likely bonus in his contract before the 2024-25 season. McDaniels did
not reach the bonus and Minnesota had a $431K luxury tax variance credit. The bonus next season is
now considered unlikely. It still applies toward the apron.

title: Q22: What are the different first and second apron triggers?
content:
Not allowed if post transactional salary exceeds the $195.9 million First Apron
Signings – “Buyout” Players
Teams will be unable to sign a player during a Regular Season (a) in respect of whom a request for waivers
was made during such Regular Season and (b) who had a pre-waiver Salary for the then-current Salary Cap
Year greater than the full-year amount of the $14.1 million Non- Taxpayer Mid-Level Salary Exception for such
Salary Cap Year.
How the rule works: John Smith has a $15 million salary and is waived during the regular season. A team is
not allowed to sign Smith if the post transactional salary exceeds the first or second apron.
Traded Player Exception
Teams are unable to use a Traded Player Exception more than 100% of the salary of the Traded Player(s) if
team salary exceeds the first apron.
How the rule works: The New Orleans Pelicans are $4.25 million below the first apron. They are not allowed
to trade the $36 million salary of Player A for a player earning $41 million if the post-transactional salary
exceeds the first apron.
The Golden State Warriors sign and trade Player A to Team B. Because they are using more than 100% of the
Traded Player Exception, the first apron is hard capped.
28
Pre-Existing TPEs.
Beginning on the day after the last day of the Regular Season, teams will be unable to use a TPE generated in
a prior year. (For purposes of this, a “year” will be measured from the end of a Regular Season through the end
of the immediately following Regular Season.)
A team over the second apron exception does have access to a trade exception if it is created in the offseason
or regular season. However, the trade exception is frozen starting the following offseason.
How the rule works: The Boston Celtics created a $4 million exception when Jaden Springer was traded.
Because Boston is over the first apron, the exception is frozen. They can use it but only if the post
transactional salary leaves them below the first apron.
However, a team is allowed to use a trade exception if over the apron and the exception was created in that
season. The Celtics have a $22 million TE created when Kristaps Porzingis was sent to Atlanta in July. Despite
being over the first apron, Boston is allowed to use the exception because the trade occurred after July 6.
Other rules if post transaction salary exceeds the first apron:
● Cannot acquire a player via a sign and trade
● Sign a player to more than $5.7 million of the non-tax mid-level exception or for three or more seasons.
● Sign a player using the biannual exception.
Not allowed if post transactional salary exceeds the $207.8 million Second Apron
Signings – Taxpayer Mid-Level Exception
Teams will be unable to use the Taxpayer Mid- Level Salary Exception.
How the rule works: The Cleveland Cavaliers are over the second apron. They are not allowed to sign a
player using the $5.7 million tax mid-level exception.
In the 2025 offseason, the Dallas Mavericks are below the second apron and signed D’Angelo Russell to the
exception. Dallas was now not allowed to exceed the second apron.
Aggregation
Beginning on the day after the last day of the 2023-24 Regular Season, teams will be unable to use a Traded
Player Exception generated by aggregating the Salaries of multiple Traded Players.
How the rule works: The Cleveland Cavaliers are over the second apron. They are not allowed to aggregate
the contracts of two players earning a combined $50 million if the post transaction salary leaves them over the
second apron.
29
Cash
Beginning on the day after the last day of the 2023-24 Regular Season, teams will be unable to convey cash to
another team in a trade.
How the rule works: The Phoenix Suns are over the second apron. They are not allowed to include cash in a
trade if they are over the second apron. The Brooklyn Nets sent cash in a trade during the 2025-26 season and
were not allowed to exceed the second apron.
Sign-and-Trade
Beginning on the day after the last day of the 2024-25 Regular Season, teams will be unable to acquire a
Player Contract using a TPE in respect of a player whose Contract was traded pursuant to a sign-and-trade. A
team is also hard capped at the second apron if they sign-and-trade a player and then acquire a player in
return.
How the rule works: As part of a six-team trade, Minnesota signs-and-trades Kyle Anderson to the Golden
State Warriors. The Timberwolves do not take any salary back and create a $8.8 million Trade Exception.
Minnesota is not allowed to use the exception if the post transactional trade left them over the second apron.
Signings – “Buyout” Players
Teams will be unable to sign a player during a Regular Season (a) in respect of whom a request for waivers
was made during such Regular Season and (b) who had a pre-waiver Salary for the then-current Salary Cap
Year greater than the full-year amount of the $14.1 million Non- Taxpayer Mid-Level Salary Exception for such
Salary Cap Year.
How the rule works: John Smith has a $15 million salary and is waived during the regular season. A team is
not allowed to sign Smith if the post transactional salary exceeds the first or second apron.
Pre-Existing TPEs.
Beginning on the day after the last day of the Regular Season, teams will be unable to use a TPE generated in
a prior year. (For purposes of this, a “year” will be measured from the end of a Regular Season through the end
of the immediately following Regular Season.)
A team over the second apron exception does have access to a trade exception if it is created in the offseason
or regular season. However, the trade exception is frozen starting the following offseason.
How the rule works: The Celtics created a $4 million trade exception as part of the Jaden Springer trade.
Starting on the first day after the regular season, Boston is not allowed to use that exception because they are
over the apron.

title: Q25: What happens if a team finishes over the second apron after the season concludes?
content:
Frozen First Round Pick
If a team finishes the regular season over the second apron, then their first-round pick (the 7th Draft following
the salary cap season) is frozen and not allowed to be traded.
Team Example
Boston, Minnesota and Phoenix finished over the second apron. Their 2032 first-round pick (the 7th Draft
following the salary cap season) will be frozen and not allowed to be traded.
If the Suns are in the second apron in 2024-25, but not in 2025-26, 2026-27 and 2027-28 (three out of the four
salary cap years), their pick now becomes unfrozen.
Note: All 3 teams are projected to finish out of the 2nd apron in 2025-26.
34
Moving Back in the First Round
If such team’s Team Salary exceeds the Second Apron Level in at least two of the immediately following four
Salary Cap Years, then the Frozen Pick will be moved to the end of the first round of the applicable Draft and
the team will continue to be unable to trade it. If more than one team has a Frozen Pick moved to the end of
the first round of a particular Draft, then those teams will select at the end of the first round in inverse order of
the applicable teams’ consolidated standings at the end of the preceding season.
Team Example
Boston finished the 2024-25 season over the second apron, and in at least two of the next four seasons
(2025-26 and 2026-27 for example), then the frozen pick will be moved to the end of the first-round and the
team will be unable to trade it.
If the Celtics are in the second apron in 2024-25, but not in 2025-26, 2026-27 and 2027-28 (three out of the
four salary cap years), their pick now becomes unfrozen and will not be moved back in the first-round.

title: Q27: How many players can you have on the roster in the off-season and regular season?
content:
The off-season and training camp roster size limit is 21 (including Two-Way players).
The roster for each team is set the day before the start of the regular season.
The maximum is 15 players on standard contracts and 3 players on Two-Way contracts.

title: Q28: Can you have more than 15 players on the active list during the regular season?
content:
A team is allowed to have up to 15 players dressed and on the Active List for each team for each game of the
Season.

title: Q29: What happens if you carry fewer than 14 players on standard contracts?
content:
The allowance for a team to have fewer than 14 players under Standard NBA Contracts on its roster “from time
to time as appropriate” will be eliminated and replaced with an allowance for a team to have fewer than 14
players under Standard NBA Contracts for no more than (i) 28 total days during the Regular Season, and (ii)
14 consecutive days at a time.
37

title: Q30: Are teams penalized if they fall below the minimum league wide roster formula?
content:
With respect to the minimum league wide roster formula set forth in the CBA, Step 3 of the formula will be
revised to multiply (1) the number of NBA teams that played games during the applicable Regular Season, by
(2) the number of days in the applicable Regular Season, and by (3) the “Minimum Roster Multiplier”; and:
If NBA teams fail to meet the minimum league wide roster requirement threshold in two consecutive Salary
Cap Years based on a Minimum Roster Multiplier of 14.25.
If NBA teams fail to meet the minimum league wide roster requirement threshold in two consecutive Salary
Cap Years based on a Minimum Roster Multiplier of 14.5, then the Players Association will have the right to
eliminate the third Two-Way roster spot for the remainder of the term of the CBA.

title: Q31: When do player contracts become guaranteed?
content:
● A team will begin to incur a per day cap hit if a player with $0 salary protection is not waived by 5:00
PM ET. on the Saturday before the start of the regular season.
● The last day to waive a player and incur a full salary protection cap hit is January 7 at 5:00 PM ET.

title: Q32: What happens when a player is suspended by the NBA and by their own team?
content:
If the player is suspended by the NBA, he must be on his team’s Active List during the full term of the
suspension, except if the suspension is for six or more games, the player may be transferred to the Suspended
List after the fifth game of the suspension; or
Example
Ja Morant was transferred to the suspended list after the Grizzlies fifth game.
Memphis signed Bismack Biyombo as a replacement player even with their roster at capacity.
If the player is suspended by his team, he must be on his team’s Active List or Inactive List during the full term
of the suspension, except if the suspension is for four or more games, the player may be transferred to the
Suspended List after the third game of the suspension.

title: Q33: Does a team get roster relief if there are injuries?
content:
The “hardship” rules allow a team to obtain an additional roster spot (i.e., have more than 18 players under
contract) during the Regular Season in the following circumstances: (i) the team has four injured or ill players
under Standard NBA Contracts; (ii) the first three such players have been out for at least three consecutive
Regular Season games due to injury or illness; (iii) the fourth player also has missed at least three consecutive
Regular Season games due to injury or illness; and (iv) all four players will continue to be unable to perform
playing services for a minimum of an additional two weeks.
The following modifications to the hardship rules will be in effect for the 2023-24 Regular Season:
Two-Way Players may count towards the required number of injured or ill players; provided that if a Two-Way
Player is among the four injured or ill players giving rise to the hardship exception, the player signed to the
team’s additional roster spot must have three or fewer Years of Service (the same Years of Service limitation
applicable to Two-Way Players); and
A player (including a Two-Way Player) who is determined to be a confirmed positive case of COVID-19 in
accordance with the Health and Safety Protocols for the 2022-23 Season will, upon being determined to be a
confirmed positive case of COVID-19 and until such time as he is medically cleared to resume basketball
activities with his team in accordance with the Health and Safety Protocols, be treated for purposes of a team’s
hardship application as a player who (i) has missed three consecutive games due to injury or illness
(regardless of the actual number of games missed by the player as a result of his confirmed positive), and (ii)
will continue to be unable to perform playing services due to injury or illness for a minimum of an additional two
weeks.
Any contract signed by a team pursuant to a hardship exception during the 2024-25 Regular Season will be a
10-Day Contract, regardless of when during the season such contract is signed. Note that other than in
connection with approved hardship applications, teams may not enter into a 10-Day Contracts with a player
prior to January 5. Any 10-Day Contract signed by a team and player pursuant to a hardship exception.
The Commissioner, in his sole discretion, may permit a team to replace additional injured or ill players on that
team’s roster. Teams seeking a hardship exception should contact the NBA Legal Department to commence
the approval process.
Note: The Mavericks were allowed to apply for multiple hardship exceptions during the 2024-25 season.
However, because they were only $47K below the first apron, they were not allowed to sign a player to a
10-Day contract.

title: Q34: What happens when a player retires?
content:
A player who has not yet completed the playing services called for under his player contract may be
transferred to the Voluntarily Retired List only after the Commissioner is notified in writing by both the player
and the team for which he has played.
39
No player whose name appears on any team’s Voluntarily Retired List shall, without the unanimous consent of
the Board of Governors, be permitted to engage in any Regular Season game within a period of one year from
the date that his name has been first placed on such list.
If such player subsequently desires to become an active player in the NBA, and the team that he previously
played for does not desire to acquire his services, the right to acquire such services shall be determined in
accordance with the waiver procedure.

title: Q35: If a player is waived after March 1, are they eligible for the playoffs?
content:
Any player (including any player under a Two-Way Contract) with respect to whom a request for waivers has
been made after March 1 of a season is not eligible to participate in play-in or playoff games during such
season (unless the player has been acquired by a team whose Active List is reduced to eight players due to
injury or illness).
NOTE: The March 1 deadline occurs at the end of the day on March 1. Accordingly, if a waiver request is made
in respect of a player any time on or before 11:59 p.m. (ET) on March 1, that player will remain eligible for
play-in and playoff games that season.

title: Q38: What are salary cap exceptions?
content:
Non-Qualifying (Non-Bird)
This is an exception for a player that has been under contract for one season and is now a free agent.
Criteria: 1 year
Starting Salary: Greater of 120% of previous salary or up to 120% of the minimum salary
Length: Minimum of 1 year and up to 4 years
Contract Example: Gary Trent Jr.
Trent Jr. was on the Milwaukee roster during the 2024-25 season.
He signed a two-year $7.5 million contract with Milwaukee
42
Early Qualifying (Early Bird)
This exception allows a team to retain their own free agents and exceed the salary cap.
However, unlike the bird exception that requires three seasons for a player under contract, the early bird is two
years.
Note: A player that signs back-to-back one-year contracts will establish early bird rights. This occurred with
Bobby Portis and the Milwaukee Bucks’.
Criteria: 2 years
Starting salary: $14.29M (early bird exception-2025-26) or 175% of the previous salary
Length: Must be a minimum of 2 years with no options. Maximum of 4.
Contract example: Malik Monk
Monk signed a four-year $78M contract with Sacramento.
The first-year salary of $17.4M was 175% of his 2023-24 salary
If the player is an Early Qualifying Veteran Free Agent, the new Player Contract must cover at least two (2)
Seasons (not including a Season covered by an Option Year) and may provide in the first Salary Cap Year up
to the greater of: (A) one hundred seventy-five percent (175%) of the Regular Salary for the final Salary Cap
Year covered by his prior Contract, plus one hundred seventy-five percent (175%) of any Likely Bonuses and
Unlikely Bonuses, respectively, called for in the final Salary Cap Year covered by the player’s prior Contract, or
(B) Salary plus Unlikely Bonuses totaling an amount equal to one hundred five percent (105%) of the Average
Player Salary for the prior Salary Cap Year (or if the Audit Report for the prior Salary Cap Year has not been
completed, one hundred five percent (105%) of the Average Player Salary for the prior Salary Cap Year as
computed by substituting Estimated Total Salaries (as defined in Section 1(i) above) for Total Salaries). Annual
increases and decreases in Salary and Unlikely Bonuses is a maximum of 8%. The maximum allowable years
is 4.
Contract Example
The Lakers Austin Reaves signed a two-year $2.5 million contract in 2021.
Because Reaves was under contract for two years, early bird rights were established.
Reaves would go on to sign a four-year $53.8 million contract with the Lakers in the 2023 offseason. Since his
$1.8 million salary in 2022-23 was below the average player salary, the Lakers were allowed to sign Reaves to
a starting salary of $12 million (105% of the $11.4 million average player salary in 2022-23).
43
The same holds true for the Pelicans Herb Jones.
However, Jones signed a three-year contract with New Orleans in 2021 but with a team option in year three.
The option was declined, making Jones a restricted free agent and allowing New Orleans to use early bird
rights.
Veteran Qualifying (Bird)
This exception allows a team to retain their own free agents and exceed the salary cap.
A player must be under contract for a minimum of three seasons and are allowed to change teams. For
example, Cam Johnson signed a four-year rookie contract with Phoenix in 2019.
He was then traded to Brooklyn in 2023 and his bird rights transferred to his new team.
A player is also allowed to sign a 2 year and then 1 year contract to establish bird rights.
A player that has bird rights with his original team but then is waived and eventually claimed, will now have
early bird rights with his new team.
Criteria: 3 seasons (can change teams in a trade)
Starting Salary: Up to 25, 30 or 35% of the salary cap based on years of service
Length: Minimum of 1 year and up to 5 years
Contract Example: Julius Randle
Randle originally signed with New York in 2019. He was traded to Minnesota in 2024 and his bird rights
transferred.
Claxton signed a three-year $90 million contract in July.
44
Non-tax mid-level exception
The non-tax mid-level exception (valued at $14.1 million in 2025-26) can only be used if a team is below the
first apron and not under the salary cap.
If a player is signed to the exception for more than $5.7 million (the tax mid-level exception) or 3 seasons or
more, the team is not allowed to exceed the first apron.
Criteria: Available to teams over the salary cap but below the first apron.
Starting Salary: Up to $14.1M
Length: Minimum of 1 year and up to 4 years. Mid-level can be split up.
Contract Example: Luke Kennard
Kennard signed a one-year $11M contract with Atlanta.
Because the contract was $5.7M+, the Hawks are hard capped at the first apron.
Biannual exception
A team that is over the salary cap but below the first apron can sign a player(s) using the biannual exception.
A team will trigger the first apron hard cap if the exception is used.
Criteria: Available to teams over the salary cap but below the first apron.
Starting Salary: Up to $5.1M.
Length: Up to 2 years
Contract Example: Aaron Holiday
Holiday signed a two-year $9.6M contract with Houston.
The Rockets do not have use of the biannual in 2025 and are hard capped at the first apron.
45
Tax mid-level exception
A Team may use the Taxpayer Mid-Level Salary Exception to sign one (1) or more Player Contracts during
each Salary Cap Year not to exceed two (2) Seasons in length, that, in the aggregate, provide for Salaries and
Unlikely Bonuses in the first Salary Cap Year totaling up to the amounts set forth below, provided that the
Team’s Apron Team Salary immediately following the Team’s use of such Exception exceeds the First Apron
Level.
A team cannot use the tax mid level exception and exceed the Second Apron Level.
Criteria: Available to teams over the salary cap
Starting Salary: Up to $5.7
Length: Minimum of 1 year and up to 2 years. Mid-level can be split up.
Contract Example: D’Angelo Russell
Russell signed a two-year $11.7M contract
with Denver.
The Mavericks are now hard capped at the $207.8M second apron.
Room mid-level exception
This exception is available to teams that were below the salary cap during the season and is not entitled to use
the Bi-annual Exception, Non-Taxpayer Mid-Level Salary Exception, or Taxpayer Mid-Level Salary Exception.
Criteria: Team must be a room team.
Starting Salary: $8.8M
Length: Minimum of 1 and up to 3 years.
Contract Example: Ty Jerome
Jerome signed a three-year $28 million contract with Memphis in 2025.
46

title: Q39: What are examples of how teams used exceptions?
content:
Example A
Brooklyn elects to renounce all their free agents except for Cam Thomas and Day’Ron Sharpe. They will have
$45 million in cap space available. After they exhaust room, the Nets are allowed to use the $8.8 million room
mid-level exception. They are allowed to exceed the cap to re-sign Thomas and Sharpe.
Example B
Chicago has $134 million in salary but is over the $154.7 million salary cap because of the Josh Giddey FA
hold, trade exceptions and signing exceptions. They have the $14.1 M non-tax and $5.1 million bi-annual
exception available.
Example C
Golden State has $170.5 million in salary and is $25 million below the first apron. They are allowed to sign a
player to the $14.1 million non-tax mid-level. However, if the contract is for more than $5.7 million or 2 plus
seasons, the first apron hard cap is triggered.
Example D
Denver has $201 million in salary and is over the first apron. They are allowed to use the $5.7 million tax
mid-level exception if they stay below the second apron.

title: Q40: What are the exceptions available for players drafted?
content:
First Round Exception
Each Rookie Scale Contract between a Team and a First Round Pick shall cover a period of two (2) Seasons
but shall have an Option in favor of the Team for the player’s third Season and a second Option in favor of the
Team for the player’s fourth Season.
The Option for the player’s third Season shall be exercisable during the period from the day following the last
day of the first Season through the immediately following October 31.
The Option for the player’s fourth Season shall be exercisable during the period from the day following the last
day of the second Season through the immediately following October 31. (For clarity, if October 31 in any year
falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or Federal Holiday, then the deadline for exercising Options in Rookie Scale
Contracts shall be deemed to fall on the following business day.)

Such Options shall be exercisable by notice to the player that is either personally delivered to the player or his

title: Q41: Do teams get an exception if a player suffers a season ending injury?
content:
A Team may sign or acquire one Replacement Player to replace a player who, as a result of a Disabling Injury
or Illness , is unable to render playing services (the “Disabled Player”). Disabling Injury or Illness” means any
injury or illness that, in the opinion of the physician, makes it substantially more likely than not that the player
would be unable to play through the following June 15.
An application for a Disabled Player Exception in respect of a Salary Cap Year, regardless of when the
Disabling Injury or Illness occurred, may be made at any time from July 1 through January 15 of such Salary
Cap Year.
If a Team wishes to sign a Replacement Player, such Replacement Player’s Contract may be for one Season
and provide Salary and Unlikely Bonuses for the Salary Cap Year in which the player is signed totaling up to
the lesser of (A) fifty percent (50%) of the Disabled Player’s Salary for the then-current Salary Cap Year, or (B)
an amount equal to Non-Taxpayer Mid-Level Salary Exception for such Salary Cap Year ($12.8 million in
2023-24)
Criteria: Exception is granted if the NBA determines a player is unable to play through the following June 15.
Timeline: Can apply from July 1 to January 15
Starting salary: The lesser 50% of the Disabled Player’s Salary for the current season or the amount equal to
the $14.1 million non-tax mid-level exception.
Length: A team can sign a player, acquire or claim a player that has one year left on their contract
Restriction: A team cannot apply for the exception if the injury occurred with another team
Length: 1 year
Disabled Player Exception example: Tyrese Haliburton

Indiana was allowed to apply for the exception in July 2025. The Pacers were awarded the DPE valued at

title: Q45: Are exceptions prorated during the season?
content:

remainder of the Regular Season by the amount of the unused Exception as of January 10 multiplied by a

title: Q46: What is the window when a team can negotiate with their own free agent?
content:
And when can they negotiate with other free agents?
Beginning on the day following the date of the last game of the NBA Finals, each team will be permitted to
begin negotiating the terms of a Player Contract with any player who finished the Season on the team’s roster.
The foregoing will have no impact on when a player will be permitted to enter into an oral or written agreement
concerning terms and conditions of the player’s employment or reduce any such agreement to writing in the
form of a Uniform Player Contract or amendment. (NOTE: THIS IS NEW IN 2024)
55
Beginning at 6:00 p.m. (ET) on June 30, teams and players (not on their own team) are permitted to begin
negotiations over the terms and conditions of player contracts that may be entered into after (or, with respect to
certain contracts, during) the Moratorium Period. Prior to 6:00 p.m. (ET) on June 30, teams are prohibited from
engaging in negotiations or other discussions with players or their representatives regarding such contracts.
The foregoing rule governs negotiations or discussions with (i) a team’s own players (other than permissible
talks regarding extensions or other contract amendments to which the team and player could agree at the time
of the discussion), (ii) other teams’ players who were in the last season of their contract during the prior
season, or (iii) any free agent who did not finish the prior season on an NBA team’s roster.
The penalties for violation of the foregoing rule include, among other things, forfeiture of draft picks, fines,
and/or suspension of team personnel.
The foregoing prohibition applies to both direct and indirect contract-related discussions, including through the
media. Examples of such prohibited conduct include (but are not limited to) public statements by team
personnel on the impending free agency of a team’s own player that address:
● The likelihood that the team will offer the player a contract during free agency.
● The amount or length of a potential future contract offers including whether the player may be offered a
“max” contract; or
● Whether the team would be willing to go above the Salary Cap or the Tax Level in order to retain the
player.
If a team representative is asked by the media prior to 6:00 p.m. (ET) on June 30 about the free agency of the
team’s own player, it is permissible to state the team’s general desire for the player to continue with the
organization and/or the team’s intention to begin contract negotiations with the player beginning at or after 6:00
p.m.(ET) on June 30.
To facilitate the scheduling of meetings with free agents in accordance with applicable rules, teams are
permitted, beginning at 6:00 p.m. (ET) on June 29, to communicate with impending or current free agents or
their representatives solely for the purpose of scheduling a meeting to take place at or after 6:00 p.m. (ET) on
June 30.
Any such scheduling communications cannot include any negotiations or other contract-related discussions.
Although teams may schedule meetings with players who will be free agents (or their representatives) prior to
6:00 p.m. (ET) on June 30, teams are prohibited from, prior to 6:00 p.m. (ET) on June 30, making public
statements regarding any such scheduled meetings or attempts to schedule any such meetings.

Compensation, the amount of each bonus included in the first Salary Cap Year of the Contract may

title: Q52: Do free agents count against the salary cap?

A free agent has a hold and will count against team salary until he signs with another NBA team, is renounced

Qualifying Veteran Free Agent,
A Qualifying Veteran Free Agent will be included at one hundred fifty percent (150%) of his prior Salary if it was

2022-23 salary.

Scale Contract
Will be included at two hundred fifty percent (250%) of the player’s prior Salary if it was equal to or greater than

title: Q54: When a player is drafted in the first round, do they count against the cap even if they do not sign a contract?

A First Round Pick, immediately upon selection in the Draft, shall be included in the Team Salary of the Team

shall continue to be included in the Team Salary of any Team that holds his draft rights (including any Team to

Team loses or assigns its exclusive draft rights to the player.
In the event that a First Round Pick signs with a non-NBA team, the player’s applicable Rookie Scale Cap Hold
Amount shall be excluded from the Team Salary of the Team that holds his draft rights beginning on the date
he signs such non-NBA contract or the first day of the Regular Season, whichever is later, and shall be
included again in his Team’s Team Salary at the applicable Rookie Scale Cap Hold Amount on the following
July 1.
A Team that holds draft rights to a First Round Pick may elect to have the player’s applicable Rookie Scale
Cap Hold Amount excluded from its Team Salary at any time prior to the first day of any Regular Season by
providing the NBA with a written statement that the Team will not sign the player during that Salary Cap Year
accompanied by a written statement from the First Round Pick renouncing his right to accept any outstanding

signing the player during that Salary Cap Year,

title: Q55: Is a team penalized if they have fewer than ten players on their roster in free agency?
content:
If at any time from July 1 through the day prior to the first day of the Regular Season a Team has fewer than
twelve (12) players, included in its Team Salary, then the Team’s Team Salary shall be increased by an amount
calculated as follows:
STEP1: Subtract from twelve (12) the number of players included in Team Salary.
STEP 2: If the result in Step 1 is a positive number, multiply the result in Step 1 by the Minimum Annual Salary
applicable to players with zero (0) Years of Service under the Minimum Annual Salary Scale for that Salary
Cap Year.
Example: If a team has 10 players, $1,272,870 x 2 will be included in team salary.
In determining whether a Team has fewer than twelve (12) players included in its Team Salary, the only players
who shall be counted are (i) players under Contract with the Team who are included in Team Salary, (ii) Free
Agents who are included in Team Salary, (iii) players to whom Offer Sheets have been given, and (iv) unsigned
First Round Picks.
