66
● The Contract is for at least three (3) Seasons (excluding any Option Year) but no more than four (4)
Seasons in length.
● The Contract is not signed pursuant to the Non-Taxpayer Mid-Level Salary Exception or the Mid-Level
Salary Exception for Room Team.
● A team acquiring a player in a sign-and-trade cannot exceed the first apron
The first Season of the Contract is fully protected for lack of skill
Example: The Van Horn contract was guaranteed in year 1 at $4.2 million but had no protection in year 2 and 3.
The Contract is entered into prior to the first day of the Regular Season,
With respect to any 5th Year Eligible Player who met one of the Higher Max Criteria, the Contract may not
provide the player with Salary (plus Unlikely Bonuses) more than twenty-five percent (25%) and the acquiring
Team has Room for the player’s Salary plus any Unlikely Bonuses provided for in the first Season of the
Contract.
Contract example
Duncan Robinson was signed-and-traded from Miami to Detroit. The first year is guaranteed.

title: Q57: Who qualifies as a restricted free agent? What is a Qualifying Offer?
content:
A player that has either finished their rookie scale contract, has three or less years of service (but not a
first-round pick that had his third-or-fourth year team option) or finished a Two-Way contract, is eligible to
receive a one-year Qualifying Offer.
A Qualifying Offer can be extended from the day after the last NBA Finals game until June 29.
If the Qualifying Offer is extended, the player is then a Restricted Free Agent.
A team has the right to pull the Qualifying Offer without the permission of the player up until July 13.
A Qualifying Offer expires on October 1, unless a team extends the offer.
If the offer is not extended, the player is still a restricted free agent.
The amount of the Qualifying Offer is based on the below:
67
Rookie scale contract
The NBA uses a percentage based on where a player was drafted.
Example: The salary in 2025-26 for Paolo Banchero is $15.3 million. Because Banchero was the no. 1 pick in
the draft, his Qualifying Offer is $19.9 million (130% off the fourth-year salary).
Second rd. picks or other players
The greater of:
○   135% of the previous contract plus $200K if signed in 2023-24 or beyond
○   The player’s minimum salary plus $200K
○   125% of the previous contract if signed prior to 2023-24
The Qualifying Offer is 125% of the player’s previous salary, or the player’s minimum salary plus $200K.
Example: The Qualifying Offer for former second-round pick Max Christie is $2,293,637 ($2,093,637-2 years of
service + $200K)
● Two-Way players but not eligible to sign another Two-Way because of the years of service criteria:
Minimum salary based on year of service, with $90K guaranteed
● Two-Way players: Normal salary but with $77K guaranteed

title: Q58: Can a Qualifying Offer be greater if certain criteria are met? What is the
content:
starter criteria?
To meet the Starter Criteria, a player must either start at least 41 games or play at least 2,000 minutes during
the 2025-2026 Regular Season. Alternatively, a player must either start an average of at least 41 games or
play in an average of at least 2,000 minutes over the course of the 2024-2025 and 2025-2026 Regular
Seasons.
Top 14 Draft Picks on Rookie Scale Contracts
For any First Round Pick finishing his Rookie Scale Contract who was selected with one of the first through
fourteen picks in the Draft and who failed to meet the Starter Criteria, the player's Qualifying Offer shall contain
the lesser of his normal Rookie Scale Qualifying Offer amount or the Qualifying Offer applicable to the fifteenth
68
player selected in the first round of the Draft (the "fifteenth player") as called for by the Rookie Salary Scale
applicable to the First Round Pick's Rookie Scale Contract. For purposes of calculating such Qualifying Offer
amount, the Fourth Year Salary of the fifteenth player shall be deemed to equal 120% of the Rookie Scale
Amount applicable to the fifteenth player ($8,774,590.
Non Top 9 Draft Picks on Rookie Scale Contracts
For any First Round Pick finishing his Rookie Scale Contract who was not selected with one of the first nine
picks in the Draft and who met the Starter Criteria, the Qualifying Offer shall instead contain Base
Compensation (with no bonuses of any kind) equal to the amount of the Qualifying Offer applicable to the ninth
player selected in the first round of the Draft (the "ninth player") as called for by the Rookie Salary Scale
applicable to the First Round Pick's Rookie Scale Contract. For purposes of calculating such Qualifying Offer
amount, the Fourth Year Salary of the ninth player shall be deemed to equal 120% of the Rookie Scale Amount
applicable to the ninth player ($9,615,393).
Non-Rookie Scale Contracts
For all other players subject to a Right of First Refusal not coming off of a Rookie Scale contract and who met
the Starter Criteria, the player's Qualifying Offer shall contain the greater of his normal Qualifying Offer or the
Qualifying Offer applicable to the twenty-first player selected in the first round of the Draft (the "twenty-first
player") as called for by the Rookie Salary Scale applicable to the First Round Pick's Rookie Scale Contract.
For purposes of calculating such Qualifying Offer amount, the Fourth Year Salary of the twenty-first player shall
be deemed to equal 100% of the Rookie Scale Amount applicable for the twenty-first player ($5,910,257).

title: Q59: What if a restricted free agent wants to sign with another team? What is the
content:
process?
When a Restricted Free Agent receives an offer to sign a Player Contract from a Team other than the ROFR
Team (the “New Team”), which he desires to accept, he shall give to the ROFR Team a completed certificate
substantially in the form of Exhibit G annexed hereto (the “Offer Sheet”), signed by the Restricted Free Agent
and the New Team, which shall have attached to it a Uniform Player Contract separately specifying: (i) the
“Principal Terms” of the New Team’s offer; and (ii) any non-Principal Terms of the New Team’s offer that the
69
ROFR Team is not required to match but which would be included in the player’s Player Contract with the New
Team if the ROFR Team does not exercise its Right of First Refusal.
The player’s obligation in the foregoing sentence to give to the ROFR Team a completed Offer Sheet shall be
deemed satisfied if the Offer Sheet is given to the ROFR Team by the New Team.
The Offer Sheet must be for a Player Contract with a term of more than one (1) Season (not including any
Option Year), unless the ROFR team has tendered the player both a Qualifying Offer and a Maximum
Qualifying Offer, in which case the Offer Sheet must be for a Player Contract with a term of more than two (2)
Seasons (not including any Option Year).
To extend an Offer Sheet, the New Team must have Room for the player’s Player Contract at the time the Offer
Sheet is signed and must continue to have such Room at all times while the Offer Sheet is outstanding.
The Principal Terms of an Offer Sheet are only:
1. The term of the Contract.
2. The fixed and specified Compensation that the New Team will pay or lend to the Restricted Free
Agent as a signing bonus, Current Base Compensation, and/or Deferred Base Compensation in
specified installments on specified dates.
3. Incentive Compensation; provided, however, that the only elements of such Incentive Compensation
that shall be included in the Principal Terms are the following: (A) bonuses that qualify as Likely
Bonuses based upon the performance of the Team extending the Offer Sheet and the ROFR Team; and
(B) Generally Recognized League Honors; and
4. Any allowable amendments to the terms contained in the Uniform Player Contract (e.g., Base
Compensation protection, a trade bonus, etc.)
No Offer Sheet may provide for a signing bonus that exceeds ten percent (10%) of the Compensation
(excluding Incentive Compensation) called for by the Offer Sheet.
70

title: Q60: Does a team have the right to match an offer sheet?
content:
Offer Sheet Matching Period
● A ROFR Team that receives an Offer Sheet prior to 12:00 p.m. (ET) on a day will have until 11:59 p.m.
(ET) on the immediately following day to give the First Refusal Exercise Notice;
● and a ROFR Team that receives an Offer Sheet on or after 12:00 p.m. (ET) on a day will have until
11:59 p.m. (ET) on the two days following such day to give the First Refusal Exercise Notice.
● Notwithstanding the foregoing, for an Offer Sheet received by a ROFR Team at any time during the
Moratorium Period, the ROFR Team shall have until 11:59 p.m. (ET) on July 7 (i.e., until 11:59 p.m. (ET)
on the day following the date on which the Moratorium Period ends) to give the First Refusal Exercise
Notice.
How the rule works: Under the prior CBA, teams had two full days to match on an offer sheet. The new rule
now cuts that down to 36 hours if the offer sheet is sent by 12pm ET. If the offer sheet is received after 12pm
ET, the team now has 60 hours to make a decision. For example, the Suns would have had 2 ½ days to decide
on the Deandre Ayton offer sheet that was signed in Indiana last offseason.
The ROFR Team ,upon receipt of the Offer Sheet, may exercise its Right of First Refusal.
The ROFR Team may match an Offer Sheet by using, as applicable, Room, a Veteran Free Agent Exception,
or the Minimum Player Salary Exception. In order to match an Offer Sheet, the ROFR Team must have, as
applicable, Room, a Veteran Free Agent Exception, or Minimum Player Salary Exception in an amount equal or
greater to the Salary plus any Unlikely Bonuses provided for in the first Salary Cap Year of the player’s
Contract at the time notice of the Team’s exercise of its Right of First Refusal is given and must continue to
have such Room or the applicable Exception at all times the First Refusal Exercise Notice remains in effect.
Any Team may condition its First Refusal Exercise Notice on the player reporting for and passing, in the sole
discretion of the Team (exercised in good faith), a physical examination to be conducted by a physician
designated by the Team within two (2) days from its exercise of the Right of First Refusal. In connection with
the physical examination, the player must supply all information reasonably requested of him, provide complete
and truthful answers to all questions posed to him, and submit to all examinations and tests requested of him.
If the player does not submit to the requested physical examination within two (2) days of the exercise of the
Right of First Refusal, then the First Refusal Exercise Notice shall be deemed no longer to be conditioned on
the player reporting for and passing a physical examination and the following rules shall apply:
(1) In its sole discretion, the ROFR Team shall have two (2) days following the conclusion of the two (2) day
period to withdraw its First Refusal Exercise Notice. If the First Refusal Exercise Notice is timely withdrawn in
accordance with the foregoing, such withdrawal shall have the following effects:
71
(A) The Offer Sheet shall be deemed invalid and the Team that issued the Offer Sheet shall be
prohibited from signing or acquiring the player for a period of one (1) year from the date the First
Refusal Exercise Notice was withdrawn; provided, however, that if the ROFR Team subsequently
relinquishes its Right of First Refusal (resulting in the player becoming an Unrestricted Free Agent),
then the aforementioned one-year prohibition shall be deemed to expire on the last day of the Salary
Cap Year in which the invalidated Offer Sheet was signed by the player and the New Team;
(B) The player shall be prohibited from entering into an Offer Sheet with any other Team prior to the
first day of the Salary Cap Year immediately following the Salary Cap Year in which the invalidated
Offer Sheet was signed by the player and the New Team.
(C) If the deadline by which the player was given to accept the Qualifying Offer (and, if applicable,
Maximum Qualifying Offer) provided to him by the ROFR Team has not already expired, then such
deadline shall be deemed to have expired (which shall have the effect of the player no longer being
able to accept the Qualifying Offer (or, if applicable, Maximum Qualifying Offer) given to him by the
ROFR Team); and
(D) (i) The player shall be prohibited from entering into any Player Contract with the ROFR Team other than a
Player Contract containing all of the Principal Terms (but not any terms other than the Principal Terms)
included in the Uniform Player Contract attached to the invalidated Offer Sheet (except that such Player
Contract may contain an Exhibit 6) before the later of (A) three (3) months following the date the ROFR Team
withdrew its First Refusal Exercise Notice, and (B) the January 15 of the Salary Cap Year in which the
invalidated Offer Sheet was signed by the player and the New Team.
Example
Back in 2016, Donatas Motiejunas and the Brooklyn Nets agreed on a four-year $37 million offer sheet ($6
million of the bonuses however did not count for matching purposes because they were not generally league
recognized honors).
The Rockets eventually matched but here is where things got interesting.
Motiejunas failed to show up for his physical in Houston, prompting the Rockets to pull their right of first refusal.
Motiejunas went back to being a restricted free agent, unable to sign in Brooklyn for a period of one year.
The Rockets eventually withdrew their Qualifying Offer, allowing Motiejunas to become an unrestricted free
agent.
He would go on to sign a one-year $577K contract in New Orleans.
72

title: Q61: What is the Arenas provision?
content:
If an Early Qualifying Veteran Free Agent with two (2) Years of Service receives an Offer Sheet, the player’s
Prior Team may use the Early Qualifying Veteran Free Agent Exception to match the Offer Sheet even if the
team does not have cap space.
The rule is called the Arenas provision and below is the breakdown of the rule and how it could have impacted
the Lakers in 2023.
Gilbert Arenas was drafted in the 2001 second round by Golden State, signed a two-year, $924,000 contract
(yes that was the total), won NBA Most Improved Player in 2002-03 and later entered the 2003 offseason as a
restricted free agent.
However, because Golden State was over the salary cap and Arenas signed a two-year contract in 2001, the
Warriors were not allowed to match an offer sheet that exceeded the $4.9 million Early Bird exception in the
first season.
Arenas would sign a six-year, $66 million offer sheet with the Washington Wizards.
Realizing that teams over the salary cap were disadvantaged in retaining their own Early Bird restricted free
agents, the NBA addressed this rule in the 2005 CBA.
The "Arenas rule" prevents a team from offering a first-year salary in an offer sheet that exceeds the non-tax
mid-level exception ($12.8 million in 2024-25) even if they have cap space.
If this rule had been in place in 2003, the Warriors could have matched Arenas' offer sheet because the $4.9
million Early Bird exception was greater than the $4.6 million tax midlevel.
This leads us to Reaves and the Lakers.
The Lakers had Early Bird rights on Austin Reaves, who had his two-way contract converted to a two-year deal
as a rookie in 2021.
Los Angeles was allowed to offer a contract with a first-year salary of up to $12.6 million (estimated average
player salary).
If Reaves signed (which he did) an Early Bird deal, it will have to be for at least two years, not including any
option years. The maximum he could be signed for is four years, $53.8 million.
Here's where things could have gotten interesting in a potential Reaves sweepstakes:
A team with cap space could backload a multiyear offer, giving him a significant raise in the third and fourth
years.
This scenario played out in 2016, when the Brooklyn Nets signed Tyler Johnson to a four-year, $50 million offer
sheet. Johnson's $5.6 million and $5.9 million salary (the non-tax mid-level in Year 1) in the first two seasons
increased to $19.2 million in the third and fourth years.
73
One example of such a deal for Reaves -- from a team that had $20 million in cap space -- would have looked
like this:
2023-24 -- $12.4 million (non-tax midlevel)
2024-25 -- $13.4 million
2025-26 -- $27.1 million
2026-27 -- $27.1 million
Total -- $80 million
Average -- $20 million (cap space available)
Because cap space is used, a team such as the San Antonio Spurs would have been allowed to average the
contract over the four seasons.
Los Angeles would have the right to match the offer sheet but would not be permitted to average out his
contract because it is over the salary cap, setting up Reaves to be one of the highest-paid shooting guards
starting in 2025.
Fortunately for the Lakers, no team offered Reaves an Arenas provision contract.
A team that has only the $5 million tax mid-level exception and a restricted free agent with non-bird rights is not
protected by the Arenas provision.

title: Q62: Is a player still a restricted free agent if their third-or-fourth year team option is declined?
content:
No. They are unrestricted free agens. A player that is drafted in the first round, and third-or-fourth year team
option declined in their rookie scale contract, is restricted to signing a new contract with the last team they
played for.
An example is the Suns Jalen Smith who had the third year team option in his contract declined.
Because the option was declined, the maximum that Phoenix could sign Smith for was $4.7 million (the amount
of the third year team option that was declined).
The same held true for the Indiana Pacers who acquired Smith in February 2022.
Despite Smith now an unrestricted free agent, the maximum that the Pacers could sign him to is a contract
starting at $4.7 million.
Smith would eventually sign a three-year $15.1 million contract with the Pacers.
74
Because technically the third-and-fourth year team options were declined, Smith would have been restricted in
his next contract (could not exceed $5.9 million) in Indiana if he signed a one-year $4.7 million contract with the
Pacers in 2022 and then became a free agent.
The rule does not apply if Smith were to sign with a team other than Phoenix or Indiana.

title: Q63: What is the Over 38 rule?
content:
The Over 38 rule closes a loophole where teams can sign veteran free agents to 4 or 5 years contracts.
From July 1, 2017 (via ESPN and Bobby Marks)
When the NBA and Players Association reached an agreement back in December for a new Collective
Bargaining Agreement, the thought process was the new Over 38 rule would reward star players like Chris
Paul and LeBron James.
After all it was Paul the President of the Players Association and James the Vice-President that played a
significant role in changing the rule to add a fifth year for players that signed contracts in the early 30’s.
Now seven months removed from the agreement, the Over 38 rule would not play a role in a lucrative contract
for Paul but the future of teammate Nene.
The Over 38 Rule
When Nene agreed to a four-year, $15 million contract on the first day of free agency, Houston thought they
had accomplished two goals.
The Rockets would retain their backup big while also preserving the full $8.4 million mid-level exception.
Nene would be signed with non-bird rights, an exception that allowed the Rockets to start his first year salary at
$3.4 million, 120% above the contract in the previous season.
What the Rockets failed to miscalculate is the Over 38 rule.
The Over 38 rule closes a financial loophole that would see teams sign older players to long-term contracts but
only to see that player retire.
In essence a player could sign a four-year contract in the case of Nene only to retire after the 3rd season and
collect $4 million not to play.
Since Nene’s 38th birthday would fall before October 1, the NBA would deem him to fall under the Over 38 rule.
75
The league would determine this contract as an Over 38 and spread the $4 million in the last season of the
contract over years one to three.
However, since Nene signed a contract using non-bird rights, the fourth year could not be deferred over the
first three years because it would exceed the maximum allowed.
Contract Signed with Houston
Total                        Age
Year 1         $3.5M                        35
Year 2         $3.6M                        36
Year 3         $3.8M                        37
Year 4         $4.0M                        38
Total         $14.9M
Why the Contract is Not Permitted
Total         Deferred     Total
Year 1         $3.5M         $1.2M          $4.7M*
Year 2         $3.6M         $1.3M          $4.9M
Year 3         $3.8M         $1.4M          $5.2M
Year 4         N/A           N/A            $14.9
The $4.0 million in the fourth year would be deferred over the first three seasons.
*Since the first year of the contract would exceed $3.4 million, the amount allowed on a non-bird contract,
Houston would only be permitted to sign Nene to a three-year contract.
The Options: Nene and Houston
For the Rockets the solution is simple.
Houston could sign Nene to a three-year, $15 million contract equaling the same pact as agreed on July 1 but
with one less year.
Doing so however would now decrease the Rockets $8.4 million full mid-level to $3.4 million.
The use of part of the exception now would see Houston looking for bargains in free agency to replenish a
bench lost in the Chris Paul trade.
76
After seeing the contract shortened from $15 million to $10 million, Nene has opened up his free agent options
to explore an offer that would reflect the one agreed upon originally with the Rockets.
If Nene finds a market not suitable to his liking, expect the 34-year-old to return to Houston but with $4 million
less on his contract.
With Full Bird Rights
A Qualifying Veteran Free Agent (bird rights) who (x) enters into an Over 38 Contract with his Prior Team prior
to October 1 of a Salary Cap Year, (y) is age 34 at the time he enters into the Contract, and (z) will turn age 35
on or before such October 1 shall be deemed to be 35 at the time he enters into such Over 38 Contract.
Age (as of Oct. 1)          1-3 Year Contract                   4 Year Contract                            5 Year Contract
33 or younger                      X                                    X                                       X
34                           X                                    X                                  Over 38 Rule
35-36                         X                                    X                                  Over 38 Rule
37 or older                      X                               Over 38 Rule                            Over 38 Rule
Example:
●    LeBron James will turn 41-years old in December. The maximum contract as a free agent in the 2026
offseason is 3.
●    Draymond Green turns 36-years- old in March 2026. If he declines his player option, the maximum
years he can sign with Golden State is 4 and with a different team 3.
Without Full Bird Rights
AGE (AS OF OCT. 1)                                1-3 Year Contract                          4 Year Contract
33 or younger                                 X                                         X
34                                     X                                         X
35-36                                     X                                    Over 38 rule
37 or older                                 X                                    Over 38 rule
77
Example:
●    James Harden declines his player option next season. The maximum years he can sign with a different
team is 3. Harden turns 37-years old in August 2026.
●    Kevin Durant turned 37-years old in September 2025. The maximum years he can sign with Houston is
3 and with another team 3.
How the Over 38 rule is applied
If a player is 37 years or older and signs a four-year contract with his current team, the Over 38 rule will apply.
Starting with the 4th season, because the player will be 38 or older at the time of that season, all remaining
seasons are treated as "Zero Year" seasons and become deferred over the first 3 seasons.
According to the Over 38 Rule, 2026-2027 (the 4th year) becomes the "Zero Year" in this example and is
deferred on a pro rata basis to the prior Salary Cap Years. The signing team must have room for the Total
Salary in 2023-2024, including the deferred Over 38 portions.

title: Q64: What are the different options in a player contract?
content:
Player Option
A Player Contract shall not contain any option in favor of the player, except:
An Option that: (i) is specifically negotiated between a Veteran and a Team or (except in the case of a Rookie
Scale Contract) a Rookie and a Team; (ii) authorizes the extension of such Contract for no more than one (1)
year beyond the stated term; (iii) is exercisable only once; (iv) provides that the Salary (excluding Incentive
Compensation), Likely Bonuses, and Unlikely Bonuses payable with respect to the Option Year are no less
than one hundred percent (100%) of the Salary (excluding Incentive Compensation), Likely Bonuses, and
Unlikely Bonuses, respectively, payable with respect to the last year of the stated term of such Contract; and
(v) that all other terms and conditions (other than with respect to the payment schedule for the player’s Base
Compensation) in the Option Year shall be unchanged from those that applied to the last year of the stated
term of such Contract (including, but not limited to, the percentage of Base Compensation that is protected). If
a Player Contract contains an Option in favor of the player and provides, in whole or in part, for Base
Compensation protection in the Option Year, such Contract must also contain, in Exhibit 2 of the Contract
under the heading “Additional Conditions or Limitations,” either the language set forth in subsection (A) below
or the language set forth in subsection (B) below, but not both, and such language shall define the respective
rights and obligations of the player and Team with respect to the subject matter thereof:
(A) “If this Contract is terminated by Team prior to Player’s exercise of the Option described in Exhibit 1
of the Contract, then Player shall be entitled to benefit from the Base Compensation protection
provisions of this Exhibit 2 to the same extent as if the exercise of the Option by Player had occurred
prior to Team’s termination of the Contract.”
78
(B) “If this Contract is terminated by Team prior to Player’s exercise of the Option described in Exhibit 1
of the Contract, then Team shall be relieved of any obligation to pay Player any Base Compensation
with respect to the Option Year.”
No Player Contract that contains the language set forth in subsection (B) above may provide for the Option in
favor of the player to be exercisable earlier than the day following the date of the Team’s last game of the
Season prior to the Option Year; and/or
An Early Termination Option (or “ETO”), provided that such ETO is exercisable only once and takes effect no
earlier than the end of the fourth Season of the Contract. A Contract that does not provide for an ETO when
signed may not be amended to provide for an ETO during the original term of the Contract. If a Team and a
player enter into an Extension (other than an Extension of a Rookie Scale Contract), the Contract may not be
amended to provide for an ETO and any previously existing ETO must be eliminated. If a Team and player
enter into an Extension of a Rookie Scale Contract, the Contract may simultaneously be amended to provide
for an ETO, provided that such ETO is exercisable only once and takes effect no earlier than the end of the
fourth Season of the extended term of the Contract.
Team Options
A Player Contract shall not contain any option in favor of the Team, except an Option that: (i) is specifically
negotiated between a Veteran and a Team or (except in the case of a Rookie Scale Contract) a Rookie and a
Team; (ii) authorizes the extension of such Contract for no more than one (1) year beyond the stated term; (iii)
is exercisable only once; (iv) provides that the Salary (excluding Incentive Compensation), Likely Bonuses, and
Unlikely Bonuses payable with respect to the Option Year are no less than one hundred percent (100%) of the
Salary (excluding Incentive Compensation), Likely Bonuses, and Unlikely Bonuses, respectively, payable with
respect to the last year of the stated term of such Contract; and (v) except in the case of a Contract signed
pursuant to the Second Round Pick Exception, provides that all other terms and conditions (other than with
respect to the payment schedule for the player’s Base Compensation) in the Option Year shall be unchanged
from those that applied to the last year of the stated term of such Contract (including, but not limited to, the
percentage of Base Compensation that is protected).
Exercise Period
Any ETO must be exercised by 5:00 p.m. eastern time on June 29 immediately prior to the Effective Season of
such ETO. Any Option must be exercised by 5:00 p.m. eastern time on the June 29 immediately prior to the
Season covered by the Option, except that an Option in favor of a player who would become a Restricted Free
Agent if the Option were not exercised must be exercised prior to the June 25 immediately prior to the Season
covered by such Option.
79

title: Q65: What happens when a free agent is renounced?
content:
To renounce a Veteran Free Agent, a Team must provide the NBA with a written statement renouncing its right
to re-sign the player, effective no earlier than the July 1 following the last Season covered by the player’s
Contract. (The NBA shall notify the Players Association of any such renunciation by email within two (2)
business days following receipt of notice of such renunciation.)
If a Team renounces a Veteran Free Agent, the player will no longer qualify as a Qualifying Veteran Free
Agent, Early Qualifying Veteran Free Agent, or Non-Qualifying Veteran Free Agent, as the case may be, and
the Team will only be permitted to re-sign such player with Room, pursuant to the Minimum Player Salary
Exception, or to a Two-Way Contract.
In the event a Team renounces one or more players in order to create Room for an Offer Sheet, and the
offeree-player’s Prior Team subsequently matches the Offer Sheet and enters into a Contract with that player,
the Team may rescind the renunciation (in the case where a Team renounces only one player) or all such
renunciations (in the case where the Team renounces more than one player) within two (2) business days of
the date the Offer Sheet is matched (or, if the Prior Team conditions its match on the player reporting for and
passing a physical, within two (2) business days of the player passing the physical), whereupon any such
“unrenounced” player may again sign a Player Contract with the Team as a First Round Pick, Qualifying
Veteran Free Agent, Early Qualifying Veteran Free Agent, or Non-Qualifying Veteran Free Agent, as the case
may be, and will again be included in his Prior Team’s Team Salary at his applicable Free Agent Amount;
provided, however, that a Team may not rescind the renunciation of a player if (i) at the time the player was
renounced, the Team’s Team Salary was at or below the Salary Cap and “unrenouncing” the player would
cause the Team’s Team Salary to exceed the Salary Cap, or (ii) at the time the player was renounced, the
Team’s Team Salary was above the Salary Cap and “unrenouncing” the player would cause the Team’s Team
Salary to exceed the Salary Cap by more than the amount by which the Team’s Team Salary exceeded the
Salary Cap prior to the renunciation.
A Team cannot renounce any player who is a Restricted Free Agent.

title: Q66: What is a Two-Way contract?
content:
Number of Two-Way Players
The maximum number of Two-Way Players that a team may have on its roster will be increased from two to
three.
80
Two-Way Player Salary
A Two-Way Player’s Salary in respect of a Salary Cap Year will equal 50% of the Minimum Player Salary for a
player with zero Years of Service for such Salary Cap Year (irrespective of how many Years of Service the
player has accrued prior to the Contract or accrues during the term of the Contract). The Two-Way salary for
2025-26 is $636,435.
Year of Service Criteria
Maximum of 3 years of service
A player that missed an entire NBA season because of an injury and has 4 years of service, is allowed to sign
a Two-Way contract.
The rule is named after former first round pick Harry Giles.
The Knicks were allowed to sign Dylan Windler to a Two-Way because the forward missed the entire 2019-20
season with an injury.
Days of Service
A Two-Way Player will not earn “Days of Service” with his NBA team or his G League team.
Number of Games on Active List
No player under a Two-Way Contract will be permitted to be on the Active List for more than 50 games during a
Regular Season. If a player is signed to a Two-Way Contract after the start of a Regular Season, the maximum
number of games for which such player may be on the Active List in respect of that Regular Season will be
prorated based on the number of days remaining in the Regular Season.
A player on a Two-Way contract is not allowed to sign a standard contract with any other NBA team other than
his respective team that he plays for.
Limit on Under-Fifteen Games
Any Regular Season game for which a team has fewer than 15 players signed to Standard NBA Contracts will
be an “Under Fifteen Game.” No Team will be permitted to have a Two-Way Player on its Active List for more
than 90 Under-Fifteen Games during a Regular Season. For purposes of this rule: (a) an Under-Fifteen Game
for which a Team has one Two-Way Player on its Active List will count as one Under- Fifteen Game; (b) an
Under-Fifteen Game for which a Team has 2 Two-Way Players on its Active List will count as two
Under-Fifteen Games; and (c) an Under-Fifteen Game for which a Team has three Two-Way Players on its
Active List will count as three Under-Fifteen Games.
Suspensions
81
When a Two-Way Player is suspended by the NBA, his NBA team, the G League, or his G League team, his
Compensation will be reduced to 1/145th if fewer than 20 games, 1/110 if 20 games or more, 1/174 if the
suspension is for 1 game.
Base Compensation Protection
A Two-Way Contract that is signed prior to the start of the Regular Season may provide:
For aggregate Base Compensation protection of (a) for the 2025- 26 Season, up to $85,300 (an increase from
$50,000 under the current CBA), and (b) for each subsequent Season, up to an amount equal to the maximum
amount of aggregate Base Compensation for the prior Salary Cap Year increased at the rate of growth in the
Salary Cap; and
That the Base Compensation protection for a Season will increase to up to 50% of the Base Compensation
provided for in the Contract for such Season if the team does not request waivers on the player by a date that
is on or after the first day of the applicable Regular Season.
A Two-Way Contract that is signed during a Regular Season may provide for Base Compensation protection
for the Season during which it is signed of up to 50% of the Base Compensation provided for in the Contract
for such Season.
Signing Deadline
The January 15 signing deadline for a Two-Way Contract will be moved back to March 4.
Signing Restrictions
The limit set forth in aggregate future Base Compensation protection in a Contract between a team and player
that will result in a restriction on the player signing a Two-Way Contract with the team or playing under a G
League contract for the team’s G League affiliate will increase (a) for the 2025-26 Season, from $77,500 to
$85,300, and (b) for each subsequent Season, at the rate of growth in the Salary Cap.
Salary Continuation
The separate rules for Two-Way Contracts related to the payment of unearned Based Compensation of the
UPC will be eliminated and, instead, the rules that apply to a Two-Way Player’s right to receive payment of
unearned Base Compensation in the event his Contract is terminated will be the same as those that apply to a
player whose Standard NBA Contract is terminated.
Restricted Free Agency
The rule that a Two-Way Player be on the Active or Inactive List for 15 days during the Regular Season in
order to be eligible for a Qualifying Offer will be eliminated.
Exclusive Negotiating Rights and Exhibit 10 Contracts
A player will not be permitted to sign an Exhibit 10 Contract while under a Two-Way Contract.
82
International Player Payments
A team and player will not be permitted to enter into a Two-Way or Exhibit 10 Contract for one year after the
team entered into an agreement to make an international player payment on the player’s behalf.
Playoffs
A player on a Two-Way contract is ineligible for the playoffs.

title: Q67: What are non-guaranteed contracts signed in the offseason called?
content:
A player that signs a one-year minimum contract during the offseason with no salary protection or guaranteed
dates is called a summer contract.
From July 1 until the day prior to the first day of the next Regular Season, a Team may enter into Player
Contracts that will not be included in Team Salary until the first day of such Regular Season (i.e., the player will
be deemed not to have any Salary until the first day of such Regular Season). Except as set forth in the
following sentence, no Summer Contract may provide for (i) Compensation of any kind that is or may be paid
or earned prior to the first day of the next Regular Season.
The only consideration that may be provided to a player signed to a Summer Contract, prior to the start of the
Regular Season, is per diem, lodging, transportation, compensation in accordance with Paragraph 3(b) of the
Uniform Player Contract, and a disability insurance policy covering disabilities incurred while such player
participates in summer leagues or rookie camps for the Team. A Team that has entered into one or more
Summer Contracts must terminate such Contracts no later than the day prior to the first day of a Regular
Season, except to the extent the Team has Room for such Contracts or is entitled to use the Minimum Player
Salary Exception.
A Team may not enter into a Summer Contract with a Veteran Free Agent who last played for the Team unless
the Contract is for one (1) Season only and provides for no more than the Minimum Player Salary applicable to
such player.

title: Q68: Is a team protected if a player that signs a “summer contract” suffers an injury in training camp?
content:
Yes. A team can include an Exhibit 9 in a summer contract.
83
How the rule works: Under the prior CBA, if a player signed a contract with an Exhibit 9 and was injured
during training camp, the maximum he could earn was $6,000. The new CBA increases the amount to
$15,000.
Roster Requirement
Two-Way Contracts will not count toward the minimum of 14 players required to be on a team’s roster prior to
the team signing a player to a Contract containing an Exhibit 9.

title: Q69: Is there a financial incentive for players that sign non-guaranteed contracts?
content:
Yes. A team can include an Exhibit 10 in the contract for a player signing a non-guaranteed contract.
The $85,300 bonus is given to a player if he plays 60-days for their G-League team.
Bonus Amount
The maximum Exhibit 10 Bonus amount to which a team and player could agree will increase (1) for the
2025-26 Season, from $77,500 to $85,300, and (2) for each subsequent Season, at the rate of growth in the
84
Salary Cap.
Eligibility
The Player shall be entitled to receive from the Team the Bonus Amount (if applicable) provided above,
provided that the Player (a) signs with the NBAGL prior to the deadline set by the NBAGL for NBAGL teams to
designate affiliate players, (b) is initially assigned by the NBAGL to the NBAGL affiliate listed above (or the
NBAGL affiliate of any Team that acquires the Contract, if applicable) and timely reports to such affiliate, (c)
does not leave the NBAGL (e.g., by buying out his contract with the NBAGL and signing a contract with an
international team) prior to providing sixty (60) consecutive days of service during the NBAGL Season (the
“60-Day Service Period”), provided that, in the event the player is signed to one or more Contract(s) by the
Team prior to completing the 60-Day Service Period, the Player shall still satisfy this clause (c) if he timely
returns to the Team’s NBAGL affiliate upon the completion or termination of such Contract(s) and completes
the outstanding portion of the 60-Day Service Period, with such bonus payable (if applicable) within thirty (30)
days of satisfying the above criteria.
Salary Protection
If an Exhibit 10 Contract is not waived prior to the first day of the Regular Season, then such Contract will be
deemed amended to contain an Exhibit 2 with Base Compensation protection for lack of skill and injury or
illness equal to the Conversion Protection Amount.
Returning Player Rights
Prior to signing a player to an Exhibit 10 Contract, a team will be required to disclose in writing to the player if a
different NBA team’s G League affiliate holds the player’s “returning player” rights pursuant to G League rules.
The NBA will impose a fine of no less than $25,000 on any team that fails to make the requisite disclosure in
accordance with the preceding sentence.
Payment to Injured Players
A player will be deemed to have earned his Exhibit 10 Bonus if his G League contract is terminated because of
an injury suffered while rendering services to a G League team.
85

title: Q70: What is a 10-day contract?
content:
Beginning on January 5 of any NBA Season, a Team may enter into a Player Contract (other than a Two-Way
Contract) with a player for the longer of (i) ten (10) days, or (ii) a period encompassing three (3) games played
by such Team (a “10-Day Contract”).
Salary
A 10-Day Contract must provide for the player’s applicable Minimum Player Salary.
86
Unless the contract is deemed a hardship exception, the maximum 10-Day contracts that a player can sign
with one team is two.
Re-signing Restrictions
A team that terminates a 10-Day Contract prior to the expiration of its stated term may not re-sign the player to
a Contract during the original term of the terminated 10-Day Contract.
Signing Flexibility
A team and player may, during the term of a 10-Day Contract, enter into a Rest-of-Season Contract that will
take effect beginning on the day following the last day of the term of the 10-Day Contract
Hardship Contracts.
Notwithstanding the general rule prohibiting the signing of 10-Day Contracts prior to January 5 of a Season, a
team may sign a player to a 10-Day Contract prior to January 5 if the Contract is signed pursuant to the NBA’s
roster hardship rules.
If the length of a 10-Day Contract entered into pursuant to the NBA’s hardship rules would extend to or past the
date of the team’s last Regular Season game, then the term of such 10-Day Contract will be the number of
days remaining in the Regular Season.
Conversion
The team has the right to convert a Two-Way contract based on the years left on the contract.
Example: Craig Porter Jr. signed a Two-Way for 2 years. If the contract was converted, it would have been for
the prorated minimum in year 1 and the minimum of a player with 1 years of service in year 2.
Instead, converted the Porter Jr. by using part of their non-tax mid-level exception. He was signed for 4 years.

title: Q71: What are the different extensions a player can sign and who is eligible?
content:
Rookie scale extensions
All Rookie Scale Extensions will be permitted to cover up to five new Seasons and allowed to extend for up to
25% of the salary cap in the next season.
87
A player that signs a four-or-five year max extension is allowed to negotiate All-NBA language (5th year 30%
rule).
This rule allows a team and a player who meets certain performance criteria to negotiate a maximum salary of
up to 30% of the Salary Cap in Rookie Scale Extensions:
The criteria are based on the below:
● The player was named to the All-NBA first, second, or third team, or was named Defensive Player of
the Year, in the immediately preceding season or in two of the immediately preceding three seasons.
● The player was NBA MVP during one of the preceding three seasons.
In addition, for Rookie Scale Extensions where, at the time the extension is signed, the player has not already
met the performance-based criteria, a team and player can agree upon various percentages of the Salary Cap
(between 25% and 30%) based upon how and whether the player satisfies the criteria.
For example, a team and player can agree that the player’s salary in the first season of the extended term will
be 30% if the player wins the MVP award, or 27.5% if the player is named to the All-NBA first or second team
in his fourth season.
It should be noted that a player can negotiate a four-year rookie max extension with All-NBA language.
This occurred with Pascal Siakam and the Toronto Raptors.
A player has up until the day prior to the start of the regular season to sign the extension.
Contract example
Example: Scottie Barnes, Evan Mobley, Cade Cunningham and Franz Wagner signed five-year $224M
extensions in July.
Salary: First year salary of 25%
30% rule: The contract increases to 30% of the cap in 2025-26 if any of the players earn All-NBA 1st team in
2024-25.
Years: Can be either 4 or 5 new year’s.
Performance Criteria:
●   the player was named to the All-NBA first, second, or third team, or was named Defensive Player of the
Year, in the immediately preceding season or in two of the immediately preceding three seasons.
●   The player was NBA MVP during one of the preceding three seasons.
88
Examples
Jayson Tatum was named All-NBA in 2019-20 and would eventually sign a Designated Rookie Scale extension
in the 2020 offseason. However, because Tatum did not earn All-NBA in 2020-21, his salary in the first year
was 25% of the salary cap.
Evan Mobley was named DPOY Cade Cunnigham All-NBA. Both will earn 30% of the salary cap in the first
year. Their extension will increase from $224M to $269M.
Designated veteran extension
Years of Service and Performance Criteria
Players with one year or two years left on their contracts who have seven or eight years of service in the
league and have never changed teams (other than, if applicable, by being traded during their first four seasons
in the league), and who meet certain performance criteria (see below), will be eligible to negotiate a veteran
extension covering six total years (five new years if one year remains on the current contract or four new years
if two years remain on the current contract).
Waiting Period
Designated Veteran Player Extensions can be signed no sooner than the third anniversary of the signing of the
contract.
Off-Season Signing Period
Designated Veteran Player Extensions can only be negotiated and signed during the off-season (i.e., from July
1 through the day prior to the first day of the regular season).
Salary
Designated Veteran Player Extensions will be required to provide for a first- year salary of at least 30% and no
more than 35% of the Salary Cap (under the 2023 CBA, such players’ applicable maximum first-year salary is
30% of the Salary Cap).
Performance-Based Criteria
For purposes of qualifying to negotiate for the Designated Veteran Player Extension described above or the
maximum salary for certain free agents described in section B.4 below, a player will have to meet at least one
of the following performance criteria at the time of signing:
89
● the player was named to the All-NBA first, second, or third team, or was named Defensive Player of the
Year, in the immediately preceding season or in two of the immediately preceding three seasons.
● The player was NBA MVP during one of the preceding three seasons.
Any player who is extended pursuant to these criteria cannot be traded for one year from the date of signing.
Contract example
Jaylen Brown had 7 years of service entering the 2023 offseason and was named All-NBA for the 2022-23
season. Brown has reached the years of service and performance-based criteria and is now eligible to sign a
five year and up to 35% of the 2024-25 salary cap extension.
His teammate Jayson Tatum was named All-NBA in 2021-22 and 2022-23. Tatum has reached the
performance-based criteria but has six years of service currently. This same situation occurred with Shai
Gilgeous-Alexander in the 2024 offseason.
Because he reached All-NBA in two of the three preceding seasons (2021-22, 2022-23), Tatum was eligible to
sign the Designated Veteran Extension in the 2024 offseason even if he did not reach the All-NBA criteria in
2023-24.
Veteran extension
A player that signs a 3-year and 4-year contracts may be extended after the second anniversary of the signing
of the original contract.
Example: Dorian Finney Smith signed a three-year $12 million contract with Dallas in 2019. Finney-Smith was
eligible to sign an extension starting in the 2021 offseason.
5-year contracts may continue to be extended only after the third anniversary of the signing of the original
contract.
Example: In 2021, Julius Randle had one year left on his contract and signed a four-year extension. He is
eligible to sign an extension on the third anniversary (2024 offseason).
● The maximum length is 5 years (including any years remaining on the current contract).
● The maximum salary of the first year of the extended term is the greater of 140% of the player’s Salary
in the last year of the contract or 140% of the Estimated Average Player Salary.
● Extensions signed more than 1-year prior to the expiration of the original contract may only be executed
during the offseason.
90
● A player with one year left on his contract or a player/team option in the second season, can sign an
extension up until June 30.
● A player that has two years left on his contract (not including an option), has until the day prior to the
start of the regular season to sign an extension.
● A player can include a trade bonus in an extension.
● A Contract that is amended to waive all or any portion of a trade bonus in connection with the trade of a
Player Contract may not be subsequently extended until the later of (i) six (6) months from the date of
the trade.
The following rules apply to all Extensions other than Extensions entered into in connection with a trade:
For each Salary Cap Year covered by an Extension after the first Salary Cap Year covered by the extended
term, the player’s: (A) Salary, excluding Incentive Compensation, may increase or decrease in relation to the
previous Salary Cap Year’s Salary, excluding Incentive Compensation, by no more than eight percent (8%) of
the Salary for the first Salary Cap Year covered by the extended term of the Contract; and (B) Regular Salary
may increase or decrease in relation to the previous Salary Cap Year’s Regular Salary by no more than eight
percent (8%) of the Regular Salary for the first Salary Cap Year covered by the Contract.
In the event that the first Salary Cap Year covered by the extended term of a Contract provides for Incentive
Compensation, the amount of each bonus included in the first Salary Cap Year of the extended term may
increase or decrease in each subsequent Salary Cap Year by up to eight percent (8%) of the amount of such
bonus in the first Salary Cap Year of the extended term.
In the event that the first Salary Cap Year covered by a Contract provides for Incentive Compensation, the
amount of each bonus included in the first Salary Cap Year of the Contract may increase or decrease in each
subsequent Salary Cap Year by up to eight percent (8%) of the amount of such bonus in the first Salary Cap
Year of the Contract.
Recent extension: The Hawks extended Dejounte Murray four-years $111 million with an additional $9.3
million in likely/unlikely bonuses. Atlanta was allowed to include a trade bonus of 15% in the extension. Below
is the breakdown:
Year         Current contract                       Likely/Unlikely Bonuses
2023-24       $17,714,000                           $1,500,000
Year         Base Comp Extension                     Likely/Unlikely Bonuses
2024-25       $24,799,600 (140%-2023-24)$2,099,997 (140% increase)
2025-26       $26,783,600 (8% increase)               $2,227,999 (8% increase)
2026-27       $28,767,536                           $2,436,001
2027-28       $30,751,504                           $2,604,003
91
Murray had three sets of incentives worth $500K each in the current extension.
In the extension, there are now eight sets of bonuses worth up to $2.1 million.
Declined Options
The rule prohibiting a team or a player from declining to exercise an Option and the team and player
subsequently (or simultaneously) entering into an Extension that provides for a Salary in the first year of the
extended term that is lower than the Salary in the declined Option Year will be eliminated.
How the rule works: A player like Jrue Holiday had a $37.3 million player option for the 2024-25 season.
Under the prior CBA, Holiday could eliminate the player option but the first year of the extension had to equal
or greater than $37.3 million (player option). Under the new CBA, Holiday declined the option and signed for
$30 million in the first year of the extension.
Extension chart

title: Q73: Can a player be extended if he was traded?
content:
If a player is traded, the maximum for a period of 6 months that a player can extend for is 4 total seasons
(including what is left on their original contract) and a 120% increase of the greater of the player’s prior salary
salary and the estimated average player salary ($13.9M).
94
EXTENSION EXAMPLE
Player B has a $25M salary and is in the last year.
EXTENSION

Year 2- $31.5M (5% raise off Year 1)
Year 3- $33M ($1.5M added)
Total $94.5M

title: Q74: Can a team use available cap space to renegotiate and extend a contract?
content:
Yes. A Player Contract covering a term of four (4) or more Seasons may be renegotiated no sooner than the
third anniversary of the signing of the Contract.
Any Player Contract that has been renegotiated provide for an increase in Salary or Incentive Compensation in
any Salary Cap Year covered by the Contract of more than five percent (5%), or extended, may not
subsequently be renegotiated until the third anniversary of the signing of such Extension or Renegotiation.
A Team with a Team Salary below the Salary Cap may renegotiate a Player Contract in accordance with the
following rules:
The Renegotiation may provide for additional Regular Salary, Likely Bonuses, and/or Unlikely Bonuses for the
then-current Salary Cap Year covered by the Contract (the “Renegotiation Season”) that, in the aggregate,
would not exceed the Team’s Room at the time of the Renegotiation. (For clarity, a Renegotiation may provide
for additional Likely Bonuses and/or Unlikely Bonuses even if such category (i.e., Likely Bonuses or Unlikely
Bonuses) was not provided for by the Contract.)
Every category (Regular Salary, Likely Bonuses and Unlikely Bonuses, respectively) that is increased for the
Renegotiation Season must also be increased for each of the remaining Seasons of the Contract.
For each Season of the Contract after the Renegotiation Season, the player’s additional Regular Salary may
increase or decrease over the previous Season’s additional Regular Salary by no more than eight percent (8%)
of the additional Regular Salary provided for in the Renegotiation Season. In the event that the Renegotiation
Season provides for additional Incentive Compensation, the amount of additional Likely Bonuses and Unlikely
Bonuses provided for in each Season after the Renegotiation Season may increase or decrease by up to eight
percent (8%) of the amount of additional Likely Bonuses and Unlikely Bonuses, respectively, provided for in the
Renegotiation Season.
95
No Renegotiation may contain a signing bonus, unless the Renegotiation is accompanied by an Extension and
the signing bonus would otherwise be permitted under the rules governing the inclusion of signing bonuses in
Extensions.
In no event may a Team with a Team Salary at or above the Salary Cap renegotiate a Player Contract.
In no event may a Team and a player renegotiate a Player Contract from March 1 through June 30 of any
Salary Cap Year.

Other
In no event shall a Team and player negotiate a decrease in Salary or in any Incentive Compensation for any

A Player Contract that is extended may be renegotiated simultaneously. If a Player Contract is extended and
renegotiated simultaneously, then the amount of the player’s Salary, excluding Incentive Compensation, in the
first Salary Cap Year covered by the extended term may decrease by no more than forty percent (40%) of the

that the last Salary Cap Year covered by the original term provides for Incentive Compensation and such
Incentive Compensation is also renegotiated, the amount of Likely Bonuses and Unlikely Bonuses in the first
Salary Cap Year covered by the extended term may decrease by up to forty percent (40%) of the player’s

title: Q76: What are the procedures a team follows when a trade is agreed upon?
content:
The league office is available to take trades over the weekend and on holidays. Trades submitted to the league
office over the weekend or on holidays will be conducted as soon as practicable, consistent with the need to
ensure the accurate processing of trades in compliance with all applicable rules. Given the complexity and
significance of many trades teams conduct and the range of issues that can surface in connection with the
league office’s review of such trades, teams wishing to ensure the ability to complete a trade on a weekend or
holiday are encouraged to continue to provide the league office with notice of the trade in advance of the
impending weekend or holiday.
No player may be traded during a game (NBA or G League) for which the player is dressed to play. In addition,
when scheduling a trade call with the league office, any NBA team trading a player who has been assigned to
the G League must advise the league office of such a G League assignment.
No trade shall be effective until all terms and conditions of the trade are disclosed and agreed to during a
conference call with the league office.
Required Health and Insurance-Related Information
Prior to a trade call, teams that are parties to a trade are required to exchange by email (with a copy to the
league office) the health disclosures required. If information concerning the cardiovascular health (including as
reflected in any echocardiogram report available in the league wide EMR) of the player whose contract or draft
rights are being assigned is required to be disclosed pursuant to Section 4.03 of the By-Laws, the team must
make the disclosure required under Section 4.03 notwithstanding that there is no separate disclosure
requirement for all echocardiograms in respect of a player who is traded. Moreover, it is important for player
health purposes that teams carefully review, for each player whose contract or draft rights the team acquires,
the echocardiogram reports available in the EMR and continue to upload echocardiograms to the EMR in
accordance with the annual memo regarding EMR recording and uploading.
With respect to trades involving a player’s draft rights, unless waived by the assignee team with respect to a
particular player, the obligation to disclose relevant health information on the trade call contained in Section
4.03 of the By-Laws applies not only to players whose contracts are being traded, but also to players whose
draft rights are being traded.
To facilitate the efficient trading of a player’s draft rights while still ensuring that assignee teams receive all
required health information, a team trading a player’s draft rights is not responsible for providing to the
assignee team any information that is available to all teams through a current or former Draft Combine “team”
98
section of the EMR. Instead, disclosure of such information by the assignor team to the assignee team is
deemed to have occurred by virtue of the availability of such information to all teams through the EMR.
However, if the assignor team has any relevant health information that is not available to all teams through the
Draft Combine section of the EMR (e.g., by virtue of information collected at a team’s pre-Draft workout), then
the assignor team must disclose such information to the assignee team (unless such disclosure is waived by
the assignee team) in accordance with usual procedures. As always, teams also are prohibited under the
By-Laws from failing to disclose any other material information (or make any other material misrepresentation)
during the trade call.
The above-described rule regarding information contained in the Draft Combine section of the EMR applies
only to the trading of a player’s draft rights. In any trade of a player who is under contract to an NBA team, the
assignor team remains responsible for disclosing all required information (including but not limited to all
relevant information with respect to the player in the EMR).
One or more teams may waive the right to receive health disclosures on one or more players (e.g., during and
shortly following the Draft, teams typically waive their rights to receive health disclosures in respect of players
from that Draft whose draft rights the team is acquiring).
In addition to the disclosure of health-related information, prior to a trade call teams that are parties to a trade
are also required to exchange by email (with a copy to the league office) certain insurance-related information.
This information includes: (i) whether the player is enrolled in the League Wide TTD insurance program, and, if
so, whether the coverage of the player is subject to any special medical exclusions, and information regarding
any life, disability, or other insurance coverage that the team has purchased with regard to its players outside
of the League Wide TTD insurance program or the League Wide accidental death and dismemberment
insurance program.
NOTE: If an assignor team has purchased any life, disability, or other insurance coverage with regard to the
player outside of the league wide TTD insurance program and the league wide accidental death and
dismemberment insurance program, the assignee team may elect to have one or more of such insurance
policies assigned to it. If the assignee team so elects and notifies the assignor team in writing with a copy to
the league office within 30 days of the date of the trade call, the assignor team shall assign to the assignee
team the requested policies (if assignable). If any of such policies are assigned to the assignee team, the
assignee team shall reimburse the assignor team for the pro-rata portion of any premiums paid by the assignor
team relating to the period following the trade and before the assignment of the policies. If proceeds from any
requested policy become payable to the assignor team prior to the assignee team’s election to receive the
coverage and/or prior to the assignment of the coverage to the assignee team, then the assignor team shall
pay the proceeds to the assignee team.
A trade call will not be scheduled until all necessary disclosures have been reduced to writing and exchanged
by the parties with a copy to the league office. In addition, if a trade requires the consent of a player whose
contract is being traded, then the trade call will not be scheduled until the league office has received the
player’s signed written consent.
99
NOTE: The league office will periodically review the rules governing the disclosure of health and insurance
information for trade calls in order to ensure disclosure of such information as required by the By-Laws,
increase efficiency in the trade process, and promote secure management of player health information.
During the Conference Call
Participants will include a representative of each of the teams making the transaction and a representative of
the NBA Legal Department.
The parties will recite the terms of the transaction to which they had previously agreed.
If a player contract is involved, the NBA representative will review with the parties limited contract information
and then confirm that each team has reviewed in full all exhibits of and amendments to (and is aware of the
salary cap-related information available in PCMS related to) the contract(s) it is acquiring. If a team has any
questions or would like clarification regarding the terms of any contract being assigned, the team may ask
questions or seek clarification prior to or during the trade call. Any contract terms that are subject to specific
points of agreement between the parties (for example, the details of a player’s deferred compensation payment
schedule in circumstances where the teams must agree on the timing of the particular payments that each
team will make) will be discussed on the call.
Each assignor team will be responsible for confirming on the trade call that there are no terms of the
contract(s) of the player(s) it is assigning other than those set forth in the contract(s) as shown in PCMS or
reviewed on the trade call. In accordance with Section 4.04 of the By-Laws, should any such contract terms
exist and not be disclosed by the assignor team on the trade call they will remain the obligation of the assignor
team.
If a player contract is assigned during the Regular Season, the salary of the player so assigned (including
related payroll taxes) shall be apportioned on a per diem basis utilizing the entire number of days in the
Regular Season, without regard to playoff games or exhibition games. The assignor team shall be responsible
for the portion of the salary through the day of the assignment, and the assignee team shall be responsible for
the salary after said date. If, however, the player dresses in a game for the assignee team on the date of the
assignment, then the assignee team shall be responsible for the salary on that date. The foregoing may be
modified by agreement of the parties, however, any such agreement with respect to salary reimbursement will
be included when determining whether the teams participating in the trade are compliant with the cash
transfers rule (as discussed in Paragraph E.1.a above).
NOTE: Unless altered by agreement of the parties on the trade call, any “adjusting payments” necessary to
have each team meet its obligation to pay the salary of the player(s) it is trading through the date of the trade
as set forth in Section 4.04(a) of the By-Laws will be due within 30 days of the date of the trade call.
In order to facilitate efficient processing of trades and consistent treatment of life insurance reimbursement
obligations, if a team assigns a player contract containing a life insurance reimbursement provision, then any
required reimbursement pursuant to the player’s contract will be the responsibility of the assignor or assignee
team, in accordance with the following:
100
The assignor team shall be responsible for reimbursing the player if at the time of the trade call:
In accordance with the player’s contract, the player has provided to the assignor team evidence that he paid
the premiums for which reimbursement is sought; or
The assignor team has already reimbursed the player for the premiums for term life insurance for that season.
The assignee team shall be responsible for reimbursing the player if at the time of the trade call the player has
not yet been reimbursed or submitted evidence that he paid the premiums for which reimbursement is sought.
For trades that are conditional upon one or more of the assigned players each reporting to his new team and
successfully passing a physical, the teams will agree on the trade call on the date and time by which the
assignee team must notify the league office and the other team(s) that each of the specified players has
reported and passed a physical.
NOTE: If a player fails to report and submit to a physical by the date and time agreed upon by the teams on
the trade call and, as a result, the player’s new team desires to rescind the trade, the new team must so notify
the league office and the other team(s) within 15 minutes after the date and time by which the player was
required to report. Failure to provide such notice shall be deemed to constitute a waiver of the requirement that
the player report and submit to a physical.
If a player reports and submits to a physical but then does not pass the physical and, as a result of the player
failing his physical, the new team desires to rescind the trade, the new team must so notify the league office
and the other team(s) by the date and time agreed upon by the teams on the call. Failure to provide such
notice shall be deemed to constitute a waiver of the separate requirement that the player pass the physical
administered by the new team.
Teams are not required to read on the trade call the health disclosures that they are making in connection with
the trade. In order to meet its disclosure obligation under Section 4.03 of the By-Laws in respect of each player
whose contract (or draft rights) it is assigning, each team will be required to represent on the trade call that the
health disclosures exchanged prior to the call satisfy the disclosure requirements of Section 4.03 of the
By-Laws. With respect to any player whose contract (or draft rights) the assignee team is acquiring, the team
may request, or the league office may in some cases require, that the assignor team read on the trade call the
applicable health disclosures.
The NBA representative will ask appropriate questions designed to identify team responsibilities and
understandings.
Immediately following the trade call, one team involved in the trade is required to send an email to the league
office (the “confirming email”) outlining the terms of the trade and copying the other team(s) involved in the
trade. The other team(s) are then required to reply to the confirming email, again copying the league office and
the other team(s), to confirm whether the terms of the trade reflected in the confirming email are those to which
the teams agreed on the call. The teams will agree on the call which team will send the confirming email.
Promptly following the conference call, the league office will send an email to the teams setting forth the
conditions that must be satisfied in order for the trade to be consummated (e.g., passing of physical exams and
101
submission of required trade certifications). When all conditions have been satisfied, the league office will send
an email to the teams advising them.
NOTE: No player involved in the trade may play in any game or practice or engage in any conditioning or other
physical activity with his new team (or any G League team) until the teams have received the email from the
league office advising them that all conditions of the trade have been satisfied. In addition, no transaction
involving any player in the trade may be made (e.g., placing a player in the trade on waivers or recalling such a
player from a G League assignment) until the teams have received the email from the league office advising
them that all conditions of the trade have been satisfied.
A memorandum to the file will be prepared by the league office representative on the call, which will set forth all
terms and conditions of the transaction. This memorandum, with related attachments, will be provided to all
parties, and a copy of the player contract(s) will be provided to the assignee team or teams.
Section 4.03 of the By-Laws provides that no team shall misrepresent or fail to disclose during a trade call any
relevant information in its possession, custody, or control concerning the health of a player whose contract or
draft rights the team is assigning. For purposes of the foregoing sentence, “relevant information” shall include
“any information concerning current or prior injuries, illnesses, or other health conditions that could affect the
player’s ability to play skilled basketball at any point during the player’s career.” Teams must take care to select
and organize the health information being disclosed to ensure that the information is sufficiently detailed to
meet the standard set forth in Section 4.03 of the By-Laws, but not so detailed – for example, disclosures
including extensive language copied verbatim or without regard to materiality from MRI reports, surgical notes,
or other medical documents from the EMR – as to undermine the rule’s purpose of bringing relevant
information pertaining to a player’s health to the attention of the assignee team. The league office will require a
team to revise disclosures that include extensive language that is not consistent with the above-described
standards.
As a reminder, there is a trade disclosure tool within the EMR that allows team EMR users to generate a trade
disclosure form for a player by pulling from the health-related records for the player maintained in the EMR and
supplementing those records with additional information, if any, that the team plans to disclose to comply with
its trade disclosure obligation. Teams may, but are not required, to use the EMR tool to document its trade
disclosures.
No team shall make any material misrepresentation or fail to disclose any material information during the trade
call.
If any team is found, after a hearing before the Commissioner, to have violated Paragraphs E.2.i or j above, the
team shall be subject to penalty. Such penalty shall be within the absolute and sole discretion of the
Commissioner and may include a fine (not to exceed $1,000,000), suspension of the offending employee,
rescission of the trade, and/or forfeiture or transfer of the offending team’s draft choices.
If a player contract is involved, unless the parties agree otherwise, the assignor team will be required to
complete the player assignment form for signature of the assignee-team. (If contracts are being traded by the
teams to one another, the NBA representative on the conference call will ask which team will initiate the form.)
The assignment form, containing all signatures, must then be forwarded to the NBA Legal Department within
102
10 days after the conference call for approval by the Commissioner. Accordingly, the team responsible for the
preparation of the form must send it to the assignee-team(s) for signature immediately following the
satisfaction of all conditions to the trade.
In any dispute relating to the transaction, the memorandum to the file prepared by the league office will be
determinative.

title: Q78: Does a team help with moving expenses when a trade happens?
content:
A Team's Obligation To reimburse player for “reasonable” expenses related to the assignment of a Player
Contract from one Team to another (in accordance with Paragraph 10 of a Uniform Player Contract) shall
extend to the reimbursement of the actual expenses incurred by such player in moving to the home territory of
his new Team, provided that such expenses result directly from the assignment and are ordinary and
reasonable, and provided further that, prior to his actually incurring such expenses, the player (i) consults with
the Team to which his Contract has been assigned in advance concerning his move, and (ii) furnishes the
Team with a written estimate of such proposed expenses from an established moving company so as to afford
such assignee Team an opportunity to make reasonably comparable alternative arrangements for the move of
the player. The player shall furnish such written estimate to the Team within a reasonable time following the
notice of the assignment of the Player Contract.
Upon receipt of such an estimate from the player, the Team shall, within ten (10) days, either agree to
reimburse the player for the expenses set forth in such estimate or make alternative arrangements (at the
Team’s expense) for the move of the player. “Reasonable” moving expenses shall include the cost of moving
104
not more than one (1) automobile for the player (and not more than two (2) automobiles if the player is
married).
Hotel Accommodations
A player whose Contract is assigned from one Team to another shall be reimbursed by the assignee Team for
the cost of a hotel room in a hotel (comparable to that in which such Team’s players are lodged while “on the
road”) in the assignee Team’s home city for up to forty-six (46) days following the assignment.
Housing Costs Reimbursement
A player whose Contract is assigned from one Team to another shall be reimbursed by the assignee Team for
the cost of his living quarters (either rent or mortgage expense) in the city from which he is assigned, for a
period of three months after the date of the assignment; provided, however, that such payment shall: (i) be
made only if and to the extent that the player is legally obligated for such costs; and (ii) not exceed $6,000 per
month. Any such payments shall be made on a pro rata basis if a full month is not involved.

title: Q79: How is cash handled in a trade?
content:
Cash paid or received in trades occurring during a Salary Cap Year (including cash received as a salary
reimbursement) is limited to an aggregate of $7,964,000 per team for the 2025-26 Salary Cap Year.
Teams over the second apron are not allowed to send cash in a trade.
The maximum annual cash limit in trades increases or decreases annually at the same rate as the Salary Cap.
Cash received by a team in one or more trades will not be netted against cash paid in the same or other
trades, and vice versa, for purposes of applying this rule.

title: Q80: Who is responsible for player incentives in a trade?
content:
In the event a player contract contains a “Performance Bonus and such Performance Bonus is earned by the
player in a Salary Cap Year, the bonus will be the responsibility of the final team that employed the player
under such player contract during the applicable Regular Season (i.e., the Regular Season encompassed by
the Salary Cap Year in which the Performance Bonus was earned).
At the time of a trade, the parties may agree on a different allocation of financial responsibility for payment of
any Performance Bonus earned during the then-current Salary Cap Year; however, if they do so, the portion of
105
the performance bonus agreed to be paid or reimbursed by the team other than the team considered
responsible for such bonus (as described above) will be treated as a cash transfer for purposes of the cash
transfers rule.
