title: Q82: What is the Traded Player Exception?
content:
A Team may use the “Expanded Traded Player Exception” to replace one (1) or more Traded Players with one
(1) or more Replacement Players whose Player Contracts are acquired simultaneously and whose post-trade
Salaries for the then-current Salary Cap Year, in the aggregate, are no more than an amount equal to the
greater of:
$0-$8.27M
107
The lesser of: (A) two hundred percent (200%) of the aggregated pre-trade Salaries of the Traded Player(s),
plus $250,000
Example: The Clippers acquired Marjon Beauchamp ($2.7M) with the Expanded Traded Player Exception
(200%+$250K) created by the trade of Kevin Porter ($2.2M).
$8.27-$33.1
One hundred percent (100%) of the aggregated pre-trade Salaries of the Traded Player(s), plus an amount
equal to $8.5 million multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which is the Salary Cap for the then-current
Salary Cap Year and the denominator of which is the Salary Cap for the 2025-26 Salary Cap Year.
Recent trade: Miami acquired Norman Powell ($20.5M) with the Expanded Traded Player Exception of Kevin
Love ($4.1M) and Kyle Anderson ($9.2M)
$33.1M+
One hundred twenty-five percent (125%) of the aggregated pre-trade Salaries of the Traded Player(s), plus
$250,000.
Example: Houston acquired Clint Capela ($6.7M) and Kevin Durant ($54.7M) with the Expanded Traded
Player Exception (125%+$250K) created by the trade of Dillon Brooks ($21.2M) and Jalen Green ($33.5M)
Aggregated Standard Traded Player Exception
A Team may use the “Aggregated Standard Traded Player Exception” to replace two (2) or more Traded
Players with one (1) or more Replacement Players whose Player Contracts are acquired simultaneously and
whose post-trade Salaries for the then-current Salary Cap Year, in the aggregate, are no more than an amount
equal to one hundred percent (100%) of the aggregated pre-trade Salaries of the Traded Players, plus
$250,000.
If a Team’s post-assignment Apron Team Salary would exceed the First Apron Level, then the $250,000
allowance above shall be reduced to $0.
Recent Trade: Toronto acquired Brandon Ingram ($36M) with the Aggregated Standard Traded Player
Exception created by the trade of Bruce Brown ($23M) and Kelly Olynyk ($12.8M).
108
Standard Traded Player Exception
A Team may use the “Standard Traded Player Exception” to replace one (1) Traded Player with one (1) or
more Replacement Players whose Player Contracts are acquired simultaneously or non-simultaneously and
whose post-assignment Salaries for the Salary Cap Year in which the Replacement Player(s) are acquired, in
the aggregate, are no more than an amount equal to one hundred percent (100%) of the pre-trade Salary of
the Traded Player, plus $250,000, provided that any Player Contract acquired non-simultaneously pursuant to
this Exception must be acquired within one (1) year following the date on which the Traded Player was traded.
Example: Team A trades a player earning $12M to Team B for a player with a salary of $6.8M.
Recent trade: Denver acquired Cam Johnson with the Standard Traded Player Exception created by Michael
Porter Jr. They now have a $17.3M trade exception available.

title: Q83: What are the rules for teams that have cap space in a trade?
content:
A Team with a Team Salary below the Salary Cap may acquire one (1) or more players by assignment whose
post-assignment Salaries, in the aggregate, are no more than an amount equal to the Team’s room under the
Salary Cap plus $250,000.

title: Q84: If a team has a signing exception, can they use that to acquire a player in a trade?
content:
Beginning with the 2024-25 Salary Cap Year, teams will be permitted to use the Non-Taxpayer Mid-Level
Salary Exception, Mid-Level Salary Exception for Room Teams, or Bi- annual Exception to acquire one or more
players by trade or waiver claim (provided that the remaining term of the acquired Contract is less than or
equal to the maximum term of the applicable Exception).
For clarity, teams would not be permitted to aggregate such Exceptions with each other or with any other
Exception.

Lakers’ own); and (2) $3,500,000.
● Miami sent to Utah: (1) Josh Richardson; (2) a 2031 second round draft pick (the
more favorable of Indiana’s own and Miami’s own); and (3) $563,655.
● Toronto sent Miami Davion Mitchell.
● Utah sent Toronto PJ Tucker.
Trade Rules
● Detroit acquired Schroder with cap space and Waters with the veteran minimum exception.
● Golden State acquired Butler ($48.8M) with the Expanded Traded Player Exception (125%) created by
the trade of Schroder ($13M) and Wiggins ($26.3M). Golden State has an $8,780,488 Standard Traded
Player Exception (Kyle Andrson) and $2,196,970 Standard Traded Player Exception (Waters).
● Miami acquired Anderson ($8.8M) with the Non-Taxpayer Mid-Level Salary Exception ($12.8M) and
Mitchell ($6.5M) and Wiggins ($26.3M) with the Standard Traded Player Exception created by the trade
of Butler ($48.8M). Miami has a $16,070,814 Standard Traded Player Exception (Butler) and
$3,051,153 Standard Traded Player Exception (Richardson).
114
● Toronto acquired Tucker with the Expanded Traded Player Exception ($7.7M) created by the trade of
Mitchell ($11.5M).
● Utah acquired Martin with the Standard Traded Player Exception created by the trade of Tucker
($11.5M) and Richardson ($3M) with the Minimum Player Salary Exception. Utah has a $3,564,000
Standard Traded Player Exception (Tucker).
Other Notes:
● As part of the trade, Butler signed a two-year $111 million extension. His 2025-26 player was declined
and replaced with a new salary starting at 35% of the cap (the maximum allowed). The second year of
the extension is a 105% increase off 2025-26.
● Butler had a 15% trade bonus on his contract. However, because a trade bonus added to salary cannot
exceed the maximum salary allowed, the bonus was reduced to $417K. Butler elected to waive the
bonus.

title: Q87: When can players selected in the draft be traded after they sign a contract?
content:
Drafted Rookie: No player drafted who signs a Standard NBA Contract or player who signs a Two-Way
Contract may be traded before thirty (30) days following the date on which the Contract is signed.
Example: Ace Bailey signed a contract for the first-round pick exception on July 2. The first day he can be
traded is August 1.
Two-Way: A player that signs a Two-Way can be traded 30-days after the contract has been signed.
Example: Tamari Bates signed a Two-Way contract on July 2. The first day he can be traded is August 1.

title: Q88: What is the first date free agents signed in the offseason can be traded?
content:
December 15: A free agent that signs a contract on or before September 15.
Example: Tyus Jones signed a one-year $7 million contract with Orlando. The first day he can be traded is
December 15.
115
Three months: A free agent that signs a contract after September 15.
Example: John Smith signs a free agent contract on September 27. The first day he can be traded is
December 27.
January 15: A free agent that signs a contract with his own team for more than 20% from his previous contract
and is an early or bird free agent.
Example: Naz Reid signed a five-year $125 million contract with Minnesota. Because Reid had bird rights and
the contract is 20% from his previous contract, he cannot be traded until January 15.

title: Q89: If a player signs an extension, can he be traded immediately?
content:
A player that signs an extension for more than four seasons (including what is left on the contract) or the first
year of the extension is more than a 120% increase in the first year of the extension cannot be traded for six
months. A player also has a six-month restriction if the salary increases or decreases more than 5% over the
contract..
Example: Steven Adams signed a three-year $39 million extension on June 14. The first date that Brunson
can be traded is December 14.

title: Q90: Can a player have a no trade clause if they re-sign with their own team for one season?
content:
A free agent that signs a one-year contract with his prior team and has early or bird rights the following season.
The player has veto power on any trade. If the player approves the trade, he loses early or bird rights with the
new team. A player is allowed to waive the one-year bird restriction at the time of signing.
Example: Kyle Lowry signed a one-year contract with Philadelphia. Lowry has the right to veto any trade. His
early bird rights do not carry to his new team.

title: Q91: If a player is traded, can he be moved again in another deal?
content:
For a period of two months, a player acquired in a trade (not with cap space) cannot be aggregated with
another contract. A player that is traded on or before December 15, can be traded on the Feb. 6 trade
deadline.or
116
Example: Desmond Bane was traded from Memphis to Orlando on June 15. The first date the contract can be
aggregated with another salary is August 15. Bane can be traded but not with another salary.

title: Q92: If a player is traded and then waived, can he re-sign with his former team?
content:
If a Team trades a player and the assignee Team subsequently places the player on waivers, the assignor
Team shall not be permitted to sign the player to a new Contract (or claim the player off of waivers) before the
earlier of: (i) one (1) year following the date all conditions to the trade were satisfied; or (ii) the July 1 following
the last Season of the player’s Player Contract.
Example: Marcus Smart is bought out of his contract in Memphis. He would not be allowed to sign a new
contract in Boston.
There is the “Andrew Bogut rule” when a player can be traded to a third team, then waived, and eligible to sign
with his original team.
Example: Chris Paul is traded from Phoenix to Washington. He was traded again from Washington to Golden
State and waived during the regular season. He would be allowed to sign with the Suns.

title: Q93: What is a no trade clause?
content:
A Player Contract entered into by a player who has eight (8) or more Years of Service in the NBA and who has
rendered four (4) or more Years of Service for the Team entering into such Contract may contain a prohibition
or limitation of such Team's right to trade such Contract to another NBA Team.
A no trade clause cannot be included in an extension.
The No Trade Clause carries with a player if he is traded.
LeBron James was allowed to have a No Trade Clause in his contract during his second stint in Cleveland. The
NBA credits a player with years of service with his team even if he changed teams between contracts. The
same situation occurred with Damian Lillard when he re-signed in Portland. Because Lillard accrued the years
of service with the Trail Blazers, he was allowed to negotiate a no trade clause despite playing in Milwaukee
last season.
Example: Bradley Beal became the 10th player in NBA history to have a no trade clause included in his
contract. Beal still had the no trade clause despite his trade from Washington to Phoenix. James has a no
trade clause in the contract he signed with the Lakers in 2024.
117
Note: Beal was waived from Phoenix, and the no trade clause no longer exists.

title: Q94: If a team matches an offer sheet, when can that player be traded?
content:
A free agent who signed an offer sheet that was eventually matched cannot be traded without the player’s
approval. The player during the season is not allowed to be traded to the team he signed the offer sheet with.
Example: Deandre Ayton signed an offer sheet with Indiana in 2022. The contract was eventually matched by
Phoenix. For a period of one-year, Ayton could not be traded to the Pacers and also had the right to veto any
other trade.

title: Q95: What are the rules if a player signs a rookie extension?
content:
A player that signs a rookie extension. For trade purposes, his current salary is used as outgoing salary. The
average of the fourth year of his current contract and new extension count as incoming salary for the acquiring
team.
Example: For trade purposes $12.35 million (the 4th year) for Jabari Smith Jr. counts as outgoing salary in a
trade. The Smith Jr. contract counts as $22.39 million (the average of the last year and extension) as incoming
salary for a new team.

title: Q96: When can a player be traded if he is claimed off waivers?
content:
A team that has acquired the rights and title to the contract of a player through the waiver procedure may
waive such rights at any time, but may not sell or trade such rights for a period of 30 days after the acquisition
thereof; provided, however, that if the rights to such player were acquired between seasons, the 30-day period
described above shall begin on the first day of the next succeeding season.
Example: Jordan Goodwin was waived by the Lakers and claimed by Phoenix. He cannot be traded until
Nov. 20, 30-days after the regular season begins.
118

title: Q97: How does Base Year Compensation affect a trade?
content:
A Qualifying Veteran Free Agent or Early Qualifying Veteran Free Agent and his prior Team enter into a Player
Contract, in connection with an agreement to trade the Contract immediately following such Contract signing is
above the Salary Cap, and
The new Contract to be traded provides for Salary and Unlikely Bonuses for the first Season of such Contract
in excess of the Salary and Unlikely Bonuses that could have been provided for by the Contract had the player
been a Non-Qualifying Veteran Free Agent and;
Then for purposes of calculating the assignor Team’s Traded Player Exception, the player’s Salary shall be
deemed equal to the greater of the Salary for the last Season of his preceding Contract, or
Fifty percent (50%) of the Salary for the first Season of his new Contract.
Example: The Miami Heat signed-and-traded the contract of Max Strus to Cleveland. For purposes of the
trade, $7.2 million (50% of the current salary) was used as outgoing salary from the Heat.
Player A had a $7.9 million salary in 2024-25. He signed a three-year $66 million contract with a salary of $22
million in year 1. As part of the signing, he is traded to Team A. For trade purposes, $11 million is used as
outgoing salary.

title: Q98: Are teams allowed to stack minimum contracts in a trade?
content:
Other than during the period from December 15 through the trade deadline each Season, if:
A team is aggregating the Salaries of two or more Contracts for the purpose of acquiring in a simultaneous
trade one or more Replacement Players, and
The number of Contracts being aggregated exceeds the number of Replacement Players, then no more than
one “Minimum Contract” may be among the Contracts that the team is aggregating. For the purposes of this
rule, a “Minimum Contract” is a Contract that provides for a player’s Minimum Player Salary in the Salary Cap
Year in which the trade occurs or, if the trade occurs after the last day of the Regular Season of a Salary Cap
Year, in the Salary Cap Year immediately following such Salary Cap Year.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, a team will not be prohibited from aggregating two Minimum Contracts when
such Contracts are the only Contracts being aggregated by the team.
119

title: Q99: When can a player that renegotiates and then extends his contract be traded?
content:
There will be a six-month waiting period (a) between the time a player’s Contract is renegotiated and when it
may be traded and (b) between the time a player’s Contract is traded and when it may be renegotiated.
Example: Under the prior CBA, the Pacers Myles Turner was eligible to be traded despite having his contract
renegotiated and extended. The reason was that the increase in year one of the extension did not exceed
105%. The new rule closes this loophole.

title: Q100: What are the rules regarding trading draft picks? What is the Stepien rule?
content:
Seven-year rule
●   A team is allowed to trade a first or second round pick up to seven drafts.
●   The seven-year rule takes into account the 2026 to 2032 Draft (AFTER THE 2025 DRAFT)
●   A draft pick cannot be conveyed after the seventh draft.
○    Example: Team A will send Team B a 2032 top-14 protected first. The first will not convey if it
falls in the top 14.
Election to defer
One-Time Election to Defer. Subject to the 7- Year Rule, the parties to a trade may agree that one or both
teams involved in the trade will be permitted to exercise a one-time option to defer the conveyance or receipt of
a pick for one year only.
120
For example, the following trade is permissible, even though it does not specify the precise year in which the
pick will be conveyed:
Team A conveys to Team B the least favorable of the 2023 second round picks that Team A currently
possesses; provided, however, that Team A and Team B shall each have the option to defer the conveyance
for one year.
If Team A and/or Team B elect to defer the conveyance for one year, then Team A will convey its own 2024
second round pick to Team B.”
Example
As part of the Anthony Davis trade, New Orleans had the right to defer the 2024 Lakers first to 2025. The first
was deferred and eventually sent to Atlanta as part of the Dejounte Murray trade.
Later acquired trades
It is not permissible for teams to trade future first round or second round picks that the team might acquire in
subsequent trade transactions. Thus, the following type of trade is not permissible:
“Team A conveys to Team B one 2025 second round pick from among any that Team A currently possesses or
subsequently acquires in future transactions.”
Protection based on draft position
Subject to the 7-Year Rule and all other applicable rules (including rules relating to required minimum
consideration in trades), a team is permitted to convey a future draft pick that is “protected” based on the
team’s selection number in the Draft.
For example, the following trade is permissible, even though it does not specify the precise year in which the
pick will be conveyed:
“Team A conveys its own first round draft pick to Team B in the first Draft in which such pick is not among the
top 14 picks in the Draft; provided, however, that if Team B does not receive a first round draft pick pursuant to
the foregoing in any of the Drafts from 2023 through 2029, then Team B will instead receive Team A’s own
2029 second round draft pick.”
In addition, subject to all other applicable trade rules, it is permissible for a team to protect a draft pick that it
acquired from another team in a prior trade and convey such draft pick in a subsequent trade, provided that: (i)
the team protecting the draft pick in such subsequent trade holds the rights to such pick unconditionally; or (ii)
the team protecting the draft pick in a subsequent trade previously held the rights to such pick unconditionally,
121
but then entered into another trade pursuant to which the team may be obligated, subject to protection, to
convey the draft pick to another team.
The following are examples of permissible trades involving a team protecting a draft pick it acquired from
another team:
Assume that, pursuant to the terms of a prior trade, Team A has acquired Team B’s 2024 second round pick
unconditionally: “Team A conveys a 2024 second round draft pick (Team B’s own) to Team C provided that
such draft pick is not among picks 31-45 in the 2024 NBA Draft.”
Assume that the following trade occurs after the trade described immediately above (with no intervening
transactions related to Team B’s own 2023 second round draft pick): “Team A conveys a 2024 second round
draft pick (Team B’s own) to Team D, provided that such draft pick is not among picks 46-60 in the 2024 NBA
Draft.”
Note that a team may also provide for alternative consideration in the event that a traded draft pick is not
conveyed due to protection; provided, however, that the year in which the alternative consideration would be
conveyed is specified. For example, assume that, as a result of a prior trade, Team A holds the rights to Team
B’s 2024 first round draft pick unconditionally: “Team A conveys a 2024 first round draft pick (Team B’s own) to
Team C, provided that such pick is not among the top 14 picks in the 2024 NBA Draft. If Team A does not
convey the 2024 first round draft pick (Team B’s own) to Team C pursuant to the foregoing, then Team A shall
instead convey to Team C the following two second round draft picks: (i) Team A’s own 2024 second round
draft pick, and (ii) Team A’s own 2025 second round draft pick.”
Stepien rule
●   No team may trade a future first round pick if the result may be to leave the team without first round
picks in any two consecutive future years.
● This is permissible: From a prior trade, Team A does not have a 2026 first and are not allowed to trade
a 2027 first. However, they now acquire an unprotected 2026 first in a trade. Because the pick is
unprotected, Team A is now allowed to trade a 2027 first.
●   If Team A does not have a 2026 first round pick and only one 2027 first round pick (its own), then Team
A is prohibited from trading its 2027 first round pick prior to the date of the 2026 Draft.
Golden State Warriors example
2026: Own
122
2027: Own
2028: Own
2029: Own
2030: Own if 1-20 or to Washington if 21-30
2031: Own
2032: Own
Golden State traded their 2025 first to Miami. Starting on the night of the draft, the maximum firsts Golden St.
can trade is FOUR: 2026/2028/2030 (if 1-20)/2032.

title: Q101: What is the process when a team elects to waive a player?
content:
A team desiring to secure waivers on a player shall notify by email the Executive Vice President, Basketball
Operations at the NBA, who, on behalf of such team, shall notify all other teams by email of the waiver request.
Waiver requests are circulated by the league office at 5:00 p.m. (ET) throughout the year (including Saturdays,
Sundays and legal holidays). At the conclusion of the waiver period, the Executive Vice President, Basketball
Operations will notify all teams by email regarding the disposition of the player. Once a team has notified the
Executive Vice President, Basketball Operations to attempt to secure waivers on a player, such notice may not
be withdrawn.
If a team desires to secure waivers with respect to a player who is in the last year of his contract (or who may
potentially be in the last year depending on whether an option is exercised), the team’s waiver request must be
received by the league office sufficiently in advance of the end of the Regular Season (i.e., no later than 5:00
p.m. (ET) two days prior to the date of the last game of such Regular Season for all teams) such that the
48-hour waiver period will expire prior to the last game of the Regular Season for all teams.

title: Q102: Can a team claim a player that is waived?
content:
In the event that more than one team claims rights to a player placed on waivers, the claiming team with the
lowest winning percentage at the time the waiver was requested shall be entitled to acquire the rights to such
player.
If the request for waiver occurs between seasons or prior to midnight on November 30, the teams’ winning
percentages at the close of the previous season shall govern.
If tied based on the above, then waiver priority shall be given, if possible, to the team with the worst winning
percentage in Regular Season games played among the tied teams during the current season or during the
preceding season, as the case may be. If still tied, a coin toss shall determine waiver priority. For the purpose
of determining standings, both conferences shall be deemed merged and a consolidated standing shall control.
123
The waiver price shall be $1,000 per player awarded on waivers, payable by the assignee team to the league
office.
Outside of a player signed to the veteran minimum exception, a claiming team must have cap space or a trade
exception to claim a player.

title: Q103: What happens if a player clears waivers?
content: If a player is not claimed and clears waivers, he will then become an unrestricted free agent.

title: Q104: What is the waiver process for a player bought out of their contract?
content:
When a buyout takes place, the team and player agree to amend and then reduce the amount of guaranteed
salary owed.
The player is then placed through the standard waiver process.
Example
The Pistons Blake Griffin agreed to reduce the Base Compensation Protection in his contract by $13.3 million.
His cap hit in 2020-21 was reduced from $36.6 million to $32.45 million and then in 2021-22 $38.95 million to
$29.76 million.
As part of the buyout, the Pistons eliminated the set-off provision, allowing Griffing to recoup the lost earnings.
He would eventually sign three contracts totaling $4.2 million.
The Magic and Patrick Beverley agreed to a contract buyout on February 12.
However, the amount of the buyout was contingent on the next Beverley contract.
He would eventually sign a one-year $801,614 contract in Chicago and that amount was reduced in the salary
owed by the Magic.
124

title: Q105: What is the 65-game rule and how does that impact league recognized honors?
content:
To be eligible for MVP, an All-NBA Team, Defensive Player of the Year, an All-Defensive Team, or Most
Improved Player honors, a player must satisfy at least one of the following two criteria:
No player shall be eligible for NBA Most Valuable Player, NBA Defensive Player of the Year, NBA Most
Improved Player, All-NBA Team (First, Second, or Third), or NBA All-Defensive Team (First or Second) honors
(the “Applicable Generally Recognized League Honors”) for a Season unless the player has satisfied at least
one of the following criteria (the “Award Eligibility Criteria”) in respect of such Season: (1) the player played in
at least sixty-five (65) Regular Season games; or (2) the player (A) played in at least sixty-two (62) Regular
Season games,(B) suffered a “season-ending injury” (as defined below), and (C) played in at least eighty-five
percent (85%) of the Regular Season games played by his Team prior to the player suffering such injury.
A player will be considered to have played in a Regular Season game for purposes of these rules if he played
at least 20 minutes of such game; provided that, in respect of no more than two Regular Season games per
season, he will be considered to have played in a Regular Season game for purposes of these rules if he
played at least 15 minutes and fewer than 20 minutes in such game.
Grievance Process
A player who fails to satisfy either of the criteria set may bring either an “Award Eligibility Grievance” or an
“Extraordinary Circumstances Challenge” (but not both an Award Eligibility Grievance and an Extraordinary
Circumstances Challenge).
Eligible Players
A player may bring an Award Eligibility Grievance in respect of a Season if winning one of the applicable
awards in such Season could or would impact whether such player is eligible to:
● Receive a Maximum Annual Salary in excess of 25% of the Salary Cap by satisfying the 5th Year 30%
Max Criteria.
● Enter into a Designated Veteran Player Contract.
● Enter into a Designated Veteran Player Extension.
● An Award Eligibility Grievance must be filed by a player within two days of the date on which it became
mathematically impossible for the player to play 65 Regular Season games in a Season, provided that
any such Grievance must be filed no later than 11:59 p.m. (ET) on the day following the last day of such
Regular Season.
● A hearing will be held by the System Arbitrator within two days of the date of the filing by the player and
a decision will be issued by the System Arbitrator on the day following the date of the hearing. The
125
player, the Players Association, the team, and the NBA shall be entitled to participate in the hearing,
which will be conducted by videoconference.
● The player will bear the burden of proving, by clear and convincing evidence, that the team willfully
limited the minutes or games played by the player with the intention of depriving the player of eligibility
for one or more of the awards. If the player satisfies the burden of proof and prevails at the hearing, the
sole remedy will be that he will be deemed eligible for such awards. For clarity, neither the foregoing
sentence nor anything else in the CBA will be construed to prohibit the NBA from imposing discipline on
a team whose player prevails at such a hearing for conduct prejudicial or detrimental to the best
interests of the NBA.
Extraordinary Circumstances Challenge
A player who fails to satisfy either of the criteria may nonetheless be deemed eligible for the awards listed in
that section if an independent expert (to be jointly selected by the NBA and Players Association) determines,
upon application by the player, that he should be deemed to have met the games played requirement because:
i. It was impracticable for the player to play in one or more of the game(s) that he missed due to
extraordinary circumstances.
ii. The player would have played in at least 65 Regular Season games if he had played in every game that
he missed due to the extraordinary circumstances.
iii. As a result of the extraordinary circumstances, and taking into account the totality of the circumstances
(including whether the player did not play in other Regular Season games in which he could have
played), it would be unjust to exclude the player from award eligibility.
Any application by a player under this provision must be made no earlier than 12:00 p.m. (ET) on the last day
of the Regular Season and no later than 11:59 p.m. (ET) on the day after the last day of the Regular Season.
The parties will discuss in good faith the establishment of procedures in connection with this provision.
Shortened Season
If a pandemic or other similar health or security situation frustrates the purpose of the award qualification
requirements rule (e.g., league operations are suspended and teams do not complete 82 Regular Season
games in a Season), then the criteria will be adjusted proportionally or the parties will work in good faith to
identify another reasonable alternative.
● Aggregate Regular Season Performance. Voters for MVP, All-NBA Teams, Defensive Player of the
Year, All-Defensive Teams, and Most Improved Player will be directed to consider a player’s aggregate
performance over the course of the Regular Season (taking into account the player’s total number of
games and minutes played) when making their selections.
Positionless Voting
All-NBA and All-Defensive Team voters will be directed to vote for the most deserving players each season
without regard to position (e.g., voting the top five such players to the All-NBA 1st Team, the next five to the
All-NBA 2nd Team, and the final five to the All-NBA 3rd Team).
126
Neither the IST Finals Game, Play-In Games, nor a Team’s or a player’s performance during any such games,
shall be considered for purposes of determining whether, as a result of his achievement of agreed-upon
benchmarks related to a player’s performance as a player or the Team’s performance during a particular
Season

title: Q106: How are incentives built into a contract?
content:
Unlikely bonuses
** Remember that unlikely bonuses count against the apron.
No Player Contract may provide for Unlikely Bonuses in any Salary Cap Year that exceed fifteen percent (15%)
of the player’s Regular Salary for such Salary Cap Year at the time the Contract is signed; provided, however,
that: (i) with respect to Extensions, if the amount of Unlikely Bonuses in the Salary Cap Year in which the
Extension is signed exceeds fifteen percent (15%) of the player’s Regular Salary for such Salary Cap Year, the
Extension may provide for up to the same percentage of Unlikely Bonuses in the first year of the extended
term; and (ii) no Renegotiation may provide for an increase in Unlikely Bonuses if, after the Renegotiation, the
amount of Unlikely Bonuses in respect of any Salary Cap Year covered by the renegotiated Contract exceeds
fifteen percent (15%) of the player’s Regular Salary for such Salary Cap Year.
Example
As part of his rookie extension, RJ Barrett has unlikely bonuses for the below years:
2023-24       $2,901,789
2024-25       $3,133,929
2025-26       $3,366,072
2026-27       $3,598,209
The bonuses are for All-NBA, All-Star participant and All-Defensive 1st or 2nd Team
The bonuses are considered unlikely and are not applied to his current salary.
If Barrett were to be named an All-Star in 2024-25, he would earn $1,044,643 and the bonus amount would be
then applied to taxable salary at the end of the 2023-24 season.
The $1,122,024 All-Star bonus in 2024-25 is now deemed likely and applied to his 2025-26 salary.
No Player Contract may provide for any Unlikely Bonus for the first Salary Cap Year covered by the Contract
that, if included in the player’s Salary for such Salary Cap Year, would result in the Team’s Team Salary
exceeding the Room under which it is signing the Contract. For the sole purpose of determining whether a
Team has Room for a new Unlikely Bonus, the Team’s Room shall be deemed reduced by all Unlikely Bonuses
127
in Contracts approved by the Commissioner that may be paid to all of the Team’s players that entered into
Player Contracts (including Renegotiations) during that Salary Cap Year.
Likely Bonuses
No Uniform Player Contract may provide for Incentive Compensation for a Season that exceeds twenty percent
(20%) of the Regular Salary called for by the Contract for such Season.
Example
The Lakers signed Yi Jianlian to a one-year $8 million contract in 2016.
As part of the contract, there were $6.86 million in what was considered likely bonuses.
Under the current CBA, the Yi contract would not have been allowed.
Signing bonus
No Uniform Player Contract may provide for a signing bonus that exceeds fifteen percent (15%) of the
Compensation (excluding Incentive Compensation) called for by the Contract (or, in the case of an Extension,
in the extended term of the Extension).

title: Q107: Can a player receive a bonus if they are traded?
content:
A Player Contract may contain (in Exhibit 4 to such Player Contract) a provision entitling a Player to earn
Compensation if the player's Uniform Player Contract is traded ("trade bonus") subject to the following:
A trade bonus shall be payable only the first time that the Contract is traded; provided, however, that if a
Contract is signed in connection with an agreement to trade the Contract and the Contract contains a trade
bonus, the bonus shall not apply to such initial trade but shall instead be payable only the second time the
Contract is traded.
A trade bonus shall not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the Base Compensation remaining to be earned by the
player pursuant to the Contract at the time of the trade (excluding an Option Year if not yet exercised).
128
How to calculate a trade bonus:
Example A
●   Dejounte Murray is under contract for 4 seasons with a player option in the last year.
●   He is owed $114M.
●   Murray has a 15% trade bonus for the salary owed, not including the player option.
●   Murray was traded to New Orleans on July 6.
●   The trade bonus is worth $12.1M (15% x $83,486,706)
●   The $12.1M bonus is spread evenly to the 2024-25, 2025-26, 2026-27 cap hit and counts as outgoing
salary. The player option is not factored in.
●   The sending team (Atlanta in this case) is responsible for paying the bonus.
Example B
● Rudy Gobert is under contract for 3 seasons with a player option in the last year.
● He has a 7.5% trade bonus for the remaining salary owed.
● His salary in the next 2 years is $35M (2025-26) and $36.5M (2026-27)
● Gobert is traded in July 2025 and has $71.5M left on his contract (not including the player option).
● The trade bonus= $71.5M x 7.5%= $5.36M
● $2.68M is applied to his 2024-25 and 2025-26 salary.
More trade bonus notes:
● Luka Doncic has a 15% trade bonus in his contract. However, because the bonus would exceed the
maximum salary allowed in 2024-25, the bonus was voided.

title: Q109: Can a team assign a player to the G-League?
content:
An NBA team may assign any player (other than a Two-Way Player) on its Active List or Inactive List to play in
the NBA G League for its affiliated NBA G League team, provided that (i) the player has zero, one, or two
Years of Service at the time of the assignment, or (ii) the player has more than two Years of Service and has
consented in writing to such assignment. With respect to an assignment of a player with more than two Years
of Service, the National Basketball Players Association also must consent in writing to the assignment prior to
the player being permitted to play (such Players Association consent to be secured by the NBA). A suspended
player may not be assigned to the NBA G League during the term of the suspension.
130
The Phoenix Suns may assign any player (other than a Two-Way Player) on its Active List or Inactive List to
any team other than G League Ignite or Mexico City Capitanes pursuant to the flexible assignment process
described below.

title: Q110: What is the In-season tournament?
content:
Each Season, the NBA will determine and supervise the arrangements made with respect to an In-Season
Tournament in accordance with the terms set forth below.
Tournament Phases
The In-Season Tournament will consist of two stages: the “Group Stage” and the “Knockout Stage.”
A. Group Stage
1. During the first two months of the Regular Season, all thirty teams will participate in the Group Stage.
During this period, two days of each week will be designated for the playing of “Group Stage Games”
and the only games played on such days will be Group Stage Games.
2. Group Stage Games will be treated as Regular Season games for all purposes under the CBA. A
team’s record in Group Stage Games will determine whether the team qualifies for the Knockout Stage.
3. Each team’s opponents in the Group Stage Games will be determined as follows:
The fifteen teams in each Conference will be divided into three groups of five teams each (for a total of six
groups of five teams each league wide). A team will play each of the other teams in its group in one Group
Stage Game during the Group Stage, for a total of four Group Stage Games per team.
Teams will be placed in groups via a random drawing:
Prior to the drawing, in each Conference each team will be placed into a “pot” based on its record in the prior
Regular Season. The teams with the three best prior-Regular-Season records in a conference will be placed in
“Pot 1” for its conference; the teams with the fourth through sixth best prior-Regular-Season records will be
placed in “Pot 2”; the teams with the seventh through ninth best prior-Regular-Season records will be placed in
“Pot 3”; the teams with the tenth through twelfth best prior-Regular-Season records will be placed in “Pot 4”;
and the teams with the thirteenth through fifteenth best prior-Regular-Season records will be placed in “Pot 5.”
In each Conference, one team from each pot will be randomly selected into each of the three groups in that
Conference (i.e., “East Group A,” “East Group B,” “East Group C,” “West Group A,” “West Group B,” and “West
Group C”).
The team with the best standing in Group Stage Games in each of the six groups will advance to the Knockout
Stage. Final standings in each group will be determined based on records in Group Stage Games. In the event
two or more teams are tied within a group, the tie among the teams will be broken based on record in Group
Stage Games against each other and, if still tied, based on better net result of total points scored less total
points allowed in all Group Stage Games. These and additional tiebreakers will be confirmed by the NBA
following consultation with the Competition Committee.
131
A “wildcard” team from each Conference will also advance to the Knockout Stage. The wildcard team will be
the team from each Conference with the best record in Group Stage Games that finished second in its group.
In the event two or more teams are tied for the wildcard in a Conference, the tie among the teams will be
broken based on better net result of total points scored less total points allowed in all Group Stage Games.
These and additional tiebreakers will be confirmed by the NBA following consultation with the Competition
Committee.
Knockout Stage
Eight teams will participate in the Knockout Stage, a phase of the tournament consisting of single-elimination
“Knockout Games.”
Games played in the first and second rounds of the Knockout Stage (the “IST Quarterfinals” and “IST
Semifinals,” respectively) will be treated as Regular Season games for all purposes under the CBA (other than
as set forth in the BRI section above). The “IST Finals Game” will not be considered a Regular Season game
for purposes of a team’s Regular Season record and a player’s or team’s performance in such game will not be
considered for purposes of bonuses or conditional protection, but will be considered for purposes of
determining whether the player has met the games played requirement for certain league honors, and certain
rules that apply to Regular Season games.
In each Conference,(i)IST Quarterfinal games will be hosted by the two teams with the best record in Group
Stage Games, and (ii) the team with the best record in Group Stage Games will host the wildcard team. In the
event two or more teams are tied for the best record in Group Stage Games, the tie among the teams will be
broken based on better net result of total points scored less total points allowed in all Group Stage Games.
These and additional tiebreakers will be confirmed by the NBA following consultation with the Competition
Committee.
TheIST Semifinals games and IST Finals Game will be played at a neutral site (i.e., not the home arena for any
participating team).
A player will not be eligible to participate in the IST Finals Game with a participating team unless such player
was on the team’s roster as of the start of the first scheduled IST Semifinals game.
The four teams that lose in the IST Quarterfinals will each play one additional Regular Season game during the
Knockout Stage on days on which IST Semifinal games and the IST Finals Game are not scheduled.
The 22 teams that do not participate in the Knockout Stage will each play two Regular Season games during
the Knockout Stage on days on which Knockout Games are not scheduled.
The actual In-Season Tournament schedule for the 2023-24 Season will be established by the NBA by August
2023 and, prior to the public announcement of the schedule, the Players Association will have the opportunity
to provide the NBA with comments, which will be considered in good faith.
132
Tournament Awards A. Prize Pool
For the 2023-24 Season, an In-Season Tournament Prize Pool will be allocated to the players on the teams
that participate in the Knockout Stage as follows:
●   $500,000 to each player on the team that wins the IST Finals Game;
●   $200,000 to each player on the team that loses the IST Finals Game;
●   $100,000 to each player on a team that loses in the IST Semifinals; and
●   $50,000 to each player on a team that loses in the IST Quarterfinals.
For each player, the amounts set forth above will be multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which is the
number of Knockout Games for which the player was eligible to play for the team and the denominator of which
is the total number of Knockout Games played by the team. For the purposes of the calculation described in
this Section, an In-Season Tournament game for a which a player was eligible to play while under a Two-Way
Contract or a 10-Day Contract will count as one half of a game for which the player was eligible to play for the
team.
The amounts, if any, by which the prize amounts set forth above will grow annually are subject to further
discussion between the parties.
The In-Season Tournament Prize Pool will be included each Season in the calculation of Benefits.
League Honors
Each year, players will be selected for the following league honors related to the In-Season Tournament: Most
Valuable In-Season Tournament Player and All-Tournament Team. Selection will be based on the players’
performance in Group Stage and Knockout Stage Games.

title: Q111: What is the age requirement for the NBA Draft?
content:
No player may sign a Contract or play in the NBA unless he has been eligible for selection in at least one (1)
NBA Draft. No player shall be eligible for selection in more than two (2) NBA Drafts.
A player shall be eligible for selection in first NBA Draft with respect to which he has satisfied all applicable
requirements below:
The player (A) is or will be at least nineteen (19) years of age during the calendar year in which the Draft is
held, and (B) with respect to a player who is not an “international player” (defined below), at least one (1) NBA
Season has elapsed since the player’s graduation from high school (or, if the player did not graduate from high
school, since the later of the graduation of the class with which the player would have graduated based on the
high school class he was in when he (i) first enrolled in high school, or (ii) was last enrolled in high school); and
The player has graduated from a four-year college or university in the United States (or is to graduate in the
calendar year in which the Draft is held) and has no remaining intercollegiate basketball eligibility; or
133
The player is attending or previously attended a four-year college or university in the United States, his original
class in such college or university has graduated (or is to graduate in the calendar year in which the Draft is
held), and he has no remaining intercollegiate basketball eligibility; or
The player has graduated from high school in the United States, did not enroll in a four-year college or
university in the United States, and four (4) calendar years have elapsed since such player’s high school
graduation; or
The player did not graduate from high school in the United States, and four (4) calendar years have elapsed
since the graduation of the class with which the player would have graduated had he graduated from high
school; or
The player is or will be at least twenty-two (22) years of age during the calendar year of the Draft, has signed a
“non-NBA professional basketball contract” (defined below), and has rendered services under such contract
prior to the January1 immediately preceding such Draft; or
The player is or will be twenty-two (22) years of age during the calendar year of the Draft and is an
international player; or
The player has expressed his desire to be selected in the Draft in a writing received by the NBA at least sixty
(60) days prior to such Draft (an “Early Entry” player).
International player is a player: (i) who has maintained a permanent residence outside of the United States for
at least the three (3) years prior to the Draft, while participating in the game of basketball as an amateur or as a
professional outside of the United States; (ii) who has never previously enrolled in a college or university in the
United States; and (iii) who did not complete high school in the United States.
A “non-NBA professional basketball contract” means a contract between a player and any non-NBA basketball
team or league pursuant to which the team or league pays money or compensation of any kind – in excess of a
stipend for living expenses – to the player for rendering services to a basketball team.
A “professional basketball team or league not in the NBA” means any team or league that pays money or
compensation of any kind – in excess of a stipend for living expenses – to a basketball player for rendering
services to such team and/or league.

title: Q112: What are the rules for the Draft combine? What happens after the combine
content:
concludes?
Beginning with the 2024 NBA Draft Combine, all invited players will be required to attend and participate in the
Draft Combine.
Refusal to Attend the Combine
134
Invited players who are not excused and do not fully participate in the Combine (or in any required subsequent
testing), or are excused and do not subsequently complete components of the Combine as reasonably
determined by the NBA in consultation with the Players Association, will not be eligible to be drafted in the NBA
until the first subsequent Draft for which the player attends and fully participates in the Combine (and any
required subsequent testing) immediately preceding such Draft.
General Attendance Requirement
All players invited to attend the Draft Combine will be required to attend and participate in:
On-Court/Measurements
Strength and agility tests, shooting drills, performance testing, and anthropometric measurements (height,
wingspan, etc.) (5 on 5 will be optional for all players).
Medical/Health
League medical history/testing, medical examinations, and biomechanical and functional movement testing, in
accordance with Section VI below.
Other
Media circuit, player development sessions, team interviews, and tests/assessments, as determined by the
NBA in consultation with the Players Association.
Player Experience at Combine
Flights
All Combine attendees and one family member will travel first class.
Hotels
All Combine attendees will have individual hotel rooms.
Media Exposure
The NBA will undertake to provide new media opportunities at the Combine to benefit players.
Mental Health and Wellness Awareness Efforts
Jointly-created mental health programming for players will be included as part of the Pre-Draft Information
Program presented at the Combine.
G League Contract Offer for All Combine Attendees
All players who attend and participate in the Combine will be offered a G League contract covering the
following season.
135
Players Physically Unable to Participate
Any player who is physically unable to participate in one or more basketball activities, medical tests, functional
movement tests, or any other tests required at the Combine will be:
Excused from participation in the applicable activities or tests;
Required to complete the component(s) of the Combine that he is able to complete (e.g., team interviews,
medical history, certain medical testing, etc.); and
Required subsequently to complete components of the Combine (e.g., any medical testing that he was unable
to participate in at the Combine, strength and agility testing) as reasonably determined by the NBA at a later
date before the Draft unless he remains physically unable to do so.
Any such determination with respect to this Section IV will be made by the medical director of the Combine,
who will be required to consider any opinion timely provided by the player’s treating physician.
Other Excused Absences
A player may be excused from attending one or more days of the Combine due to a reasonable excuse, as
reasonably determined by the NBA (e.g., family tragedy, birth of a child, playing with a FIBA club that is still in
season at the time of the Combine). Any such player may be required subsequently to complete components
of the Combine as reasonably determined by the NBA in consultation with the Players Association at a later
date before the Draft (e.g., by attending an NBA Global Camp or via individual assessments and exams
arranged by the NBA).
Combine Medical Testing
The medical testing and performance testing at the Combine will be established by the NBA after consultation
with the Players Association.
Independent Second Opinion Physicians at Combine
The NBA and Players Association will agree annually on joint second opinion physicians (specific to orthopedic
specialties – e.g., foot and ankle, spine, hip, wrist/hand) to attend the Combine, examine certain players, and
write an expert report for each player examined to be entered into the player’s EMR file, which will then be
made available to the player and teams in accordance with Section IX below. A second opinion examination
will take place and a report will be created either at a player’s or team’s request.
Follow-Up Medical Testing. Based on available medical information, including the results of medical testing at
the Combine, players may be required to undergo reasonable and appropriate follow-up testing before the
Draft, as determined by the medical director of the Combine in consultation with the player’s treating physician.
Limits on Certain Team Access to League Medical History/Testing, Medical Examinations, and Biomechanical
and Functional Movement Testing for Certain Players
136
Team Access. Information related to Sections I.A. and I.B. above (including, without limitation, any information
related to Sections IV-VIII above) for all invited players will be shared with all teams, except that with respect to
the results of the league medical history/testing, medical examinations, and biomechanical and functional
movement testing, the only teams that will receive such information for a player ranked as a top-10 prospect
are those with a Draft pick in such player’s Potential Draft Range (as set forth below).
Player Rank                          Potential Draft Range
1                                   1-10
2-6                                 1-15
7-10                                1-25
Any assignee team that trades for a Draft pick in the then-upcoming Draft would be provided with access to
such information for each player in the Potential Draft Range associated with such pick (e.g., if a team with the
16th pick in the then-upcoming Draft acquires the 15th pick in the then-upcoming Draft, such team would gain
access to the results of league medical history/testing, medical examinations, and biomechanical and
functional movement testing for players ranked 2-6).
Confidentiality
Teams may use the results of league medical history/testing, medical examinations, and biomechanical and
functional movement testing for Draft evaluation purposes only, and may not discuss any such results with
representatives of any other team (regardless of whether the other team would otherwise have access to the
same results); provided, however, that (1) subject to Section IX.A. above, team medical staff may discuss such
results with medical staff of other teams who performed the medical examination of the player at the Combine
or in connection with Sections IV, V, or VIII above (for clarity, the only team personnel who will be involved in
such examinations will be those who are entitled to access the player’s information ; (2) a team may discuss
such results with representatives from other teams entitled to access the player’s information if the player
provides written consent (with notice to the Players Association); and (3) nothing in this Exhibit shall limit any
rights a team has to use or disclose such results in respect of a player who is under contract with the team or
as to whom the team holds exclusive Draft rights (e.g., following the Draft, a team disclosure of medical
information in connection with a trade of a player’s Draft rights). For clarity, a team will not have violated this
confidentiality restriction to the extent its discussion involves only public information regarding a player.
If the NBA has reason to believe that this confidentiality restriction has been violated, it will advise the Players
Association in a timely manner.
If the Players Association determines that this confidentiality restriction has been violated, it may bring a
proceeding before the System Arbitrator.
Upon a finding by the System Arbitrator of a material violation, the System Arbitrator shall have the authority to
impose on any team found to have committed such violation a fine of up to $1,000,000. In considering an
appropriate fine for a violation, the System Arbitrator shall take into account all relevant factors, including but
137
not limited to the impact of the violation on the player, the degree of care demonstrated by the team, and any ill
intent regarding the player.
Ranking NBA Prospects
The NBA and Players Association will agree upon, and include in the new CBA, a method to rank the top-10
prospects prior to the Draft Lottery using a blend of publicly-available rankings, an appointed panel of experts,
and a retained-scouting service.
Fitness-to-Play
For clarity, and consistent with current practice, nothing herein will limit the right of the NBA, Players
Association, or a team to refer a player to a Fitness-to-Play Panel if advised by a physician that the player has
a potentially life-threatening injury, illness, or other medical condition that renders him medically unable and/or
medically unfit to perform his duties as a professional basketball player and/or that performing such duties
would create a materially elevated risk of death, paralysis, or other permanent spinal injury for the player.
Should the NBA, Players Association, or a team refer a player to a Fitness-to-Play Panel (e.g., if advised by
one of the cardiologists at the Combine that a player has a potentially life-threatening medical condition that
would create a materially elevated risk of death for the player), then the fact that the case was referred, the
Panel’s determination, and related records will, in accordance with the Fitness-to-Play Panel process, be made
available to all 30 teams.
Post-Draft Access
Beginning on the day after the conclusion of the Draft, teams will no longer have access to league medical
history/testing and medical examination results for any player whom they did not select in the Draft or whose
Draft rights they do not hold.
Agents at Combine
To promote players’ access to their representatives, certified player agents who represent players participating
in the Combine will be (A) credentialed for the on-court portion of the Combine, and (B) able to reserve a room
in the official Combine hotel block (agents will be required to pay for their own rooms).
Additional Consultation
Following execution of the new CBA, the NBA will consult with the Players Association in good faith on (A)
creating a list of non-exclusive jointly-recommended interview questions to provide to NBA teams each year
prior to the Combine and (B) any issues the Players Association raises relating to scheduling or operational
details of the Combine (e.g., setting the dates and location of the Combine, elements of the player experience
at the Combine).
138
Pro Days
Prior to the NBA Draft each year, teams will be prohibited from attending any workouts organized by
draft-eligible players or such players’ agents or representatives (e.g., “pro days”) other than those (A)
conducted as part of the NBA Draft Combine (with such workouts scheduled by the NBA in coordination with
the Players Association); or (B) organized by the Players Association (in coordination with the NBA) in (1)
California, and (2) a location on the East Coast, provided that the workouts conducted will, in each case, take
place in a single athletic facility over no more than a two-day period (provided, however, that in circumstances
where conducting the workouts in a two-day period is impracticable, such workouts may, following discussion
by the NBA and Players Association, be conducted over a three-day period). The NBA and Players Association
will continue to discuss whether the workouts conducted in California and on the East Coast may take place in
NBA team facilities.
Automatic Eligibility
A player will no longer be automatically eligible for the NBA Draft by virtue of rendering services to a non-NBA
professional basketball team, and Article X, Section 1 will be revised to provide that such a player will be
automatically eligible for an NBA Draft if he is or will be 22 years of age during the calendar year of the Draft.

title: Q115: What are the types of salary protection?
content:
Lack of Skill
When a Team agrees to protect, in whole or in part, the Base Compensation provided for by a Uniform Player
Contract in the event such Contract is terminated by the Team, by reason of the player’s lack of skill, the
termination of such Contract by the Team on account of the player’s failure to exhibit sufficient skill or
competitive ability shall in no way affect the player’s right to receive, in whole or in part, the Base
Compensation payable pursuant to Exhibit 1 (or Exhibit 1A or Exhibit 1B, as applicable) to such Contract in the
amounts and at the times called for by such Exhibit; provided, however, that: (i) such lack of skill does not
result from the player’s participation in activities prohibited by Paragraph 12 of the Uniform Player Contract (as
such Paragraph may be modified by Exhibit 5 to the Player Contract), attempted suicide, intentional
self-inflicted injury, abuse of alcohol, use of any Prohibited Substance or controlled substance, abuse of or
addiction to prescription drugs, conduct occurring during the commission of any felony for which the player is
convicted (including by a plea of guilty, no contest, or nolo contendere), participation in any riot, insurrection, or
war or other military activities, or failure to comply with the requirements of Paragraphs 7(d)-(i) of the Uniform
Player Contract; (ii) at the time of the player’s failure to render playing services, the player is not in material
breach of such Contract; (iii) if the Team, for its own benefit, seeks to procure an insurance policy covering the
player’s lack of skill, the player cooperates with the Team in procuring such an insurance policy, including by,
among other things, supplying all information requested of him, completing application forms, or otherwise, and
submitting to all examinations and tests requested of him by or on behalf of the insurance company in
connection with the Team’s efforts to procure such policy; and (iv) if the Team, for its own benefit, has procured
such an insurance policy, the player cooperates (in the manner described above) with the Team and insurance
company in the processing of the Team’s claim under such policy.
181
Death
When a Team agrees to protect, in whole or in part, the Base Compensation provided for by a Uniform Player
Contract in the event such Contract is terminated by the Team, if such failure has been caused by the player’s
death, the termination of such Contract by the Team shall in no way affect the player’s (or his estate’s or duly
appointed beneficiary’s) right to receive, in whole or in part, the Base Compensation payable pursuant to
Exhibit 1 (or Exhibit 1A or Exhibit 1B, as applicable) to such Contract in the amounts and at the times called for
by such Exhibit; provided, however, that: (i) such death does not result from the player’s participation in
activities prohibited by Paragraph 12 of the Uniform Player Contract (as such Paragraph may be modified by
Exhibit 5 to the Player Contract), suicide, intentional self-inflicted injury, abuse of alcohol, use of any Prohibited
Substance or controlled substance, abuse of or addiction to prescription drugs, conduct occurring during the
commission of any felony for which the player is convicted (including by a plea of guilty, no contest, or nolo
contendere), participation in any riot, insurrection, or war or other military activities, or failure to comply with the
requirements of Paragraphs 7(d)-(i) of the Uniform Player Contract; (ii) at the time of the player’s failure to
render playing services, the player is not in material breach of such Contract; (iii) if the Team, for its own
benefit, seeks to procure an insurance policy covering the player’s death, the player cooperates with the Team
in procuring such an insurance policy, including by, among other things, supplying all information requested of
him, completing application forms, or otherwise, and submitting to all examinations and tests requested of him
by or on behalf of the insurance company in connection with the Team’s efforts to procure such policy; and (iv)
if the Team, for its own benefit, has procured such an insurance policy, the player’s estate and/or duly
appointed beneficiary cooperates (in the manner described above) with the Team and insurance company in
the processing of the Team’s claim under such policy.
Injury or Illness
When a Team agrees to protect, in whole or in part, the Base Compensation provided for by a Uniform Player
Contract in the event such contract is terminated by the Team, by reason of the player’s failure to render his
services thereunder, if such failure has been caused by an injury, illness, or disability suffered or sustained by
the player, the termination of such Contract by the Team shall in no way affect the player’s right to receive, in
whole or in part, the Base Compensation payable pursuant to Exhibit 1 (or Exhibit 1A or Exhibit 1B, as
applicable) to such Contract in the amounts and at the times called for by such Exhibit; provided, however,
that: (i) such injury, illness, or disability does not result from the player’s participation in activities prohibited by
Paragraph 12 of the Uniform Player Contract (as such Paragraph may be modified in Exhibit 5 to the Player
Contract), attempted suicide, intentional self-inflicted injury, abuse of alcohol, use of any Prohibited Substance
or controlled substance, abuse of or addiction to prescription drugs, conduct occurring during the commission
of any felony for which the player is convicted (including by a plea of guilty, no contest, or nolo contendere),
participation in any riot, insurrection, or war or other military activities, or failure to comply with the
requirements of Paragraphs 7(d)-(i) of the Uniform Player Contract; (ii) at the time of such injury, illness, or
disability the player is not in material breach of such Contract; (iii) if the Team, for its own benefit, seeks to
procure an insurance policy covering the player’s injury and/or illness, the player cooperates with the Team in
procuring such an insurance policy, including by, among other things, supplying all information requested of
him, completing application forms, or otherwise, and submitting to all examinations and tests requested of him
182
by or on behalf of the insurance company in connection with the Team’s efforts to procure such policy; and (iv)
if the Team, for its own benefit, has procured such an insurance policy, the player cooperates (in the manner
described above) with the Team and insurance company in the processing of the Team’s claim under such
policy.
Mental Disability
When a Team agrees to protect, in whole or in part, the Base Compensation provided for by a Uniform Player
Contract in the event such Contract is terminated by the Team, if such failure has been caused by the player’s
mental disability, the termination of such Contract by the Team shall in no way affect the player’s (or his duly
appointed legal representative’s) right to receive, in whole or in part, the Base Compensation payable pursuant
to Exhibit 1 (or Exhibit 1A or Exhibit 1B, as applicable) to such Contract in the amounts and at the times called
for by such Exhibit; provided, however, that: (i) such mental disability does not result from the player’s
participation in activities prohibited by Paragraph 12 of the Uniform Player Contract (as such Paragraph may
be modified in Exhibit 5 to the Player Contract), attempted suicide, intentional self-inflicted injury, the use of any
Prohibited Substance or controlled substance, abuse of or addiction to prescription drugs, conduct occurring
during the commission of any felony for which the player is convicted (including by a plea of guilty, no contest,
or nolo contendere), participation in any riot, insurrection, or war or other military activities, or failure to comply
with the requirements of Paragraphs 7(d)-(i) of the Uniform Player Contract; (ii) at the time of the player’s
failure to render playing services, the player is not in material breach of such Contract; (iii) if the Team, for its
own benefit, seeks to procure an insurance policy covering the player’s mental disability, the player (and/or his
duly appointed legal representative) cooperates with the Team in procuring such an insurance policy, including
by, among other things, supplying all information requested of him, completing application forms, or otherwise,
and submitting to all examinations and tests requested of him by the insurance company in connection with the
Team’s efforts to procure such policy; and (iv) if the Team, for its own benefit, has Procured such an insurance
policy, the player (and/or his duly appointed legal representative) cooperates (in the manner described above)
with the Team and insurance company in the processing of the Team’s claim under such policy.
Miscellaneous
No agreement by a Team to protect, in whole or in part, the Base Compensation provided for by a Uniform
Player Contract shall require (or be construed as requiring) such Team to continue to employ the player
(whether on the Active List, Inactive List, Two-Way List, or otherwise); nor shall any such agreement afford the
player any right to be employed, or to be deemed as having been employed, by such Team for any purpose.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, when a Team agrees to protect, in whole or in part, the
Base Compensation provided for by a Uniform Player Contract, and such protection is contingent on the
satisfaction of a condition expressly set forth in Exhibit 2 to that Contract, such protection shall be applicable
183
and effective only if the Player Contract has not previously been terminated at the time such condition is
satisfied.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, when a Team agrees to protect, in whole or in part, the
Base Compensation provided for in any Option Year in favor of the Team included in a Uniform Player
Contract, such protection shall be applicable and effective only if the option to extend the term provided for in
the Contract was exercised by the Team prior to the termination of the Contract. When a Team agrees to
protect, in whole or in part, the Base Compensation provided for in any Option Year in favor of the player, the
applicability of such protection in the circumstance where the Option has not been exercised by the player.
During the term of a Player Contract, the percentage of protected Base Compensation for any future Season
shall not exceed the percentage of unearned protected Base Compensation for any prior Season.
Thus, for example, a Team could not provide for fifty percent (50%) Base Compensation protection in the first
Season of a Player Contract and one hundred percent (100%) Base Compensation protection in the second
Season of the Contract.
However, the foregoing rule does not prevent a Team from providing a percentage of Base Compensation
protection in a future Season that is higher than in a prior Season if the higher level of Base Compensation for
the future Season is conditional and the condition cannot be satisfied until the completion of the prior Season.
For example, it is permissible for a Contract to provide that Base Compensation protection for the first Season
of a Player Contract equals fifty percent (50%) and Base Compensation protection for the second Season will
be increased from fifty percent (50%) to one hundred percent (100%) if the player is on the Team’s roster as of
the August 1 prior to the second Season of the Player Contract.

title: Q117: Can a player receive compensation for training camp?
content:
The weekly training camp advance payment amount set forth in Paragraph 3(b) of the UPC will increase from
$2,000 to $4,500, and such advances will be recovered equally from a player’s first two scheduled
semi-monthly payments of Base Compensation (instead of from only the first such payment).
Note: If a player under contract with guaranteed salary receives a training camp payment, that player will have
the $4,500 per week deducted from his salary.

title: Q118: Can a player receive an advance?
content:
A player can get up to 25 percent of their annual salary as of July 1. They can get another 25 percent as of
October 1. No more than 50 percent of the salary can be paid in advance of the first standard payment starting
November 1.
If a player's salary isn't fully guaranteed, the advance is limited to 80 percent of the guaranteed salary, or 50
percent of his base salary—the lower of the two. Then, the player can get up to 25 percent of that amount as of
July 1 and October 1.
In the case of the Matisse Thybulle offer sheet signed with Dallas (and eventually matched by Portland),
Thybulle will receive $2,625,00 (25 percent) of his 2023-24 salary 14 days after approval of the contract. He
will also receive $2,625,000 (25 percent) of his 2023-24 salary on October 1.

title: Q119: Does the team have disability insurance in case a player is injured?
content:
Every team is required to participate in the Leaguewide Temporary Total Disability Insurance Program
(the “TTD Program”). In general, under the terms of the TTD Program, each team will be required to
submit for underwriting consideration five players, each of whom must be among the team’s five
highest-paid players based on either current season salary or total remaining salary. Such five
players must include the players who rank first and second under the current-season salary and total
remaining salary categories with two or more contract years remaining. Teams may submit for
consideration more than five players.
In general, once an insured player has a covered disability for a period greater than 41 Regular
Season games, the TTD Program will pay to the team a disability insurance benefit equal to 80% of
the player’s Regular Season salary on a per game basis beginning with the 42nd game until the time
the player is fit to play or the policy ends. The term of the policy may not exceed six years. The
maximum benefit payable by the insurer will not exceed $275,000 per Regular Season game.
