title: Q120: What are the anti-collusion rules?
content:
The CBA’s anti-collusion provisions generally prohibit “agreements” (express or implied) among teams that
they will not negotiate with or sign particular players or as to what contract terms will or will not be offered.
Violation of the anti-collusion provisions of the CBA can have severe repercussions for both individual teams
and the NBA. It is thus vital that teams proceed with caution in their communications regarding free agents,
consult team counsel and the NBA Legal Department with any questions, and adhere to the rules set forth in
this Section H.
Prohibited and Permitted Conduct.
201
No team, or any of its employees or agents, may enter into any agreement, express or implied, with any other
team (i) to negotiate or to refrain from negotiating with any veteran or rookie, (ii) to submit or not to submit an
Offer Sheet to any Restricted Free Agent, (iii) to offer or not to offer a player contract to a free agent, (iv) to
exercise or not to exercise a right of first refusal, or (v) concerning the terms and conditions of employment
offered to any veteran or rookie.
The CBA does not prohibit all communication among teams on the subject of free agent negotiations. Under
the CBA and league rules, the following communications are permitted:
Each team’s Designated Negotiators (i.e.,the two persons designated as the only representatives of the team
who may conduct free agent negotiations, as discussed in Paragraph H.3 below) are authorized to
communicate with the Designated Negotiators of any other team in order to verify or confirm claims that
particular offers have been made or promised to particular players. For example, if it is claimed that a player
has been offered or promised an offer of a particular salary or a particular range of salary, a team’s Designated
Negotiators are permitted to contact the Designated Negotiators of the team that allegedly made the offer to
inquire as to whether the offer was in fact made. This applies to claims about offers to any player, regardless of
whether the team is interested in signing that player. The purpose of this rule is only to ensure that teams can
conduct their free agent negotiations on the basis of accurate and truthful information and will not be misled by
false or exaggerated claims or reports.
The league office is prohibited from disclosing to any team that another team has negotiated with or is
negotiating with any free agent. The league office may discuss with any team its own negotiations with free
agents and provide advice and assistance concerning the structuring of player contracts. However, the league
office may not pass on to other teams any information regarding a team’s negotiations with free agents.
Teams may not enter into any agreement or understanding with respect to the signing and trading of a player,
except in accordance with the “sign-and-trade” rules set forth in the CBA.
Teams are prohibited from failing or refusing to negotiate or enter into a player contract with any player who is
free to negotiate and sign a contract with any team because that player: (i) has previously been subject to the
exclusive draft rights obtained by another team in an NBA Draft; (ii) has previously refused or failed to enter
into a player contract containing an option; (iii) has become a Restricted or Unrestricted Free Agent; or (iv) is or
has previously been subject to a Right of First Refusal. This, of course, does not require a team to negotiate
with a free agent if it genuinely is not interested in his services.
Penalties under the Anti-Collusion Rules
If collusion is found, the affected players will have the right to terminate their contracts and, in addition, the
following penalties will be imposed:
The first time a team engages in collusion, it will be required to pay double the amount of damages suffered by
any player injured by the collusion.
The second time a team engages in collusion, it will be required to pay treble damages; and
202
If a team engages in collusion more than twice, it will be required to pay treble damages, plus a fine of
$4,000,000.
In addition to these specific penalties, the Players Association will have the right to terminate the entire CBA,
upon a finding that:
In any one season, five or more teams have engaged in collusion and the collusion has affected five or more
players; or
In any two consecutive seasons, seven or more teams have engaged in collusion and the collusion has
affected seven or more players; or
At any time, 10 or more teams have engaged in collusion, even if only one player is affected.

title: Q121: What happens if a team circumvents the salary cap?
content:
The CBA contains salary cap circumvention rules that prohibit teams from, among other things, paying any
player for basketball services outside of the terms of his UPC, agreeing to enter into a future player contract, or
undertaking any action that is designed to circumvent the intention of the parties as reflected in the CBA. As
part of this broad prohibition, the circumvention rules generally prohibit teams from providing–or arranging for
others to provide – any compensation, benefit, or anything else of value to a player (or any person or entity
related to a player, such as his agent) unless such compensation, benefit, or other value is included in the
player’s UPC or otherwise expressly permitted under the CBA.
The following is a summary of the salary cap circumvention rules as set forth in Article XIII of the CBA. This
summary is intended only as a reference and is not meant to define the full meaning or scope of any provision
in the CBA. Each team is responsible for reviewing the applicable provisions of the CBA in their entirety and
taking appropriate steps to ensure that all team representatives and affiliates are in compliance at all times with
these rules.
Prohibited Conduct
(1) Under Article XIII, Section 2(a) of the CBA, a team is prohibited from entering into, among other things, any
agreements, transactions, promises, undertakings, or understandings of any kind with a player that involve
“compensation or consideration of any kind or anything else of value,” “an investment or business opportunity
to be furnished or made available to the player,” or “any future Renegotiation, Extension, or other amendment
of an existing Player Contract, or entry into a new Player Contract.” The general prohibition set forth above
means that, among other things, teams and Team Affiliates are prohibited from providing – or arranging for
others to provide – potential investment or business opportunities to a player, including any free agent or
draft-eligible player, or any person or entity related to a player. As noted above, the circumvention rules also
broadly prohibit teams and Team Affiliates from providing a player, or any person or entity related to a player,
with compensation, benefits, or things of value beyond what is called for in the player’s UPC and the CBA.
203
The above prohibition is very broad and is violated even absent any specific intention to provide compensation
to a player or otherwise circumvent the salary cap. Even an attempt to enter into or solicit a relationship that is
prohibited under Article XIII, Section 2(a) constitutes a violation of the prohibition.
(2) Under Article XIII, Section 1(b) of the CBA, a team is prohibited from entering into an agreement or
understanding with a sponsor, business partner, or any other third party under which the third party pays or
agrees to pay compensation for basketball services to a player under contract to the team, even if such
compensation is ostensibly designated as being for non-basketball services.
(3) Under Article XIII, Section 1(c) of the CBA, a team is prohibited from having a financial arrangement with or
offering a financial inducement to any player (not including retired players) not signed to a current Player
Contract. Consistent with the foregoing, teams are prohibited from, among other things, paying an unsigned
player to practice or work out with the team or paying or offering to pay compensation to an unsigned draft
rookie or unsigned free agent in exchange for such player agreeing to participate in a summer league or a
rookie camp. The only compensation that may be provided to a player participating in a summer league or
rookie camp is as set forth in Section IV.A.3 of this Manual.
Also note that under the league’s salary cap circumvention rules teams are prohibited from providing – or
arranging for others to provide – potential investment or business opportunities to any international player (in
connection with the team’s attempt to secure rights to the player or otherwise).
b. Applicability of Prohibitions. All of the above prohibitions apply to all team representatives. For this purpose,
“team representatives” includes persons holding ownership interests in an NBA team, as well as all full-time or
part-time personnel, officers, directors, employees, agents, or other representatives of the team, and whether
classified as “employee,” “consultant,” or otherwise. The prohibitions also apply to any other persons who are
directed or authorized to act by team representatives. The prohibitions also apply to all Team Affiliates (as that
term is defined in the CBA). The prohibitions also apply to players’ agents and representatives and any other
person or entity related to a player. The prohibitions also apply to contacts by a team with players employed by
other teams (such contacts also may constitute tampering in violation of Article 35A(f) of the NBA Constitution;
see Paragraph D.1 above).
Teams are responsible for taking all appropriate steps to ensure that all team representatives are in
compliance at all times with the above CBA and NBA Constitution provisions.
c. Examples of Prohibited Conduct. Set forth below are examples of conduct that is prohibited under the
circumvention rules. Note that these examples are for purposes of illustration only and do not constitute an
exhaustive list of conduct prohibited under such rules.
Examples of Conduct Involving Investment or Business Opportunities That Is Prohibited Under the
Salary Cap Circumvention Rules.
(1) A team representative invests in a company that is related to a player, or a player invests in a company that
is affiliated with a team representative.
(2) A team representative helps a player gain access to an investment fund operated by a friend of the
representative.
204
(3) A team representative acquires an interest in a firm that represents NBA players.
(4) A team representative’s non-NBA company engages a player to make promotional appearances on behalf
of the company.
(5) A team promotes or sells a product that is produced by a player’s business.
(6) A team hires a player’s relative in a business, operations, administrative, or other similar role.
(7) A business owned by a team representative’s spouse signs a player to an endorsement deal.
(8) A team representative assists a player in negotiating or obtaining a product endorsement agreement with a
sports apparel company.
(9) A team representative recommends one of the team’s players to a team sponsor as a candidate for an
endorsement arrangement. (If teams are approached by business partners or other third parties regarding a
potential business relationship with a player, teams should respond solely by providing the third party with
contact information for the player and/or his agent.)
(10) A team’s affiliated arena rents retail space in the arena to a player or a business owned by the player.
(11) A team suggests to a local company that the company offer a player an opportunity to enter into a
business venture or agreement if the player signs a contract with the team.
(12) A team sells a sponsorship to a business owned by a player.
(13) A media business operated by a team representative enters into a partnership with a player or a business
owned by a player.
(14) A team employs a recently-retired player in a non-playing capacity (e.g., as a player development or
affiliated G League coach) and subsequently seeks to re-sign the individual as a player.
NOTE: Teams are allowed, subject to all CBA rules, to hire a recently retired player in a non-playing capacity;
however, if a team does so, it will thereafter be prohibited from signing the individual as a player.
Examples of Other Prohibited Conduct Under the Salary Cap Circumvention Rules.
(15) A team representative pays a cash bonus to a player (not disclosed in the player’s UPC) upon the player’s
signing with the team.
(16) A team representative promises a player who is currently under contract with the team that the team will
sign the player to a new UPC once the player’s current contract expires.
(17) At the time a player and team are negotiating the terms of a UPC, a team representative promises the
player that the team will also sign the player (or another player – e.g., a player represented by the same agent)
to a future UPC.
205
(18) A team makes payments or reimbursements to or on behalf of a player in respect of travel, lodging, or
meal expenses incurred in recruiting, negotiating, or signing the player in excess of that permitted under
league rules.
(19) A team agrees to promote, help organize, or donate give-away items for a player’s for-profit basketball
skills training camp.
(20) A team’s coach pays a cash prize to players who win shooting contests during team practices or who
recover a certain number of loose balls in a game.
(21) A team organizes and pays for a team-building activity or celebration in a non-business destination (e.g.,
Bermuda).
(22) An executive of a company affiliated with a team representative makes a residence in the team’s home
city available to one of the team’s players.
(23) A team representative takes a player to the Super Bowl at the representative’s expense.
(24) A team representative recommends a player for membership in a private club (e.g., a country club
membership).
(25) A team representative arranges, facilitates, or conducts any type of direct transaction with a player to
provide the player with goods or services (on a discounted basis or otherwise). The circumvention rules would
prohibit, for example, players participating in a corporate employee discount program of a company owned in
whole or in part by a team representative or a team sponsor providing players with the sponsor’s products for
free.
(26) A team representative allows a player use of a private aircraft (e.g., plane, helicopter, etc.) in
circumstances other than those expressly permitted by league rules. (Please refer to Paragraph I.2.b below for
details.)
Penalties
Penalties for violating the circumvention rules include forfeiture of draft picks, a team fine of up to $7.5 million,
suspension of team personnel, and voiding of current and future player contracts between the team and any
players at issue.
A violation of the rules may be proven by direct or circumstantial evidence, but not limited to, evidence that a
Player Contract or any term or provision thereof cannot rationally be explained in the absence of the conduct
violating the rules.
Reporting Requirements
(1) Mandatory Circumvention Certification. The CBA requires a certification from each team that it has not
violated the circumvention provisions during the preceding season. Refer to Paragraph H.4 below for the
required certification language.
206
(2) Solicitation of Unauthorized Benefits. Teams are required to report to the league office any solicitation by
a player of compensation or other benefits that are not authorized under the CBA. This includes any solicitation
made by a player himself, by the player’s agent, or by any other person acting (or purporting to act) on the
player’s behalf. Reports must be made even if the solicitation is rejected. For purposes of this requirement, a
“solicitation” includes a request, suggestion, demand, or any other communication that seeks an unauthorized
benefit, whether express or implied. Thus, for example, if a free agent tells a team representative that he will
sign a player contract with that team if the team’s owner commits to invest in a business owned by the player, a
report would be required. Similarly, if a player’s agent tells a team representative that the player will demand a
trade unless the team pays the player a cash bonus outside the player’s UPC, a report would be required.
Reports must be made within 24 hours of the relevant activity.
(3) Contact by Uncertified Player Representatives. Teams are required to report any contacts initiated on a
player’s behalf by an uncertified player representative regarding contracts, transactions, or related matters.
Thus, for example, if a free agent’s friend (who is not a certified agent) contacts a team representative to
discuss potential contract terms on the player’s behalf, a report would be required. Reports must be made
within 24 hours of the relevant activity.
As a reminder, negotiating a player contract with an agent or representative who is not certified by the Players
Association is prohibited under the CBA. The Players Association periodically provides the league office with
updated lists of players and the agents that represent them.

title: Q122: What happens if a team, agent or player tampers?
content:
Article 35A(f) of the NBA Constitution provides as follows:
“No person may, directly or indirectly, (i) entice, induce, persuade, or attempt to entice, induce or persuade, any
Player who is under contract to, or whose exclusive negotiating rights are held by, any other Member of the
Association to enter into negotiations for or relating to his services or negotiate or contract for such services or
(ii) otherwise interfere with any such employer-employee relationship (or prospective employer-employee
relationship in the case of a Player subject to exclusive negotiating rights) of any other Member of the
Association. The Commissioner, either in his discretion or at the request of a Member who alleges that its
Player has been tampered with, shall conduct an investigation into whether a person has violated the
anti-tampering rule set forth in the prior sentence. In the event that, following such investigation and a hearing
at which the person (and the Member employing the person allegedly tampered with) has an opportunity to be
heard after due notice, the Commissioner determines that the anti-tampering rule has been violated, he shall
have the power, in his sole discretion, to impose a penalty for such offense, which penalty may include (without
limitation) the suspension of such person for a definite or indefinite period; the prohibition of the Member
employing or otherwise affiliated with the offending person from hiring the Player tampered with for a definite or
indefinite period; the forfeiture of Draft picks held by the Member employing or otherwise affiliated with the
offending person or the transfer of such Draft picks to the aggrieved Member; and/or the imposition of a fine
upon the offending person and/or the Member employing or otherwise affiliated with such offending person in
207
an amount not to exceed $10,000,000. In the event that the Commissioner imposes a fine, he may direct that
some or all of the fine be paid directly to the Member aggrieved by the tampering.’’
Article 35A(e) of the NBA Constitution provides for a similar tampering prohibition covering coaches, trainers,
general managers, or any other person who is under contract to any team.
The anti-tampering rule contained in the NBA Constitution embodies a fundamental principle in a league of
partners – namely, that employment contracts are to be respected and conduct that interferes with contractual
employment relationships is prohibited. This principle is particularly important in today’s media environment,
where any actions or comments relating to potential player movement receive immediate and widespread
public attention. Teams should be entitled to focus their efforts on the competition with the players they have
under contract, without having to divert attention or resources to conduct or speculate regarding the potential
destinations of those players in future seasons once their contracts expire.
The scope of the anti-tampering rule is broad, and its application in any given case is based on all facts and
circumstances. Accordingly, conduct that does not violate the rule in any single instance may nevertheless
constitute a violation if it becomes repeated or part of a broader collection of improper actions. Teams should
therefore refrain from any conduct – including public statements – that could be viewed as targeting or
expressing interest in another team’s player.
Under Article 35A of the NBA Constitution, it is a violation of the league’s anti-tampering rule for any person
affiliated with an NBA team to directly or indirectly (i) entice, induce, or persuade, or attempt to entice, induce,
or persuade, any player, coach, GM, or other person under contract to any other NBA team (or, in the case of
players, whose exclusive draft rights are held by such team) to enter into negotiations for or relating to that
person’s services or to negotiate or contract for such services, or (ii)otherwise interfere with the
employer-employee relationship (or prospective employer-employee relationship in the case of a drafted
player) between that employee and the other NBA team. The anti-tampering rule applies to all team
representatives. For this purpose, “team representative” includes persons holding ownership interests in the
team as well as all full-time or part-time personnel, officers, directors, employees, agents, or other
representatives of the team, and whether classified as “employee,” “consultant,” or otherwise. The rule also
applies to any other persons who are directed or authorized to act by team representatives. For example, it
would be a violation of the rule for a team to encourage or direct one of its players to recruit (whether privately
or publicly) a player under contract to another team.
Potential penalties for tampering include suspension of the offending person, prohibition of the offending team
from hiring the person who was tampered with, forfeiture of draft picks, and individual and/or team fines of up
to $10 million.
The scope of the anti-tampering rule is broad. Below are examples of conduct that is prohibited by the rule. For
purposes of illustration, these examples all involve contact with another team’s player. However, the rule
applies equally to contact with other personnel who are under contract with another team (such as a coach or
GM).
Examples of Prohibited Contact.
Direct Contact
208
Teams are prohibited from having any direct communications (e.g., meetings, telephone calls, texts, etc.) with
a player on another team that violates the restrictions described above, including expressions of interest in
obtaining the player’s current or future services. Contact with a player is permitted if authorized in advance by
the player’s current team. In addition, the rule does not prohibit social interaction required by courtesy, such as
a brief greeting to a player in the arena prior to a game. (Please note, however, that even social courtesies
could form the basis for a tampering violation if they are established to be intentional on the part of the team,
repeated, and/or done for the purpose of conveying interest in the player while he is under contract to another
team.)
Contact with Agent or Representative
Teams are prohibited from having communications with a player’s agent or other representative that would be
prohibited if made to the player. For example, contacting a player’s agent to express interest in trading for the
player or signing the player in a subsequent season would violate the rule.
Other Indirect Contact
The rule prohibits indirect communications, such as those made through intermediaries – e.g., a player’s family
member, friend, or personal trainer. For example, expressing interest in a player through his spouse would
violate the rule even if no direct contact is made with the player.
Public Statements. The rule also prohibits public statements that would violate the rule if made directly to a
player. This includes statements by a team or its personnel that are made at live events, on team websites, via
social media outlets, or to members of the media. For example, a public statement by a team’s GM that the
team is interested in acquiring another team’s player via trade would violate the rule. This also includes
statements made at events that may appear private but involve a likelihood of team comments being made
public, such as season ticket holder activities or sports conferences.
For clarity, isolated public comments by team representatives praising another team’s player will not be
regarded as violations of the anti-tampering rule unless aggravating circumstances are present. Potential
aggravating circumstances include:
(a) Stated interest in signing or trading for the player;
(b) Referencing the player’s fit (or lack thereof) with his current team or
(c) Referencing the amount of compensation a player deserves or is likely to be paid under a future
contract;
(d) Repeated or excessive praise of the player;
(e) Any other conduct, taking into account context, that is reasonably viewed as interfering with the
player’s relationship with his current team (including but not limited to conduct reasonably viewed as
constituting an expression of interest in obtaining the player’s current or future services).
So, for example, “Player A is a great player” would not be a tampering violation by an executive of Team B, but
“Player A would be a great fit for our team” would be a tampering violation.
As another example, brief statements made by a GM complimenting the ability of a player on another team in
response to questions from the media before a game would not be a tampering violation. On the other hand, a
209
series of unprompted tweets by a GM praising a prospective free agent on another team would constitute a
tampering violation.
Player-to-Player Tampering
The player tampering rule prohibits players from tampering with players and other team personnel. The rule is
enforced in the following ways:
(a) Tampering conduct or statements by a player that result from coordination with his team are prohibited. Put
differently, any conduct or statements that would violate the anti-tampering rule if undertaken directly by a team
will also violate the rule if coordinated with or effectuated through a player.
(b) Repeated or excessive public conduct or statements by a player that tamper with another team’s player are
prohibited. For example, a sustained public recruiting pitch by a player on Team A that he would like to play in
the future with a player on Team B would violate the rule.
(c) Conduct or statements by a player that induce another player to demand a trade will be regarded as
violative of the player tampering rule. For example, if a player on Team A suggests to a player on Team B that
the Team B player should demand a trade to Team A, the player on Team A has violated the player tampering
rule. It is not necessary that the conduct or statements actually induce a player to demand a trade – even an
attempt would be actionable under the player tampering rule. In addition, direct or indirect conduct or
statements of this kind by a player (such as by a player’s agent or family member) would violate the rule.
The tampering rule does not prohibit private discussions between or among players regarding future career
plans.
Free Agency
With respect to free agency, examples of prohibited conduct include (but are not limited to) public statements
by team personnel on the impending free agency of a player under contract with another team that address:
(1) The player’s desirability compared to other impending free agents;
(2) The player’s potential “fit” with a new team;
(3) Whether the player is currently being utilized well by his current team;
(4) The amount or length of the contract offer that the player is likely to receive through free agency;
(5) Whether a new team is “interested in,” “looking at,” “considering,” or “talking about” the player;
(6) The fact that “any team” or “every team” would be interested in acquiring the player;
(7) Whether a new team would be willing to go above the Salary Cap or the Tax Level in order to acquire the
player; or
(8) Whether a new team is seeking to acquire the player in a sign-and-trade transaction.
210
If a team employee or representative is asked by the media about a potential free agent prior to the July 1
following the last season covered by the player’s contract, or about any other person under contract to another
NBA team, the most prudent response is to decline comment.
If your team is interested in the coaching or other non-playing employment services of an impending free agent
and would like to speak with or comment publicly about the player prior to July 1, the proper first step is to call
the player’s existing team and obtain permission to speak with the player for this purpose. Similarly, if your
team is interested in the employment services of any employee under contract to another NBA team (other
than a player), the proper first step is to call the team and obtain permission to speak with the employee.

title: Q123: What is the anti-drug policy?
content:
No Marijuana Testing
There will be no testing for marijuana, and marijuana will no longer be on the Prohibited Substance List.
No More Needles
All HGH blood testing will be done via Dried Blood Spot Testing (drops of blood gathered via a small prick), and
there will be no more use of needles.
Reduced Penalties for Xanax, Valium
Players who test positive for Benzodiazepines (e.g., Xanax, Valium) will no longer be dismissed and
disqualified and will instead be subject to the same penalties as players who test positive for SPEDs (25-game
suspension for first offense).
Reduced Reinstatement Time Following Dismissal & Disqualification
Players dismissed and disqualified from the NBA for the use of hard drugs may apply for reinstatement in 12
months, reduced from 24 months.
Random Testing
In addition to the testing procedures set forth, a player shall be required to undergo urine testing for Prohibited
Substances at any time, without prior notice to the player, no more than four (4) times each Season and no
more than two (2) times during each Off-Season. The last day of a Season for a player shall be the day before
that player’s Off-Season begins.
Penalties
211
Any player who (i) tests positive for a SPED, Benzodiazepine, or Diuretic pursuant to Section 5 (Reasonable
Cause Testing or Hearing), Section 6 (Random Testing), or Section 16 (Additional Bases for Testing), or (ii) is
adjudged by the Grievance Arbitrator pursuant to Section 5(e) above to have used or possessed a SPED,
Benzodiazepine, or Diuretic, shall suffer the following penalties:
For the first such violation, the player shall be suspended for twenty-five (25) games and required to enter the
SPED Program (or the Drugs of Abuse Program if the positive test or the use or possession is for a
Benzodiazepine);
For the second such violation, the player shall be suspended for fifty-five (55) games and, if the player is not
then subject to in-patient or aftercare treatment in the SPED or Drugs of Abuse Program (as applicable), be
required to enter the SPED Program (or the Drugs of Abuse Program if the positive test or the use or
possession is for a Benzodiazepine); and
For the third such violation, the player shall be immediately dismissed and disqualified from any association
with the NBA or any of its Teams in accordance with the provisions of Section 12(a) below .
The penalties set forth above with respect to a player’s use of a SPED or Benzodiazepine may be reduced or
rescinded by the Grievance Arbitrator.
Note: See Exhibit 1-3 and 1-4 in the CBA for the list of banned drugs.
Reinstatement
After a period of at least one(1)year from the time of a player’s dismissal and disqualification, such player may
apply for reinstatement as a player in the NBA.
However, such players shall have no right to reinstatement under any circumstance and the reinstatement shall
be granted only with the prior approval of both the NBA and the Players Association, which shall not be
unreasonably withheld. The approval of the NBA and the Players Association shall rest in their absolute and
sole discretion, and their decision shall be final, binding, and unappealable. Among the factors that may be
considered by the NBA and the Players Association in determining whether to grant reinstatement are (without
limitation): the circumstances surrounding the player’s dismissal and disqualification; whether the player has
satisfactorily completed a treatment and rehabilitation program; the player’s conduct since his dismissal,
including the extent to which the player has since comported himself as a suitable role model for youth; and
whether the player is judged to possess the requisite qualities of good character and morality.
For a First-Year Player, the NBA and the Players Association will consider an application for reinstatement only
if the player has, in the opinion of the Medical Director or the SPED Medical Director (as applicable),
successfully completed any in-patient treatment and/or aftercare prescribed by the Medical Director or the
SPED Medical Director (as applicable). For a Veteran Player who was dismissed and disqualified in connection
with a Drug of Abuse, the NBA and the Players Association will consider any application for reinstatement only
if the player can demonstrate, by proof of random urine testing acceptable to the Medical Director (conducted
on at least a weekly basis), that he has not tested positive (i) for a Drug of Abuse or synthetic cannabinoid
within the twelve (12) months prior to the submission of his application for reinstatement and during any period
while his application is being reviewed, and (ii) if the Medical Director deems it necessary in his or her
212
professional judgment, for marijuana and/or alcohol for the six (6) months prior to the submission of his
application for reinstatement and during any period while his application is being reviewed. For a Veteran
Player who was dismissed and disqualified under Section 12(a) above in connection with a SPED, the NBA
and the Players Association will consider any application for reinstatement only if the player can demonstrate,
by proof of random urine and/or blood testing acceptable to the SPED Medical Director (conducted on at least
a weekly basis), that he has not tested positive for a SPED within the twelve (12) months prior to the
submission of his application for reinstatement and during any period while his application is being reviewed.
The granting of an application for reinstatement may be conditioned upon random testing of the player or such
other terms as may be agreed upon by the NBA and the Players Association.
Any player who has been reinstated and is subsequently dismissed and disqualified from any association with
the NBA or any of its Teams shall therefore be ineligible for reinstatement.
In the event that the application for reinstatement of a First-Year Player dismissed and disqualified pursuant to
Section 6(b) above is approved, such player, by reason of his Player Contract having been rendered null and
void, shall be deemed not to have completed his Player Contract by rendering the playing services called for
thereunder. Accordingly, such player shall not be a Free Agent and shall not be entitled to negotiate or sign a
Player Contract with any NBA Team, except with his prior team.
A First-Year Player who has been reinstated, immediately upon such reinstatement, notify the Team to which
he was under contract at the time of his dismissal and disqualification (the “previous Team”). Upon receipt of
such notification, the previous Team shall then have thirty (30) days in which to make a Tender to the player
with a stated term of at least one (1) full NBA Season (or, in the event that the Tender is made during a
Season, of at least the remainder of that Season) and calling for at least the Minimum Player Salary then
applicable to that player but not more than the Salary provided for in Section 13(f)(iii) below. If the previous
Team makes such a Tender, it shall, for a period of one (1) year from the date of the Tender, be the only NBA
Team with which the player may negotiate and sign a Player Contract. If the player does not sign a Player
Contract with the previous Team within the year following such Tender, the player shall thereupon be deemed a
Restricted Free Agent, subject to a Right of First Refusal. If the previous Team fails to make a Tender, the
player shall become an Unrestricted Free Agent.

title: Q124: What is the player conduct policy? When can a player get suspended or
content:
fined?
In addition to any other rights a Team or the NBA may have by contract (including but not limited to the rights
set forth in Paragraphs 9 and 16 of the Uniform Player Contract) or by law:
When a player (A) fails or refuses, without proper and reasonable cause or excuse, to render the services
required by a Player Contract or this Agreement, or (B) is suspended by his Team or the NBA for failing or
refusing, without proper and reasonable cause or excuse, to render the services required by a Player Contract
or this Agreement, the Current Base Compensation payable to the player for the year of the Contract during
which such failure or refusal and/or suspension occurs shall be reduced by 1/91.6th of the player’s Base
Compensation for each missed Exhibition, Regular Season, Play-In, or playoff game; and
213
If a player has a salary of $35,640,000 the fine for missed game is $389,082
When a player is, for proper cause other than the player’s failure or refusal to render the services required by a
Player Contract or this Agreement, suspended by his Team or the NBA in accordance with the terms of such
Contract or this Agreement, the Current Base Compensation payable to the player for the year of the Contract
during which such suspension occurs shall be reduced by (i) 1/145th of the player’s Base Compensation for
each missed Exhibition, Regular Season, Play-In, or playoff game for any suspension of fewer than twenty (20)
games and (ii) 1/110th of the player’s Base Compensation for each missed Exhibition, Regular Season,
Play-In, or playoff game for any suspension of twenty (20) games or more (including any indefinite suspension
that persists for twenty (20) games or more or consecutive suspensions for continuing acts or conduct that
persist for twenty (20) games or more).
Example
Player A has a salary of $20 million and is suspended for 5 games. The per game amount is $137,931 and a
total amount is $689,655.
Player B has a salary of $35 million and is suspended for 25 games. The per game amount is $318,182 and
total amount is $7,954,545.
New CBA rule
If such suspension is for conduct on the playing court and is a one-game suspension, the Current Base
Compensation payable to the player for the year of the Contract during which such suspension occurs shall be
reduced by an amount equal to the player’s Current Base Compensation for such Season multiplied by a
fraction, the numerator of which is one (1) and the denominator of which is the number of days in the Regular
Season.
For clarity, for any other game for which such player is suspended by his Team or the NBA during such
Season, the Current Base Compensation payable to the player for the year of the Contract during which such
suspension occurs shall be reduced.
Example
John Smith is suspended for one-game for failure to leave the court and has a salary of $5M.
The one game suspension is $28,736-1/174 (total days of the regular season).
Carryover Suspensions (New CBA rule)
If (i) a player has games remaining on a suspension at the time his Contract ends (because the player has
completed the playing services thereunder or because the Contract has been waived), or (ii) a suspension is
imposed upon a player when that player is a free agent, and – in either case – he, though otherwise able to
play, remains a free agent at the start of the next Regular Season (the “Next Season”):
214
His suspension will be deemed to have been served once his prior team has played a number of games in the
Next Season equal to 1.5 times the number of games that remained on the term of the suspension (with any
half games rounded up to the nearest whole number)
EXAMPLE: Patrick Beverley is suspended 4 games for the 2024-25 regular season.
Beverley signed a player contract in Israel for the 2024-25 season.
The suspension will be deemed served after Milwaukee (his prior team) plays six regular season games.
If the player subsequently signs one or more Player Contracts, the player’s total Compensation for the Next
Season (or the first subsequent Season thereafter for which he signs a Player Contract if he does not sign a
Player Contract for the Next Season) under one or more Contracts will be reduced in accordance with Article
VI, Section 1 of the CBA for the number of games that had been remaining on the suspension at the start of
the Next Season.
For clarity, if a player remains unsigned at the start of the Next Season for some number of games but not the
total number of games for which he needed to remain unsigned to be deemed to have served his suspension,
he will be credited for two- thirds of the games he missed while he remained unsigned (rounded to the nearest
whole number) and he will serve the remainder of the suspension upon signing a Contract.

title: Q125: What happens if a player fails to report?
content:
A player who withholds playing services called for by a Player Contract for more than thirty (30) days after the
start of the last Season covered by his Player Contract shall be deemed not to have “completed his Player
Contract by rendering the playing services called for thereunder.” Accordingly, such a player shall not be a
Veteran Free Agent and shall not be entitled to negotiate or sign a Player Contract with any other professional
basketball team unless and until the Team for which the player last played expressly agreed otherwise.
Example
If James Harden were to withhold services for more than thirty days, he would not be allowed to negotiate a
new contract as a free agent in 2024 unless the 76ers agreed.

title: Q126: What are the maximum fines for conduct detrimental or when a player asks to be traded?
content:
Conduct or Statements Detrimental; Tampering. The maximum player fine that may be imposed for (1)
conduct or statements prejudicial or detrimental to the best interests of basketball, the NBA, or a team, or (2)
violations of the tampering rules, will be $100,000.
Public Trade Demands. Any player (or, for clarity, any player representative or person acting with authority on
behalf of a player) who publicly expresses a desire to be traded to another Team shall be subject to a fine
215
and/or a suspension. The maximum fine that may be imposed by the NBA on a player pursuant to the
foregoing shall be $150,000.
Certain On- and Off-Court Conduct
Leaving the Bench Area
In administering the rule regarding a player leaving the bench area in connection with an altercation during a
game and determining whether discipline will be imposed, the league office will take into account the following
factors, as well as any other relevant facts and circumstances: (1) the distance the player traveled from the
bench, and (2) the extent to which he entered the immediate proximity of the altercation.
Throwing Objects into the Stands
A player who throws or kicks an object into the stands (including a player who throws or kicks an object at the
basket stanchion when the object lands in the stands) will receive a technical foul and be subject to an
automatic ejection and a fine and/or suspension, provided that throwing or kicking the ball into the stands or at
the basket stanchion will only result in an automatic ejection and a fine and/or suspension if the ball was
thrown or kicked with force.
Profanity
The use of profanity will not result in discipline in the following instances, provided that, in all circumstances,
any egregious and/or persistent use of profanity will result in discipline: (1) outside the arena, including in
media appearances or interviews; (2) in an interview conducted courtside immediately following the end of a
quarter or the game; and (3) in addressing the media before or after a practice or game. For clarity, use of
racist, sexist, homophobic, or other discriminatory or derogatory language will remain prohibited at all times
and will subject a player to appropriate discipline.
Criticism of Game Officials
Rule I.O.3 of the annual Player Conduct, NBA Uniform Requirements, Dress Code, and Other Player-Related
Matters memorandum will be revised to provide that a player who publicly criticizes game officials will be
considered to be acting in a manner prejudicial or detrimental to the NBA and subject to appropriate discipline
only when the criticism is unprofessional or inappropriate.
Player and Game Official Conduct
On a quarterly basis, the NBA and Players Association will meet to discuss the relationship and interactions
between players and NBA referees, including any discipline imposed by the NBA on referees for conduct on
the playing court.
Fines Imposed on Teams
216
For any fine imposed on a team, team Governor, or other team personnel by the NBA for violations of league
rules regarding (A) injury, illness, rest, and game status reporting, (B) timing of free agency discussions, (C)
tampering, (D) leaving the bench area during a game, or (E) team criticism of game officials, 50% of such fine
amount will be payable to the NBA and 50% will be payable to an NBPA-Selected Charitable Organization (as
defined in Article VI, Section 6(a) of the CBA); provided, however, that the maximum amount payable to an
NBPA-Selected Charitable Organization will be 50% of the amount of the maximum fine that could be imposed
on a player for engaging in the conduct at issue and provided further that where there is no specified maximum
fine for a player, the maximum amount payable to the NBPA-Selected Charitable Organization will be $50,000
(i.e., 50% of $100,000).
How the rule works: If the Mavericks were fined $750K under the new CBA, $375K would have gone to the
Players Association.
Practices
When a player, without proper and reasonable excuse, fails to attend a practice session scheduled by his
Team, he shall be subject to the following discipline: (i) for the first missed practice during a Season – $2,500;
(ii) for the second missed practice during such Season – $5,000; (iii) for the third missed practice during such
Season – $7,500; and (iv) for the fourth (or any additional) missed practice during such Season – such
discipline as is reasonable under the circumstances.
When a player, without proper and reasonable excuse, refuses or intentionally fails to attend any practice
session scheduled by his Team, he shall be subject to such discipline as is reasonable under the
circumstances.
Other Fines
●   Mandatory Programs: $20K
●   Promotional Appearances: $20K
●   Media Training: $20K
●   Business of Basketball: $5K
●   Anti-Gambling Sessions: $100K
Unlawful Violence
When a player is convicted of (including by a plea of guilty, no contest, or nolo contendere to) a violent felony,
he shall immediately be suspended by the NBA for a minimum of ten (10) games.
Firearms and Other Weapons.
Whenever a player is physically present at a facility or venue owned, operated, or being used by a Team, the
NBA, or any League-related entity, and whenever a player is traveling on any NBA-related business, whether
on behalf of the player’s Team, the NBA, or any League-related entity, such player shall not possess a firearm
of any kind or any other deadly weapon. For purposes of the foregoing, “a facility or venue” includes, but is not
limited to: an arena; a practice facility; a Team or League office or facility; a facility or venue used for an NBA
217
event (such as an In-Season Tournament, All-Star, or NBA playoff venue); and the site of a promotional or
charitable appearance.
At the commencement of each Season, and if the player owns or possesses any firearm, the player will
provide the Team with proof that the player possesses a license or registration as required by law for any such
firearm. Each player is also required to provide the Team with proof of any modifications or additions made to
this information during the Season.
(c) Any violation shall be considered conduct prejudicial to the NBA under Article 35(d) of the NBA Constitution
and By-Laws,and shall therefore subject the player to discipline by the NBA in accordance with such Article.
One Penalty
The NBA and a Team shall not discipline players for the same act or conduct. The NBA’s disciplinary action will
preclude or supersede disciplinary action by any Team for the same act or conduct.
When the NBA becomes aware of any potential or actual disciplinary action which may be or has been
imposed by a Team for a player’s act or conduct, the NBA may, within forty-eight (48) hours, prohibit the
discipline from being imposed or rescind the discipline that has been imposed, as applicable. If the NBA
prohibits or rescinds the discipline, only the NBA shall thereafter be permitted to impose discipline on the
player for that act or conduct. If the NBA does not prohibit or rescind the Team’s discipline, the Team may
impose its proposed discipline or the Team’s discipline will remain in effect, as applicable, and, if the Team’s
discipline becomes effective or remains in effect, the NBA may not thereafter impose discipline on the player
for that act or conduct.
The same act or conduct by a player may result in both a termination of the player’s Uniform Player Contract
by his Team and the suspension of the player by the NBA if the egregious nature of the act or conduct is so
lacking in justification as to warrant such double penalty, and (ii) both the NBA and the Team to which a player
is traded may impose discipline for a player’s failure to report for a trade.
League Investigations.
Players are required to cooperate with investigations of alleged player misconduct conducted by the NBA.
Failure to so cooperate, in the absence of a reasonable apprehension of criminal prosecution, will subject the
player to reasonable fines and/or suspensions imposed by the NBA. Any investigations of alleged misconduct
that is covered by the Joint NBA/NBPA Policy on Domestic Violence, Sexual Assault, and Child Abuse shall be
governed by the terms of that Policy.
The NBA shall provide the Players Association with such advance notice as is reasonable in the circumstances
of any interview or meeting to be held (in person or by telephone) between an NBA representative and a player
under investigation
Player Arrests
A Team shall not impose discipline on a player solely on the basis of the fact that the player has been arrested.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, (a) a Team may impose discipline on a player for the conduct underlying the
218
player’s arrest if it has an independent basis for doing so, (b) nothing herein shall permit a Team to discipline a
player for his failure to cooperate with a Team’s investigation of his alleged misconduct if he has a reasonable
apprehension of criminal prosecution, and (c) nothing herein shall prevent a Team from precluding a player
from participating in Team activities without loss of pay to the extent it otherwise has the right to do so.

title: Q127: What is the league’s domestic violence program?
content:
The parties have agreed to the Joint NBA/NBPA Policy on Domestic Violence, Sexual Assault, and Child
Abuse (and any amendments thereto), which is attached below.
Any evaluation, counseling, treatment, and/or discipline of a player for engaging in acts covered by this Policy
shall be governed by the terms of the Policy.

227
228
229
Trades
Any player (or, for clarity, any player representative or person acting with authority on behalf of a player) who
publicly expresses a desire to be traded to another Team shall be subject to a fine and/or a suspension. The
maximum fine that may be imposed by the NBA on a player pursuant to the foregoing shall be $150,000.
Gambling by Former NBAGL Players.
A player shall be subject to discipline imposed by the NBA for violations of NBAGL rules pertaining to gambling
involving the NBA, NBAGL, and/or NBA-affiliated leagues that were committed during any prior period of time
230
during which the player was subject to NBAGL rules relating to gambling. The NBA may impose such discipline
only in circumstances where, and only to the extent that, discipline would be authorized by the NBA under this
Agreement for the same conduct under NBA rules pertaining to gambling by players involving the NBA,
NBAGL, and/or NBA-affiliated leagues.
Any player suspended by the NBAGL for violations of the NBAGL rules pertaining to gambling involving the
NBA, NBAGL, and/or NBA- affiliated leagues who signs a Uniform Player Contract before the full term of the
suspension is served shall serve the remainder of the suspension in the NBA. In addition, any player
suspended under NBAGL rules pertaining to gambling involving the NBA, NBAGL, and/or NBA-affiliated
leagues whose NBAGL contract ends before the full term of the suspension is served shall be subject to Article
VI, Section 1(c) of this Agreement with respect to the NBAGL suspension if, at the start of the following NBA
Regular Season, he is a Free Agent who has games remaining to be served on the NBAGL suspension. For
purposes of Article VI, Section 1(c), the “Team to which he was under contract when the suspension was
imposed” shall be deemed to be the NBA team, with which the player first signs a Player Contract following
imposition of the NBAGL suspension.
What is the process when a player wants to file a grievance?
Grievances May Be Initiated,as set forth below,by player,a Team, the NBA, or the Players Association, except
that the Players Association may not initiate a Grievance involving player discipline without the approval of the
player(s) concerned.
A Grievance must be initiated, within thirty (30) days from the date of the occurrence upon which the Grievance
is based, or within thirty (30) days from the date upon which the facts of the matter became known or
reasonably should have become known to the party initiating the Grievance, whichever is later.
Upon at least thirty (30) days’ written notice to the other side, the NBA and the Players Association may
arrange to have a hearing scheduled on a date that is mutually convenient to the parties to the dispute, the
NBA, the Players Association, and the Grievance Arbitrator; provided, however, that if the NBA and the Players
Association cannot agree on a hearing date, the Grievance Arbitrator shall set a reasonable hearing date that
follows the expiration of the thirty-day notice period. Only the NBA and the Players Association may schedule
or postpone hearings before the Grievance Arbitrator.
Dispute Involving (i) a fine of $50,000 or less or suspension of twelve (12) games or fewer (or both such fine
and suspension) imposed upon a player by the Commissioner (or his designee) for (x) conduct on the playing
court or (y) for in-game conduct involving another player, or (ii) action taken by the Commissioner (or his
designee) (A) concerning the preservation of the integrity of, or the maintenance of public confidence in, the
game of basketball and (B) resulting in a financial impact on the player of $50,000 or less, shall not give rise to
a Grievance, shall not be subject to a hearing before, or resolution by, the Grievance Arbitrator, and shall not
be determined by arbitration; but instead shall be processed exclusively as follows:
Within twenty (20) days following written notification of the action taken by the Commissioner (or his designee),
the Players Association (with the approval of the player involved) may appeal in writing to the Commissioner.
231
Upon the written request of the Players Association, the Commissioner shall designate a time and place for a
hearing as soon as is reasonably practicable following his receipt of the notice of appeal.
As soon as reasonably practicable, but not later than twenty (20) days, following the conclusion of such
hearing, the Commissioner shall render a written decision, which decision shall, constitute full, final, and
complete disposition of the dispute, and shall be binding upon the player(s) and Team(s) involved and the
parties to this Agreement.
In the event such appeal involves a fine and/or suspension imposed by the Commissioner’s designee, the
Commissioner, as a consequence of such appeal and hearing, shall have authority only to affirm or reduce
such fine and/or suspension, and shall not have authority to increase such fine and/or suspension.
If a dispute is not resolved in a manner satisfactory to the player, then the Players Association may (with the
approval of such player) seek review of the financial impact of the Commissioner’s decision by filing a written
request for such review with the Player Discipline Arbitrator (as provided for below) within ten (10) days
following the issuance of such decision, and the following procedures shall apply:
Following receipt of the written request for review, the Player Discipline Arbitrator shall schedule a meeting with
the player, the Players Association, and the NBA (and such representatives as each may designate), shall
review the relevant facts and circumstances, and shall issue a decision affirming or reducing the financial
penalty imposed by the Commissioner. All such meetings shall be in person, shall be held in New York
(alternating between the NBA and Players Association offices), and shall be conducted during the month of
September following the conclusion of the Season in which the in-game conduct involving another player
occurred.

title: Q128: What are the health and safety protocols?
content:
Streamlined EMR Access: Players will have full and easy access to their medical reports via a new mobile
app.
No Mandatory Vaccines or Wearable Use: The current practice of vaccinations not being required and
wearable use being voluntary will continue.
Stricter Reporting Guidelines for Player Injuries: For a player projected to miss more than two weeks, the
first public injury disclosure from the team may only describe when the player will be re-evaluated by the team,
as opposed to when he will return to play, thereby reducing the stress on players to return too early from injury.
Quality Control of Player Health via EMR Reports to NBPA: NBA will provide EMR summary reports to
enable NBPA to monitor and complete quality-control checks regarding team/NBA medical practices.
232
Third-Party Trainers: Third-party trainers used by players will have to meet industry- standard certification
requirements.

title: Q129: Can a player earn additional finances outside of their contract?
content:
Sports Betting Promotion: Players will be entitled to do endorsement deals relating to sports betting and
fantasy, so long as they are not promoting NBA basketball.
Sports Betting Investment: Players will be entitled to own an interest in sports betting and fantasy
companies.
Cannabis Investment: Players will be entitled to invest in companies that make products containing
marijuana.
CBD Promotion & Investment: Players will be entitled to endorse and invest in companies that make CBD
products.
Investment in WNBA Teams: Players will be entitled to invest in independently owned WNBA teams (not
owned by NBA governors).
Investment Alongside Governors: Players will have increased flexibility to invest alongside governors in
non-NBA businesses (5% safe harbor limit increased to 12.5%).

title: Q130: What are the licensing agreements in the CBA?
content:
Protective Group License Language: The group license participation provision will be reinserted in the
Uniform Player Contract to strengthen and protect the program and players’ distribution amounts. Participation
in the NBPA group license program – and only our program – would be the rule going forward.
Access to Game Footage and Photos: Better and easier access for players and the NBPA to game footage
and photos for non-commercial use.
NBA App and NBA TV Opportunities: Devoted section on the NBA App for NBPA content and opportunities
to access time for players and the NBPA on NBA TV.
Expanded Appearance Provisions: If requested, players will participate in one content- creation session
made available for use by the league or the player involving a sit-down interview or performance in a major
NBA brand campaign (i.e., NBA Lane).
233

title: Q131: What are the player benefits that improved in the CBA?
content:
Post-Career Income Plan Pandemic Catch-up: Contributions will be made in 2025-26 to the Post-Career
Income Plan accounts for all eligible players from 2019-20 and 2020-21 players. Those contributions had been
forfeited as part of the force majeure settlement covering the two pandemic seasons but will now be reinstated.
Total cost of funding is in excess of $125 million.
Pension Increase: The plan’s actuarial calculations will be modified to provide the highest benefit level
allowed by law.
Two-Way Player Benefit Improvements: Two-Way Players will no longer need to contribute to the cost of
their health insurance, will receive a full 401k match, and will receive credit for years of service toward pension
and health reimbursement benefits.
Increased Tuition Reimbursement Plan: The maximum reimbursement for Tuition Assistance players will
increase from $101,000 to $125,000, and more liberal tolling provisions will be installed to allow for a greater
time period in which the benefit can be used.
Playoff Pool: The playoff pool amounts, which grow annually with BRI, will not be permitted to decrease, and
will increase next season by 15%. Provisions have also been put in place to address issues regarding
non-player team personnel sharing in the players’ pool.
Legacy Fund: The funding of the Legacy Fund assisting retired players in need will increase by 50%, shared
equally by the NBA and NBPA.
Benefits Portal: A new portal will be created allowing players better and easier access to specific benefits
information.

title: Q132: What BRI impacted the players in this CBA?
content:
● Licensing: For the first time since the inception of the Salary Cap / Revenue Sharing system 40 years
ago, team and league licensing revenue from deals where players are not already directly receiving
payment as part of the transaction will be included in Basketball Related Income (BRI). This is expected
to add approximately $160M to BRI in 2023-24, growing annually.
● BRI Improvements: Revenue sharing formula will be enhanced in multiple ways, including with respect
to the treatment of complimentary tickets, team watch parties, barter expenses, plaza naming rights,
and treatment of equity transactions. Under the negotiated formula for “Forecasted BRI,” players are
again expected to receive 51% of BRI throughout the course of the agreement, resulting in a projected
$250 million collective increase in Salaries and Benefits in the 2023-24 Season. Depending on the
success of our business, players are expected to earn between $45-50 billion in Salaries and Benefits
over the full 7-year term of the CBA.
234
● Team Audits: The maximum number of NBPA team audits will increase from 10 per year to an average
of 15 per year. A two-year “lookback” effectively allows for the NBPA to make adjustments each year for
all 30 teams. The NBPA also continues to have the right to audit the NBA league office annually. These
audits are in addition to the annual joint NBPA/NBA comprehensive audit of all 30 teams by
PricewaterhouseCoopers.
